PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gibson)—by leave—agreed to:

That the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee be authorised to hold a public hearing during the sitting of the Senate today, from 8.00 pm for its consideration of the 1997‐98 additional estimates.
Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) proposed:
That government business notice of motion No. 1 standing in the name of Senator Ian Campbell, relating to a proposal for capital works in the parliamentary zone, be postponed till a later hour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will support the proposal that has been moved by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Ian Campbell) that government business notice of motion No. 1 be postponed to a later hour this day. I draw the Senate's attention to the implications of this for the Senate's program. I am particularly concerned that the government has not brought the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 on for debate today and, according to the order of business, has no intention of bringing that particular government business order of the day on for debate today. In fact, it does not propose to bring the legislation on for debate until after the dinner adjournment tomorrow.

SPEECH.PARA: It ought to be of concern to all senators that, on the first day of the last week of the scheduled sittings for this year, the government is still not proposing to bring the bill on until late tomorrow. Not only has the government not brought this important legislation on for debate, it has listed some nine bills or packages of bills ahead of the Native Title Amendment Bill on the Notice Paper today. That ought to be of massive concern to the Senate and to the people of Australia.

Anyone with an interest in the native title issue should take note that in the government's view all this other legislation is of higher priority and of more importance than the native title bill. The Senate is entitled to an explanation from the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill). I request, Madam President, that Senator Hill provide the Senate with an explanation after question time today as to why it is that all these bills are, in the government's view, of higher priority for debate than the native title bill. That goes for the superannuation package, the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1997 , which I understand has only a short amount of time remaining for debate, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 , the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Parenting and Other Measures) Bill 1997 , the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 and the migration legislation package. Perhaps Senator Hill could inform the Senate after question time today why it is the government's view that the Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1997 , the Migration Agents Registration Application Charge Bill 1997 and the Migration Agents Registration Renewal Charge Bill 1997 are all of higher importance, of greater significance and priority, than the native title bill.

While he is at it, he could deal with the other bills that are on the Notice Paper and that are to be considered before debate is scheduled for the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997— the Productivity Commission Bill 1996 , the Productivity Commission (Repeals, Transitional and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996 and so on. It is of concern to me that we have the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) saying to the Australian Senate that we ought to get on with the job. On 16 November, Mr Howard said, `Tell the Senate to get on with the job.'
On the AM program on 21 November 1997, Mr Howard said:

BREAK.PARA: The average Australian I speak to is heartily sick of this issue—
Let me interpolate—the issue is the issue of the Wik legislation. Mr Howard said:
The average Australian is saying to me, `Get the thing through. Get it out of the way. We are fed up hearing about it.'
We are saying to the government, `Bring the bill on. The time has come; get it out of the way.'

Let me also say that there had been an understanding that the government would be using the time after the dinner suspension tonight, on a no divisions no quorum basis, to get right into the second reading debate on this bill. There was also an agreement on a no divisions, no quorum basis to continue after the dinner suspension tomorrow night so that we could conclude the second reading debate. The committee stage of the native title bill could then have commenced on Wednesday morning.

According to the government's own order of business, we do not have any other intention from the government but to start the second reading debate on this legislation on the same basis—that is, no divisions, no quorums—after the suspension of the sitting for dinner tomorrow. There are at least 14 speakers from the government alone who flagged their intention to speak on this bill, and probably an equal number from the opposition. No doubt, many minor party senators and Independent senators also want to make a contribution, and I do not decry that in any way. This is amongst the most important legislation that will be dealt with during the life of this parliament, and I am sure senators on both sides of the chamber would agree with that. There is a significant number who want to make a contribution and there is a need for them to be able to do that in the time that is available. But it is not satisfactory to have this situation.
It ought to be noted that the Manager of Government Business, Senator Campbell, wrote to all parties in the chamber on 22 October seeking agreement to sit an extra week. He said:
The Government intends to deal with the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 in the week commencing November 24th.
These two sitting weeks will provide over 40 hours to debate the Native Title Amendment Bill.
The truth of the matter is that we have a situation—

TALK.START.PARA: —Incorporate the letter.

—I am happy for all the correspondence from Senator Campbell, and the response to that correspondence from Senator Carr, to be incorporated in Hansard . I do not have that material with me at the moment, but I will quickly get copies of it, and I am very happy to incorporate all the correspondence in Hansard . I thank the Manager of Government Business for his invitation. I think it will be a very useful addition to the record.

BREAK.PARA: Currently, in this session of parliament about 52 per cent of the Senate's time—

TALK.START.PARA: —Gee, I wish I had known that.

—That is right, Senator Ray—52 per cent of the Senate's time has been spent dealing with government business. That is extraordinarily unusual in this place. I suspect that it is an all‐time record. It is a very significant achievement for any government.
—Sixty-six per cent last week.

—Yes, last week 66 per cent of the Senate's time was dedicated to government business. This is just unheard of in the Senate. We have a situation where the government is applying this sort of leverage to the Senate to say, `We'll get on with an important piece of legislation that Mr Howard, the Prime Minister, demands the Senate get on with. We'll get on with it after every other piece of legislation and everything else the government in the Senate determines it wants to do, but only then.' Mr Howard should get the message across to those in the Senate who are responsible for ensuring that his will is carried out. Quite clearly, the government in the Senate does not seem to have the same intentions as the Prime Minister. This is a very serious issue for all of us.

BREAK.PARA: I ask that the Leader of the Government in the Senate come forward after question time today and in a brief statement outline to the Senate the government's intentions in relation to the Native Title Amendment Bill . I think the Senate is entitled to an explanation from Senator Hill as to why this other legislation has priority over the Native Title Amendment Bill and why the government proposes to commence debate on the second reading stage of this legislation on Tuesday evening when senators agreed informally that it would be appropriate to allow that particular time. That is extra sitting time too, I might say. As you would be aware, Madam President, the Senate does not normally sit on a Tuesday evening. It was informally agreed that that time would be used to conclude—on a `no quorums, no divisions' basis—the second reading debate on this bill so that the committee stage of the bill could commence on Wednesday morning.

You would know, Madam President—and I am sure all senators in the chamber would know—that unless we do what the Prime Minister asks—that is, get on with the debate as soon as possible—it is going to be extremely difficult to conclude it in the time remaining for the Senate. The opposition has already said, `Yes, sure, sit an extra week to allow the last two weeks of the sittings for this year to be effectively dedicated to this important issue that remains to be dealt with by the Senate.'

I believe that Mr Howard's entreaties, which were for the Senate to get on with the job, are ones that Mr Howard's colleagues over here ought to take seriously. I am disappointed that the government in the Senate appears willing to defy the commitment that the Prime Minister has given and the intentions that the Prime Minister has so clearly expressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the cat's away, the mice will play.

—That is probably right. But I think the mice are playing games other than just this one, as you would know, Senator Ray. I understand that the phones are running hot in Mr Reith's and Mr Costello's offices at this time, and no doubt we will see a lot of grandstanding. I predict that in the House of Representatives in question time this week we will see a lot of posturing from those who are tilting as alternative leaders of the Liberal Party.

BREAK.PARA: But the serious issue here is that Mr Howard has said to get on with the job and that is what ought to be done. I think Senator Hill owes the Senate an explanation and, through you, Madam President, I ask that he provide the chamber with that explanation after question time today. I do not think that we can take seriously any contribution that might be made on these issues by the Manager of Government Business. That is why I think the Leader of the Government in the Senate ought to come down and explain to us what is happening. I think that is not unreasonable in these circumstances, particularly given what the Prime Minister has said in relation to the importance of this debate and the public expectation that the Senate will start to deal with the Native Title Amendment Bill as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall not be long because we do need to focus on the matters that are before us. But I must say in fairness to the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Ian Campbell) that he has made it perfectly clear to me in all events—whether he has made it clear to anybody else I do not know—that the government was looking at reducing to a bare minimum the number of pieces of legislation it wants the parliament to have considered by Christmas.

SPEECH.PARA: Last week we did have a quite extensive debate on Public Service and other issues, but that was unavoidable. I hope that the minister concerned understands that we did have a look at that and looked at the amended legislation on its merits. I believe the government, if it examined the amendments that the Senate has passed, could live with them. If the legislation does come back here, I hope it does so in a form that we can deal with with due alacrity.

Again, I say in fairness to the Manager of Government Business that he has made that very clear. This may well take a little more time. I indicate to the Manager of Government Business just as an aside that it is a little surprising to me that the Wik bill is to be adjourned till after the superannuation legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it's not. We could've had it done by now except for this.

—I am sorry. It is on. That is fine. I do not intend to do anything other than my best to honour what I thought was my response to the government, recognising that it has concertinaed its legislative program to deal with the essential matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The Native Title Amendment Bill is an extraordinarily important piece of legislation that is coming before us. We will need to examine that and discharge it in the manner in which we have responsibility to do so. We are the legislators. We need to respond to not only Wik but also Brandy and a couple of other decisions. I think those amendments that will make the Native Title Act fully workable will be welcomed on all sides of the chamber.
We need to respond to the Wik decision. We should bear in mind Graham Hiley's preface to Wik Case Issues and Implications by Butterworth:
The Wik decision

All that the decision did was to hold that the granting of a pastoral lease, whether or not the lease has now expired or has otherwise been terminated, did not necessarily extinguish all native title rights and interests that might otherwise exist.

Bearing that in mind, and bearing in mind the fact that quite a large range of questions arise from that for us and not the courts to determine if we are to act as legislators, we will need a considerable amount of time to deal with that.

It is my view and I think the view of most of us that the legislation should be determined before Christmas. I make it perfectly clear that I am prepared to meet on Friday of this week and Friday of next week and every night this week, next week and the week after as well if that is what it takes to deal with this matter properly and effectively and with fairness and justice. I am prepared to sit as necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine makes the point that the government is entitled to its concertinaed legislation. I agree with that basically. But I do reflect back, Senator Harradine, that on two occasions in the period 1995-96 we actually had agreements from the then opposition to get to a certain point in the program before we departed. On both occasions their word was betrayed. On both occasions the chamber got up before we got to that—that is, after I and others jettisoned off a whole range of legislation to get the program down to a minimum. On two occasions we did not even get to the minimum. On one occasion Senator Hill told us we would, and then he disappeared off overseas and the rest of the coalition went home. So that happened on two occasions towards the end of the Keating government.

SPEECH.PARA: But this is about leverage. This is about saying, `Wik is essentially so important that we can take the opportunistic tactic of putting everything else on before it rather than after it.' You ask yourself, `Why not get on with Wik and put these other legislative items on afterwards?' The simple reason is that the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Ian Campbell) cannot hold his backbench on this. He knows that when they get the smell of a water hole they will be off home. That is why these particular bills have been shoved in before Wik, because he cannot control his own backbench. `Shove them all in now' is the argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —How are those cheap Qantas fares going? Two for one, if I remember.

—The old cheap Qantas fares. We did not fly to LA first class just to dodge going business class, Senator Campbell. In fact, I would keep a bit of a low profile, if I were you, after your grand statement hidden away in Western Australia about the wonderful region of Canberra. I would hide from that and from the Sunday Times article exposing your horrible past with the left‐wing Democrats. Senator Murray, why didn't you tell me he was a member of the left wing of the Democrats in Western Australia? Why did I have to read about it in the Sunday Times ? Senator Campbell, do not divert me, because this is going to be a very brief contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things we feel a bit annoyed about is that we were approached to sit on Tuesday to conclude second readings. You are proposing now apparently to not start second readings until Tuesday night.

TALK.START.PARA: —We didn't approach you.
—Are you sure of that?
—We offered it up, in fact.
—You offered it.

—And you accepted it. I see; you do not have to keep your word when you accept an offer, only when you make one. That has established a new principle in managing this particular system. Nevertheless, it is unrealistic on your current program to finish second readings on Tuesday. One wonders, given the fact that you have other government business on Wednesday, when exactly you will finish the second readings on this particular matter.

SPEECH.PARA: But I suppose what irritated me the most was reading in the press the grandstanding by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on the Senate and Wik. The implication of what he was saying is, `Nasty old Senate won't deal with Wik. Why don't they get on with the job? Why doesn't the Senate address this legislation and dispose of it?' We have had the answer today. We will not do that, because these opportunists opposite want to use Wik as leverage to get other legislation through.

The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Faulkner, has made a very valid point. We will not deal with it now, but we at least expect Senator Hill to come in and outline to the Senate when in fact the government intend to deal with Wik and how they intend to deal with it. That would be useful for the process and progressing of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 . But it is disappointing, as Senator Faulkner has pointed out, to find that the Prime Minister so lacks authority these days that even the humble Manager of Government Business can snub his nose at him while the Prime Minister is in Vancouver and not bring this on for debate.

I want to make only two other points. I thought we had been relatively cooperative in the government's legislative program. The opposition has not moved any urgency motions or MPIs for two or three weeks. We agreed to sit later on Tuesday and later on Wednesday night and to give up Wednesday general matters of public interest across the non‐controversial legislation. So, having done that, we have tried to get this particular program going.

But it raises one other question. Normally, before today's performance, we would have been willing to give up our general business on Thursday night or make arrangements to take government business through to a certain point and start general business a lot later, on the same sort of no divisions no quorums basis. We are going to have to revisit that, because we do have at least one important item that we want considered this year. Rather than give that up, we may have to reconsider that. If you want to get cooperation on these particular matters, you should be fairly transparent with us on exactly what you intend to do. The questions for Senator Hill to come down and answer are when is he going to start Wik, when does he anticipate the second readings to be completed by and when is the committee stage to start.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I just wanted to as briefly as possible put the government's point of view. It has been made clear, as Senator Harradine said, from the outset, when negotiations for an extra sitting week began some weeks ago, that the government's agenda, as it was put down at that stage, envisaged commencing debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 today. That was prefaced on a program that allowed time for the debate of a range of other bits of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The record of the Senate shows that in that time it has made reasonably good progress with a number of bills. However, last week we had a program that had a number of pieces of legislation on it and the only difference between the program of the Senate at 12.30 last Monday and the program of the Senate at 12.30 today is that the Senate was able to deal with effectively one piece of legislation—that was the Public Service Bill. We finished the child-care debate, so that was passed within the first hour or so last Monday. Apart from that, the Senate sat for one entire day plus two half days and dealt with one piece of legislation. The record will show that the consideration of that legislation was lengthy. I have the statistics on how long each speaker spoke for during that debate. All the people involved in that debate have indicated that the debate went for much longer than it should have gone for.

TALK.START.PARA: —No they haven't.
—Senator Murray doesn't. He thinks—
—And no divisions were called.
—No divisions were called. But the debate took all of one sitting week, which ensured that the Senate could not deal with any of the other items.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not a full sitting week.
—It was not a full sitting week.

—I have just said, Senator Faulkner, that you sat for one day and two half‐days. You did not sit on Thursday because you had to do estimates and you did not sit on Friday. You took 14 hours on the Public Service Bill 1997 . We had hoped to finish a range of other pieces of legislation last week and we still hope to finish that.
—Why don't you do it after Wik?

—Senator Ray, you have already answered that question. What everyone else should know is that we made an offer to the opposition late last week, bearing in mind that the Public Service Bill went probably twice as long as anyone expected it to—at least twice as long as I ex pected it to—to start the second reading debate at 9.30 this morning. Just about everybody is in Canberra already; you could have had a no divisions/no quorum situation and actually got three hours of second reading debate out of the way by now. But the opposition said, `No, we don't want to do that.' We made them an offer to actually start the native title debate at 9.30 this morning. That was rejected, so they are not particularly serious. They are still taking their own amendments through caucus. They are still taking Senator Bolkus's amendments through shadow cabinet this morning and through caucus tomorrow. So had we even got to that stage, they would not have been ready. I think the public should know that.

SPEECH.PARA: We should also go back and look at how Senator Faulkner managed government business during the native title debate in 1993. It is an absolute classic. I refer anyone who is interested to the Hansard of 17 December—I think it was the 17th; I might be out by one day but it was certainly the longest Hansard in the history of Australia and it was the longest day in the parliamentary history of Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—Senator Faulkner, I would commend that you look at that Hansard . The coalition at that stage—the opposition—guaranteed the government its entire program. Senator Hill, the then Leader of the Opposition, signed off a list with Senator Faulkner, the then Manager of Government Business in the Senate, and said, `We will complete all of this legislation.' At 4.09 on that day—the final scheduled day of sitting—Senator Gareth Evans came into this place and brought on the native title debate. He brought it on after we had completed every other single piece of legislation. As I recall, after the native

SPEECH.PARA: title debate had been concluded we sat till well after midnight to ensure that the government got their other pieces of legislation through as well and then we went home. In fact, I recall Senator MacGibbon talking on some piece of defence legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.
—I remember Senator Baden Teague speaking on an education package. That is the contrast.

SPEECH.PARA: All the coalition ever said is that we want to allow a full debate on the native title legislation and we also want to get these other pieces of legislation done. We have also, as Senator Harradine was kind enough to point out, taken out of the package every single piece of legislation that we can do without. We need the super bills, and senators involved in that debate know why. We need to debate all of the other packages. They could all be debated fairly quickly.

Quite frankly, from what I have been told, had we started the legislative program at 12.30 p.m. we would have already completed the wheat bill by now. We would now have been debating the superannuation package and been well on the way to debating native title.

I ask senators to respect the fact that we can only put a program forward and we can suggest how long each item should take. But ultimately, when the native title debate starts—or when the debate on any bill starts—is entirely in the hands of senators. If you want to talk ad nauseam on any bill, we could be here forever. The priority that senators give to each piece of legislation is not entirely up to the government to determine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your priority is No. 10—native title is No. 10 today.

—Where did it come in 1993, Senator Evans? It came about 150th in 1993, didn't it? You brought it on at 4.09 on the last day. If that is the priority you gave native title in 1993 and you want to compare our record, please feel free to do so. Senator Chris Evans, in supporting Senator Faulkner, has made a stupid and pathetic comment in regard to the way in which the importance of the native title legislation should be assessed. He says, `Oh, the importance of the legislation is where we put it in our program.' If that is the case, the Native Title Bill in 1993 was ranked about 149th because that is where you brought it on. You brought it on at 4.09 on the final sitting day. So you are not being consistent in using that argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—(1.05 p.m.)—The Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Ian Campbell), mistakenly, I think, asked me to incorporate some letters in the Senate Hansard , which I am only too pleased to do. There are three documents—a note to all parties from the manager dated 22 October 1997, a letter from the Manager of Government Business to the Manager of Opposition Business dated 29 October 1997, and a letter in response from the Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate to the Manager of Government Business dated 30 October. I particularly draw the Senate's attention to the last two paragraphs of that letter from Senator Carr, dated 30 October 1997, which state:

SPEECH.PARA: Since you cite the Mabo debate as a precedent for your request, I also take this opportunity to place on the record that the Opposition will not be adopting the tactics employed by the Coalition on that occasion.

We will not refuse to engage in dialogue on the amendments to your Native Title Bill. We will not leave it to the minor parties to carry the debate. We will not be prolonging the second reading debate and we will not be organising `relay teams' to filibuster in the committee stages. Finally, unlike the Coalition at that time, we will not be steadfastly opposing every Government proposal to facilitate the efficient handling of the bill.
I seek leave to have the three documents incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.

BREAK.PARA: MANAGER OF GOVERNMENT
BUSINESS IN THE SENATE
Parliament House
Canberra, ACT 2600
October 29th, 1997
Senator Kim Carr
Manager of Opposition Business
Dear Kim
The Government continues to seek agreement to adjourn the sittings of the Senate at the conclusion of consideration of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997, including any messages received.
You have indicated that the Labor Party is prepared to sit the extra week (commencing December 1st), but has not agreed to the adjournment resolution which aims to deal with the Bill this year.

I have consulted the relevant Minister and confirm that the Government has not received an undertaking from the ALP about the Senate concluding consideration of the Native Title Amendment Bill prior to the conclusion of these sittings. I request a re‐consideration of this position.

You may recall that at the end of the Autumn and Winter sittings (despite indications to the contrary) the Opposition denied the Government the opportunity to complete its program. On both occasions the Government had reduced the number of bills for consideration, but nevertheless key legislation was not dealt with. This is despite the fact that extensions of just a few hours could have accommodated their consideration.

In particular, I refer to the Senate's failure to deal with the Superannuation package and the message on the Hindmarsh Island Bridge Bill at the end of the Autumn sittings along with the subsequent failure to deal with the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill No. 3 1997 at the end of the Winter sittings. This was a contrary to requests that we adjourn at the conclusion of consideration of these bills and undertakings that the ALP will "look at how we are going closer to the time".

In previous years the former Government was not denied its program. In 1993 the Senate continued to sit until the Native Title Bill was passed, even though there were over 200 amendments and the Bill was not brought on for debate until the final scheduled sitting day.
Our proposal allows approximately 40 hours for debate of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997, with more hours available should parties decide they are necessary.
The Government believes this proposition is entirely reasonable and I therefore seek your agreement on the resolution.

On the issue of supplementation of travel and staff travel allowance budgets, the Government is prepared to provide confirmation to you, in writing, when we reach agreement on the sitting hours matter.
I look forward to your early response.
Yours sincerely
Senator the Honourable Ian G. Campbell
SENATOR KIM CARR
Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate
Senator the Honourable Ian Campbell
Manager of Government Business in the Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Campbell,
I write in response to your letter of 29 October about the legislation program for the Senate for the remainder of this sittings.

In relation to the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997, I reiterate that the Opposition is prepared to sit during the extra week from 1 December if this is necessary to conclude debate on this bill, subject to the Government agreeing to the necessary supplementation of travel and staff allowance.

As you are aware we have already given an undertaking in writing that we will cooperate in dealing with this Bill. I am therefore puzzled by your representation of the Opposition's position on this issue and can only assume that at the time of writing, your colleagues in the House of Representatives had not seen fit to inform you of that undertaking.

If you anticipate, presumably on the basis of your negotiations with the minor parties, that two weeks or more will be needed to deal with the Bill, you might consider bringing the Bill on before 24 November. It is now available for debate in the Senate and we see no reason why it should be delayed until the last week of the scheduled sittings.

With two and a half weeks of scheduled sittings remaining we certainly do not see the need to sit for more than one additional week. You should know that agreement to an open‐ended adjournment is an invitation to dilatoriness and filibuster. As I have already informed you, if debate is not concluded by 5 December, the Opposition remains open to discussions with the Government for additional time.

As to the argumentation in your letter, I cannot let it go uncontested. If you examine the record when Labor was in government you will find that we often ended a sitting period having to carry over essential legislation to the next sittings. In at least two cases, commitments given by the then Opposition as to the completion of the program were reneged on.

Your bald statement that "In previous years the former Government was not denied its program" is simply not true. This was one of the reasons our Government moved to a sittings pattern of three sittings a year, which has the effect of not subjecting such legislation to undue delay.

You imply (incorrectly) that a short extension of time at the conclusion of the Autumn sittings would have enabled the Senate to deal with the Superannuation package and the message on the Hindmarsh Island Bridge Bill.

It has been the custom at the end of a sittings for leave to be granted to postpone the adjournment if the bill which is then being debated can be concluded within a reasonable amount of time. This was patently not the case in relation to these two bills, as can be demonstrated by the fact that the Superannuation package alone took a further 14 hours to complete when sittings resumed.

Since you cite the mabo debate as a precedent for your request, I also take this opportunity to place on the record that the Opposition will not be adopting the tactics employed by the Coalition on that occasion.

We will not refuse to engage in dialogue on the amendments to your Native Title Bill. We will not leave it to the minor parties to carry the debate. We will not be prolonging the second reading debate and we will not be organisation `relay teams' to filibuster in the committee stages. Finally, unlike the Coalition at that time, we will not be steadfastly opposing every Government proposal to facilitate the efficient handling of the bill.
Yours sincerely,
Kim Carr

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I was at the leaders and whips meeting when the issue of the timing of the start of the debate on the second reading of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 was discussed. At the time I wanted to clarify with the Manager of Government Business and the Leader of the Government in the Senate what the program was that they wanted to get through. They said, `We want to get all of these bills through.' I made the suggestion at the leaders and whips meeting, which was agreed to, that we could start and endeavour to finish the debate on the second reading on Monday and Tuesday so that people knew when that would be taking place. Given that it was likely that there would still be committee stages of other bills left over, that gave us the leeway to deal with those after the debate on the second reading of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 . It is inevitable that there will be extra toing‐and‐froing on amendments or—and I absolutely guarantee this—in dealing with such a complex and difficult issue, there will be times in the debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill when we will need to break and there will need to be legislation to go on with.

SPEECH.PARA: I asked this in case we were to be required somehow to finish every other piece of legislation on the government's wish list before starting the native title debate—like kids: you have to eat your greens before you get your dessert. Not that I ever thought we should be forced in this way—as you know, I voted against dealing with this legislation because I do not believe that there has been proper consultation or that we should force it on in this way. Given that, I said it was reasonable for the people in the community to know when the second reading was going to be debated. That was actually agreed in the leaders and whips meeting. It was agreed that we could, if necessary, go back to the finishing‐off stages of other bills once we had finished the debate on the second reading of the Native Title Amendment Bill.

I do not know whether we have had any further meetings; I am sure that I have not been at any meetings since then where the government has got a new agreement from the people there. It was made quite clear that the parties' agreement in relation to the timing and the extra week was on the basis that that would be the start of that debate. I was here in 1993 when the filibustering went on and on. I cannot see anyone in this chamber who has any great desire to filibuster during the committee stage of the bill that we are meant to be dealing with.

I would also like to point out that the original agreement, as I understand it, on the Friday and Thursday swap was that it was the Friday that was being held back for estimates hearings. I was quite surprised, as you know, to find out that we had a Thursday estimates hearing instead of leaving that for Friday.

I actually asked the government, at that time, why they brought it on so quickly and why they were so eager to put that through on behalf of the opposition. They could have stood up against that. There were potentially the numbers in the Senate to deal with that and to say, `Okay, let's go back to the original agreement; let's use Friday for estimates; let's use Thursday for this.' It was not a matter of whether or not we sat during Senate estimates times; it was a matter of whether or not the Friday that was being left aside for Senate estimates was used for Senate estimates instead of swapping over to Thursday. But it was put through so quickly that we did not have a debate.

So there are a lot of very silly things going on at the moment. All I can say is that if, at the end of this fortnight, someone puts a motion that the Senate do now adjourn, I will probably put my hand up and say, `Okay, let's do what we should do and sensibly deal with this legislation.' If the government cannot do the right thing and keep to agreements that it has made at leaders and whips meetings, it is a wonder anybody bothers turning up. We should at least deal with the second reading.

It is a bit much for the government to suggest that we go on to second readings of other bills that they want on next year's agenda if we get to a gap in the program in dealing with the Native Title Amendment Bill, which we are certain to do. It is very rich indeed if they are suggesting that we should go on to next year's program rather than sensibly deal with any leftovers from this year's program during any gaps of proceedings in the Native Title Amendment Bill debate. This does not make any sense at all, and is going against any agreements that we have made.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 19 November.
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, page 46 (after line 5), after item 48, insert:
Add "and on the basis of merit".
(2) Schedule 1, item 53, page 47 (lines 3 to 5), omit subsection (3), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (3) Appointments to the Board under this section must be made in accordance with a code of practice determined under section 15B.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Schedule 1, item 53, page 47 (after line 5), at the end of the item, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 15B Procedures for appointment of ordinary members

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Minister must by writing determine a code of practice for appointments to the Board that:

TAB.TAB: (a) sets out general principles on which appointments of ordinary members to the Board are to be made, including, but not limited to:
(i) merit; and
(ii) independent scrutiny of appointments; and
(iii) probity; and
(iv) openness and transparency; and
(b) sets out how these principles are to be applied to the selection of members.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) After determining a code of practice under subsection (1), the Minister must publish the code.
(3) Not later than every third anniversary after a code of practice has been determined, the Minister must review the code.
(4) In reviewing a code of practice, the Minister must invite the public to comment on the code.
(5) A code of practice determined under subsection (1) is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 .

TAB.TAB: In appointing ordinary members, the Minister must ensure that the balance of interests on the Board is such that no one interest may dominate the Board or derogate from its independence.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments that I draw your attention to relate to the issue of ministerial patronage. We as a party are concerned—and I believe that we as a Senate should be most concerned—to ensure always that ministerial patronage has appropriate constraints. It is one of those areas which has increased in focus as the accountability drum has been beaten harder around the democracies of the civilised world. It was the Nolan committee in the United Kingdom which, after years of what can be regarded as an art form in the United Kingdom—that is, the ability, arising from government patronage, to put your mates into appropriate positions—finally felt that they had had enough and laid down some principles and procedures whereby ministerial patronage would be constrained.

The problem with having appointments based purely on ministerial discretion, which can of course be terminated when governments change, is that political patronage can move along eventually to the American model where administrations and people in the boards, authorities and committees which are so vital to our administration are changed over at will. That does not accord with our view as to independence and probity whereby boards and committees should be invested with appropriate persons. Ministerial patronage of that sort conflicts with the notion of having statutory authorities which are independent of and at arm's length from government.

What I have here in amendments builds on the recommendation of the Nolan committee in the United Kingdom, which was accepted by the Conservative government there, but it is a watered‐down version, because I am aware from previous debates that government is sensitive to protecting its ability to appoint to boards and authorities. In moving these three amendments, I should say that what we have focused on is the issue that appointment should be on the basis of merit. At page 45, item 53, clause 15A, appointment of ordinary members, the bill says:
(1) The Minister must not appoint a person as an ordinary member unless, in the opinion of the Minister, the person has expertise in one or more of the following fields:
(a) the production, marketing or processing of grain;
(b) the production or marketing of other products;
(c) business management;
(d) product promotion;
(e) finance.
It goes on:

BREAK.PARA: (2) In appointing persons as ordinary members, the Minister must endeavour to ensure, as far as practicable, that there is among the ordinary members a balance of skills in the areas of production, marketing and finance.
(3) Before appointing a person as an ordinary member, the Minister must consult the President of the Grains Council in relation to the appointment.

So we see a limited form of consultation and we see the spelling out of a functional approach to appointments but not a merit based approach. My amendments seek to do the following, and I will read them to you:
(1) The Minister must by writing determine a code of practice for appointments to the Board that:

PARA.TAB: (a) sets out general principles on which appointments of ordinary members to the Board are to be made, including, but not limited to:

TAB.TAB: (i) merit; and
(ii) independent scrutiny of appointments; and
(iii) probity; and
(iv) openness and transparency;

BREAK.PARA: Those I have taken directly from the UK Nolan committee's recommendation. The amendment continues:

PARA.TAB: (b) sets out how these principles are to be applied to the selection of members.

BREAK.PARA: So we still leave it within the minister's purview, but the minister must do it against a set of criteria which establish merit, independence, openness and transparency. Ministers will universally say to us, `Look, that is how we do things anyway.' That may be true of some ministers but it is not true of all ministers. Ministers vary in quality and ability, as we all do in this place, and it is appropriate for legislation to lay down the criteria and standards that are necessary. My amendment goes on to say:
(2) After determining a code of practice under subsection (1), the Minister must publish the code.
(3) Not later than every third anniversary after a code of practice has been determined, the Minister must review the code.
(4) In reviewing a code of practice—
Not in drawing it up but in reviewing a code—
the Minister must invite the public to comment on the code.
(5) A code of practice determined under subsection (1) is a disallowable instrument . . .
Particularly important is my amendment to 15C, independence of the board, which says:
In appointing ordinary members, the Minister must ensure that the balance of interests on the Board is such that no one interest may dominate the Board or derogate from its independence.

So the two hands on which this amendment rests are the hand of transparency, openness, independence and selection on merit; and, secondly, not only does it say independence but it says that the board should not be subject to capture by any one interest, either through appointment of political interests or commercial interests or of particular professional interests on a board.

Everyone in this place knows that within the farming community there has been in the past concern that particular boards and authorities have been captured by particular interests. It is my belief that the farming community as a whole would like to be assured that that is not possible. So I have retained or left the ability for the minister to exercise his or her jurisdiction but I have qualified it in terms of accountability measures which set out appointment on the basis of merit and independence.

Those, as a result, do nothing to take away from the intention of the bill and do nothing to take away from the determination that the bill makes in terms of the appointment of ordinary members in terms of their functional skills, but it does add considerably to the bill in terms of reassuring the community and the farming organisations and farmers affected that appointments will be made on a proper independent basis and one based on merit. I therefore commend my amendments to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TROETH
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Murray for his comments, but I would also like to make some comments on his amendments, which the government will not be supporting.

BREAK.PARA: The key consideration in appointments to the Australian Wheat Board is obviously the highest level of capability in specified areas of expertise. These are covered very well in clause 15A, which outlines the expertise that Senator Murray did summarise. Board members must be skilled in those areas, and this is provided for in the bill. I should point out that normal practice requires that those people who are to be appointed also provide the minister with written statements that their appointments would not cause any conflict of interest and that their tax affairs would not cause any embarrassment. This amendment would add very little to the present process and the intent of the proposed board selection is to simplify the process, not make it more complicated.

The Senate should also recognise that the appointments outlined in this would only be from November 1998 to the end of June 1999, when the statutory board expires along with the government's borrowing guarantee. Consequently, the full‐blown separate selection process is not warranted, and it would be extremely costly and time consuming. Indeed, after 1999, the board will no longer have responsibility for financial or marketing aspects anyway. This matter was not raised in the Senate report and therefore the government will not be supporting the Democrat amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would indicate, on behalf of the opposition, that we will not support the amendments moved by the Democrats. Firstly, I should say that we do not have any argument as such with the substance of what Senator Murray has put with respect to what should be the case when members of boards are appointed by ministers or by governments. We all agree that all appointments should be on the basis of merit and should be on the basis of endeavouring to ensure that various interests are represented. They should not be on the basis of pure political patronage or for favours owed or for some other criteria. Clearly, the person who is appointed should possess the skills warranted for the task at hand.

BREAK.PARA: However, the amendments put forward by the Democrats are essentially window‐dressing. The Democrat amendments still leave it clearly within the gift of the minister to make the appointments and to actually determine what the code of practice should be. Whilst it is proposed in the amendments to set out general principles, I would suggest that those general principles are ones which, given the need for flexibility in these circumstances, are nevertheless what are in place and should be followed.

If there are issues that arise in due course about the performance of board members of any government authority, statutory authority or whatever, then they are able to be taken up by members of parliament through the parliamentary process, the Senate estimates committees and so on. We fail to see how the Democrat amendments will do anything to enhance the objectives that Senator Murray has espoused. As I said, we do not argue that these are important considerations but we say that they are essentially already in place. These amendments do not take the matter any further one iota.
Senator Murray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray, your own amendment says that it is the minister who must, by writing, determine what the code of practice is.
—Because you rejected them the last time I did it. It was down to you.
—Senator Murray, despite all of your pious words and noble objectives, you are still saying very clearly that it is the minister who actually determines the code of practice.

BREAK.PARA: I also want to make a couple of other points, and Senator Troeth, the parliamentary secretary, has raised the obvious one; that is, what we are dealing with here in this legislation is the first part of a two‐part legislative change that will ultimately see the abolition of the Australian Wheat Board and the functions of the AWB taken over by listed companies on the Stock Exchange. I would have thought, Senator Murray, that if you had concerns about this issue you may have been prepared to support our amendment, which was moved in the second reading debate. That was to postpone further consideration of all of this legislation until we saw what was in the second tranche of legislation to come next year.

There are concerns about the future structure of the companies that will manage the marketing of wheat and there are concerns, as we and the farmers groups have pointed out, about taxation considerations. But Senator Troeth is right in making the point that, under the proposals as they are at the moment, the AWB will cease to exist in June 1999. So your amendment is related to a body which has a very short life span left and, in that sense, is rather insignificant in terms of what is really to follow—that is, the new structure under which wheat marketing will operate in this country. Of course, under the new structure, the companies that will be put into place will be listed on the Stock Exchange. Shares will be traded and directors of the companies will be elected by the shareholders or by the members affected. So, as Senator Troeth has said, this proposal, at the end of the day, is irrelevant for the purposes of the future structure that will exist in the wheat industry.

Those are all of the comments I have on this aspect. I do have some other questions that I wanted to ask the parliamentary secretary. If anyone wanted to comment on this they could or I could proceed to those questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the inference from Senator Forshaw was that I should wrap this up so that he can proceed to other matters. In response to the parliamentary secretary, these amendments would add very little cost to the process of appointments, but they would add a great deal of probity and merit to the method of appointment. With regard to the fact that the board expires in 1999, I think we should still endeavour to ensure that the very best board is available until that date. I am sure that the parliamentary secretary would agree with that. You would not want to have half-timers or part-timers, without their hearts in the job, governing the board until that time.

BREAK.PARA: I want to come back to Senator Forshaw's remarks. One of the advantages of being a Democrat senator is that there are so few of us that each has to do a great deal of work across a large number of portfolios. So I recall events in other portfolios which you might not have had access to, Senator Forshaw. One of those events was the debate on the CASA board. In that debate, I introduced much tougher amendments—and Labor, as expected, then knocked them over.

What I will be doing from now on, every time a board or authority comes up, is producing amendments of this sort, varied according to the circumstances. I am going to push the noses of both major parties up against the windowpane of accountability. Frankly, the executive on the right side of the chair and the executive in waiting on the left side of the chair enjoy the business of political patronage, enjoy giving jobs to mates. They will resist anything which seeks to constrain that, and they will find all sorts of reasons. Over time, I am going accumulate your reasons. You will give such reasons as `oh, badly drafted' or `oh, not relevant' or `oh, but you've still given it to the minister.' I will accumulate all your excuses.

At the end, all it will come to is a fat zero on accountability, because the Labor Party is incapable of overturning a system which benefits it when it is in government. And the government certainly will not want to overturn a system which, after 13 years, will allow it to try a little bit of patronage of its own. That is an area which, as I say, is being addressed in other civilised democracies worldwide. In this particular case, the Democrats will lead the agenda again, and again, and again, until eventually we get the government to submit in this area.

So do not think that this area of independence, of probity, of appointment on merit, of the destruction of the culture of mateship, is going to end with this bill. We will come at you again and again. I commend my amendments to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray would have it that he has the monopoly on being concerned about accountability. I have been around long enough, Senator Murray, to know a straw man argument when I see one—and, of course, this is a straw man argument. What we have here is the Democrats putting up an amendment, saying that they are concerned about accountability in terms of independence with appointments to boards of statutory authorities or government enterprises. And, if you do not happen to agree with the form of their amendment, somehow you do not support the principles. That is precisely the sort of straw man argument that Senator Murray is putting up.
—Amend the amendments.

—Senator Murray, you can make all the promises you like about bringing this matter back time and time again. Senator Murray, the real question that is at stake in this legislation, you have not made one contribution to. The Democrats squibbed it and wimped it at the 11th hour last week.

SPEECH.PARA: I invite you to read the speech made by Senator Woodley in the second reading debate. Senator Woodley, on behalf of the Democrats, stood up in this chamber and said that he had great concerns about the issue of the future taxation arrangements with respect to wheat growers and their equity in the wheat industry fund. He said that he had great concerns about the fact that the government was seeking to put through only the first stage of legislation, and nobody had yet had a chance to see the second part of the legislation. He referred to the fact that that is what the growers and the industry in Western Australia and New South Wales were saying. They were pleading with the Democrats, as they were with other members of the parliament here, to delay this legislation because of their serious concerns.

This is in Western Australia—your home state, Senator Murray. The people vitally affected by this legislation, Senator Murray, were asking you to stand up for their rights and their interests. Senator Murray, you ignored them; you squibbed it. Between those two states, those people represent somewhere around about 75 per cent of wheat marketing and exporting in this country. But, in the end, the Democrats voted with the government, and I invite you to read Senator Woodley's comments. He said that he voted with the government at the end of the day because he had listened to the Queensland wheat growers.

With all due respect, Senator Murray, where were you when the Western Australian wheat growers were asking you to support our amendment to delay this legislation until next year when we will see the full text of the bills, the second part of the legislation, and until their interests, their particular, legitimate concerns—and they are legitimate because it is their money in the wheat industry fund—about taxation have been dealt with? You did not address the main part, the essential part, of this legislation. Then you come in here with this holier than thou attitude about accountability for board members.
Let me now turn to the questions I want to address to the parliamentary secretary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. Could we please finish with my amendment and then move on to other matters? I have some remarks to add to that amendment, if you so rule.
—That is not exactly a point of order, but it may be advice on how we would proceed. Do you have any problem with being interrupted, Senator Forshaw?
—No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Just for the record please, Mr Chairman: the wheat farmers and their representative associations in Western Australia did not contact me subsequent to the second reading debate, in which I spoke, to ask me to support Labor's amendment. So I am sure that Senator Forshaw's implication was made in ignorance. But they did not ask me to support that.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments not agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some questions for the parliamentary secretary. As the government is aware, the growers organisations—the Western Australian Farmers Federation for one and the New South Wales Farmers Association for another—have repeatedly sought clarification from the government and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) as to the future taxation arrange ments with respect to the legislative changes that will result in the funds of the wheat industry fund being used as capital for the companies. Can you advise the Senate of the latest position? Have those issues been resolved? If not, when will they be resolved, given that this is a major issue of concern for the growers?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TROETH
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Forshaw, as you would be aware, taxation matters do not form part of this bill. The matter of taxation is under consideration by the minister at present.

—Mr Chairman, I had understood that the parliamentary secretary had effectively foregone a second reading speech on the basis of making some comments in the committee stage of this bill. I take it that that is now not the intention. I would ask the parliamentary secretary to respond to that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TROETH
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The matters on which I intended to comment were the subject of the amendments that were moved by both the Labor Party and the Democrats of which I had knowledge at the time, and taxation is not one of those. The matter of taxation is something that will be dealt with in the second stage of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter of critical concern. When this matter was being debated, people had been given to understood that the matter was going to be considered by cabinet either last week or this week. To interpret what the parliamentary secretary is saying, it now appears that this matter is not going to be considered by cabinet. It has not been considered—that is, it was not last week—and it appears that we will have no further elaboration on the question of taxation until some time next year.

SPEECH.PARA: That will not be until March of next year, given that the second tranche of legislation affecting this area, as I understand it, has not gone before the House of Representatives. As we sit for only two weeks in March, it would be unlikely to reach this place in March. We could be waiting many, many months to have the second tranche of legislation before parliament. If I understand what the parliamentary secretary is saying, there will be no further comment on the taxation of the wheat industry fund moneys—as they are converted into B class shares—until the second tranche of legislation is here.

A lot of things have been said to industry representatives about the tax issue. Whilst recognising that the tax issue is not critical to this bill, it was critical to the issues raised in our second reading amendment. It was critical in the sense that it was made clear by the Grains Council to me and to other opposition senators that, without adequate resolution of the tax issue, support for both tranches of legislation was not there.

I think the Senate and the industry representatives who have been involved in the debate on this issue deserve some answer on this matter. It is a very important issue. In the absence of further clarification, what has to be assumed is that we will not know anything further about this matter until whenever it is that the second tranche of legislation is brought before the House of Representatives. As we said earlier, one fears that we will have proceeded so far in this matter that it will be like unscrambling an egg to try to get out of the position that passing this legislation will create.

I want to say to Senator Murray that I was advised by the Western Australian Farmers Federation that they had sent a facsimile communication on their position to all Democrat, opposition and Independent senators. I take it from your comments that you did not receive that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not after my speech on the second reading, but prior to that, yes.
—I think we are shaving straws.
—No, we're not because that's two weeks ago.

—I think the Senate deserves some further clarity on this matter—even if it is only to say that there will be no further comment on the matter until the second tranche of legislation arrives before the parliament. But I do not think the industry will be satisfied with it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TROETH
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that, after the minister has consulted with Treasury, there will be a working party meeting in Melbourne on this coming Thursday to consider the taxation issues and there will be a discussion of these taxation issues in the context of the next tranche of legislation which, as you know, is to come on next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague Senator O'Brien has said, whilst tax is not specifically dealt with in this bill, it is essential that this issue be resolved. That is what the growers have said.

SPEECH.PARA: What is happening is that the growers' funds that are currently in the wheat industry fund will now become the capital base for the new companies. People are entitled to know, in advance of that process commencing, what the taxation arrangements will be down the track when those funds are converted to shares in the company. Growers have a right, as we know, to seek to withdraw some or all of their funds from the wheat industry fund at any time.

Senator Troeth, you have indicated that there will be a meeting. I have to say that it just reinforces the argument we put in the second reading debate that these issues have still not been resolved. People were led to believe that they were on the verge of being resolved. Senator Murray made the technical point that apparently he received communication prior to or at the time of the second reading debate and has not received any since. The issues that were drawn to his attention at that time, and to the attention of all senators, included having the tax liabilities issue clarified. It still has not been clarified. So, Senator Murray, nothing has changed in respect of the position and the reasons why the grower organisations that wrote to you and to us were seeking that deferral.

BREAK.PARA: I certainly have not been advised by either the Western Australian Farmers Federation or the New South Wales Farmers Association, who represent the bulk of the interests here, that they have changed their position. The only group that I can see which has changed its position on this legislation to any extent is the Australian Democrats.

Senator Troeth, you have partly answered the second question I asked, but it would assist if you would be more specific as to when the second tranche of the legislation will be brought into the parliament. I understood from the Senate committee hearing that it was to be in the first half of next year. Certainly we would like to know, and I am sure that growers and others affected by this legislation would like to know, precisely when that will be.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TROETH
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously it is the government's desire to have the second tranche of legislation to the parliament as soon as possible. The second tranche of legislation will concern the conversion of shares and the property question. It will be as soon as the taxation issues have been worked through with industry. That is why the working party will be meeting this Thursday and, I presume, will continue to meet until those issues have been resolved. When those taxation issues have been resolved, the second tranche of legislation will be brought to the parliament. It is the government's desire to have this legislation to the parliament as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I should respond to some of the attempts to embroil me in Labor Party politics.
—Farmer politics, you mean.

—Yes, Labor Party farmer politics; sorry, I should have qualified it. The Western Australian Farmers Federation has been prominent in this issue. Some 75 per cent of wheat is produced between Western Australia and New South Wales, so that is the obvious focus of this issue. The Western Australian Farmers Federation wrote to me, as it did to everybody else. It works very closely with the Liberal and National parties, which support this bill and this process. Those two parties have had very close consultation with their colleagues in the Western Australian Farmers Federation.

SPEECH.PARA: I apprised the Australian Democrats spokesperson for this matter, Senator Woodley, of the letter. He has been dealing with those issues, and as a result of those consultations—regrettably he is not here to answer for himself—he came to the view, like the Liberal and National parties, that it was appropriate for this bill to proceed.

My speech in the second reading debate indicated the questions that were being asked by the Western Australian Farmers Federation—it was over two weeks ago—and I indicated that the Democrats would consider their position subject to further consultations. My advice is that Senator Woodley did have those consultations, and the consequence is that we will proceed. My role in this bill has been to do with accountability; Senator Woodley is the rural affairs spokesperson. So I would appreciate it if you left that alone and continued with your own questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the opposition will be voting against the third reading, but we will not be seeking to divide.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 November, on motion by Senator Tambling:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —In the final minutes before the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) concludes the debate, it is appropriate to stress a number of things here and that is that the government is concerned to maintain a sensible and consistent taxation approach to superannuation. It has been one of the concerns that the government has had and the government has been working very hard to try and get a result which is consistent and fair and which does not put anybody in a particularly advantageous position by virtue of their being on the public payroll, nor does it seek to create a situation were people are unduly disadvantaged simply by virtue of the fact that they happen to be in a constitutionally protected scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: What the government is saying is that there basically has to be consistency across the whole of the community, so that rules that apply to those who are outside constitutionally protected schemes also apply to people who are on constitutionally protected schemes. This is part of a wider philosophy of this government which is that we believe in the basic principle of tax fairness. It would have been absurd to have a situation where we said, `Look, we are going to allow high income earners to get particular advantages that wage and salary earners cannot get.' It would have been hypocritical of us to say within a category of high income earners generally that certain people should be advantaged and certain people should be disadvantaged.

That is the philosophy with which this government approaches the problem and the philosophy that needs to be borne in mind at all times when we consider this debate. I see that the very able minister has entered the chamber and I am sure that he is in a much better position to close the debate on this matter than I am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of legislation complements the surcharge package passed by the parliament earlier this year. The package includes legislation which will strengthen the equity of the surcharge measure by ensuring that the superannuation contribution surcharge for high income earners will apply to members of constitutionally protected superannuation funds.

SPEECH.PARA: This was not an oversight in the original surcharge package, as suggested by Senator Cook. The government was honouring its undertaking to discuss the application of the surcharge to state schemes with the states to achieve a workable outcome for their schemes.

For constitutional reasons the Commonwealth is unable to impose the surcharge on certain state superannuation schemes. Accordingly, the legislation will impose liability for the surcharge directly on members of these constitutionally protected schemes. Otherwise the collection mechanism under this legislation is similar to that which applies to members of unfunded defined benefit superannuation funds under the previously passed legislation.

The package also includes legislation which amends a number of acts to give effect to: the application of a surcharge to members of Commonwealth superannuation schemes; consequential amendments arising from the legislation dealing with members of certain state superannuation schemes; technical amendments to clarify the operation of the surcharge and improve the administration of surcharge; and amendments to correct techni cal deficiencies in amendments made to the original surcharge legislation during its passage through the parliament.

I note that during the debate several speakers referred to evidence given to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, alleging that many low and middle income earners would be caught by the surcharge. I made it very clear in my statements that no low or middle income earner need pay the surcharge. All they have to do is supply their tax file numbers and, if I have said that once, I have said it many times. I am pleased to say that no‐one has ever challenged that as a correct statement of fact. No acknowledgment was given by Mr Downed in his evidence to the committee or by speakers during the debate—including somewhat surprisingly Senator Allison—to amendments moved by the Democrats to the main surcharge legislation, which in effect quarantined existing accounts from receiving modest levels of contributions.

It was stated before the committee that a particular firm had only managed a 23 per cent response rate in the collection of tax file numbers. I note that this is not indicative of the collection of tax file numbers for the industry as a whole. I have been advised that many funds have achieved far better collection rates and that a response rate from a first round mail‐out of around 65 per cent is being used as a benchmark.

Senator Cook also referred to problems funds may have in meeting the 15 December reporting deadline. The key point here is that the government has already extended the reporting date from 31 August to 15 December. Senator Cook is also well aware that this package includes provision for superannuation funds to apply to the Commissioner of Taxation for deferral of reporting. If this is a legitimate concern of the opposition, then they can assist those funds which might have difficulty in meeting the deadline by passing this legislation. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to Australia's participation in the IMF‐sponsored assistance packages to Indonesia and Thailand. What was the total amount in Australian dollars of our assistance? Of this amount, how much has been drawn down so far?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Cook mentioned, the proposed assistance packages by the IMF are to Indonesia and Thailand. In relation to Indonesia, the government welcomes the IMF program for Indonesia which was announced on 31 October. The program is a demanding one, involving monetary and fiscal adjustment, restructuring of the financial sector, significant deregulatory measures and trade reform, which will improve the efficiency, transparency and governance of the economy. Australia has agreed to provide up to $US1 billion to Indonesia in the form of supplementary financing which would remain conditional on adherence to the IMF program. Australia's assistance would be drawn down only after recourse to IMF financing and would take the form of a loan which would be repaid once the program ended.

ANSWER.PARA: China, Hong Kong, Japan, Malaysia, Singapore and the US, as well as some other countries, have also pledged support. The government is still considering the method of providing its financial assistance to this package. In relation to Thailand, we believe that the IMF will play a fundamental role in stabilising the Thai economy. However, we have stressed—and I think the Treasurer said it before—that it is necessary for the Thai authorities to be totally committed to the reform process.

Australia's contribution to Thailand is firmly linked to the IMF program. Disbursements under the Reserve Bank are conditional upon the Thai authorities meeting the IMF's conditions. In relation to the second leg of Senator Cook's question, under the swap agreement the RBA will pay the Bank of Thailand an agreed amount of US dollars to receive the equivalent amount in Thai baht. At the conclusion of the swap, the Bank of Thailand will repay the same amount of US dollars, that is, the amount not affected by the exchange rate movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. My question was: how much of the Australian guarantee has been drawn down? Senator Kemp, did I understand you to say in that answer that the Australian contribution has not been drawn on yet?
—In relation to the Indonesian matter, my understanding is that it has not been drawn down yet—
—You don't know, do you?

—Senator Conroy is a bit frisky today, particularly after last week. As far as I am aware, the same applies to the Thai arrangement, but I will check. If I have to change that, I will get back to you.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. It relates to the greenhouse gas challenge. Can the minister outline to the Senate the government's strategy for dealing with greenhouse gases and the intentions of the government in dealing with this very important and pressing problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the question. Australia is playing a constructive role in the international greenhouse negotiations taking place at present. As I have said before, our objective is to contribute to a better global outcome in relation to greenhouse gases and to carry our fair share of the burden, but not to assume a responsibility beyond that fair share of the burden. I should remind you, because it is sometimes not well appreciated, that we contribute only about 1.3 per cent or 1.4 per cent of total global greenhouse gases. That does not mean that we should not be taking prudent action to restrain emissions growth; we believe that we should.

ANSWER.PARA: That position was reinforced last week by the statement of the Prime Minister, who announced a $180 million package of domestic measures to strengthen our domestic response in this very important matter. Of interest, this response goes beyond Labor's no regrets policy, which we have built on in our first 18 months of government, and for the first time will include some action that will be at economic cost. On balance, we nevertheless believe that it is worth doing that. One of the most pleasing aspects of the package, which is also not well appreciated, is that it will now reduce our emissions per capita to four per cent below 1990 levels. If we had maintained our 1990 population we would now, after the implementation of this package, be four per cent below 1990 levels, a very substantial improvement on the graph of business as usual.

It demonstrates how much Australia is doing. The no regrets policy and the voluntary business cooperation policies have reduced our business as usual graph significantly. The announcement the other day will further substantially reduce it by about another one‐third.
