In particular, the package announced the other day which covers most of the sectors includes $60 million for the commercialisation of renewable energy technologies—great opportunities in that area—$27 million for the expansion of the successful greenhouse challenge office that I mentioned a moment ago, which is the voluntary business program, in which I believe we lead the world; $13 million for the cities for climate protection programs, to enlist the support of local government and local communities; increased vegetation through the bush for greenhouse programs; getting our corporate sector to back tree planting and revegetation initiatives through the Natural Heritage Trust; a range of measures in relation to the motor vehicle industry; energy market reform and energy performance standards for houses and commercial buildings. In some of these areas, when we are not able to achieve our desired outcome through voluntary means, we would be prepared to go to regulatory means for the first time.

What is Labor's response to this? Labor says that they could do better and they could reduce greenhouse gases to 1990 stabilisation rates. The only way Labor could do that is with a substantial carbon tax. They would build upon our initiatives by adding a substantial carbon tax to the detriment of all Australians, both directly and indirectly—a tax which has been estimated by the Electricity Supply Association of Australia at some $2 billion.

Why doesn't Labor come clean, applaud what we have done and acknowledge that if they were to go further and achieve what they believe is possible, it would require a very substantial carbon tax which would have a significantly detrimental effect upon all Australians. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Given that the government has avoided the necessity for a $2 billion carbon tax and is putting up $180 million in its greenhouse package, can the minister advise what responses have come from key industry groups who will have to support this package? What do they have to say about what we are doing as opposed to the proposal for a $2 billion carbon tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Industry responded very positively. It is good to see because, as I said, this does require more of industry, particularly in relation to power generation, in the transport sector in relation to vehicle emission standards and in the building sector in relation to commercial and domestic building standards. I will refer to just a few of them.

ANSWER.PARA: I mentioned building. The Master Builders Association endorses the Prime Minister's energy statement. The Australian Chamber of Commerce put out a statement endorsing the government's position to be pursued in the Kyoto climate change negotiations. The Fuel Ethanol Association of Australia put out a statement which said that the Prime Minister is to be congratulated for his leadership. APEA put out a statement saying that the oil and gas industry supports the government's greenhouse initiative program. ESAA also applauded the government's `genuine attempt to balance maintaining Australia's economic growth while building its credibility as good environmental managers'. So many others responded. It is good to see Australian business responding so positively. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer and minister responsible for taxation. Minister, I refer you to the new measure announced in the Treasurer's press release earlier this month entitled `Capital gains tax cost base provisions: transitional measure'. As you are aware, this new measure was announced following the new cost base rules that were provided for in the last budget and had particular application to people such as primary producers. Can you explain what expenditures gave rise to double deductions and how will they now be treated in the transitional measure that was announced by the Treasurer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Collins for his question. The amendments to the cost base rules are, as you indicated, designed to prevent taxpayers from taking into account the same item of expenditure on property twice—I think this goes to the nub of your question—once when claiming a deduction for income tax purposes and again when determining the cost base or index cost base of the asset for capital gains purposes. These amendments were announced in the 1997-98 budget and will apply to assets acquired after 13 May 1997.

ANSWER.PARA: The rules will achieve this by reducing the cost base or index cost base and asset to the extent of any net deductions, such as depreciation, already allowed to the taxpayer. However, the government has recognised that the amendments may unintentionally catch taxpayers who have purchased land or buildings before the budget announcement and who have, for example, incurred expenditure by constructing new buildings on the land after 13 May 1997. This is because the capital gains tax rules may deem the new construction to be a new and separate asset from land acquired before the budget.

The government has introduced transitional rules to ensure that the new provisions exclude expenditures on pre-budget land or buildings which create separate assets. The transitional measures will apply to expenditure incurred after 13 May 1997 but before 1 July 1999. This will minimise the impact of the new cost base rules on projects genuinely in train at the time of the budget and will provide a more certain environment for those affected by the budget measures. I think that deals with the issue that Senator Cook raised, and I welcome his interest in this.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was Senator Collins—that's what happens when you just read a brief!

—Senator Conroy, I do not want to have to refer to you today. I would really prefer not to refer to you today because of the pounding that you have received in the press over the last week. But if you persist in calling out and interjecting, I may be forced to refer to some of that press.

—I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, thank you for that information. Perhaps I could re‐ask the unanswered part of the question in a different way. Having said that, will the transitional measures apply different rules to both revenue expenditures and capital expenditures or will they be applied in exactly the same way?

—I think I have fully answered that question. You should have listened more carefully to the response which was given to you. If you want me to go through the answer again, I would be delighted to go through it, but I think it will require a bit more than a minute.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts and it relates to the government's $250 million regional telecommunications infrastructure fund—the first round of funding which was announced today—and which is the result of partial privatisation of Telstra. Minister, will you explain to the Senate the benefits which rural and regional Australia will receive following today's announcement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to inform the Senate and indeed the Australian public that we are now in the process of making up for 13 years of neglect on the part of the Labor Party. They simply could not give a damn about the bush. They paid the penalty at the last election. Despite all of that, when they had the opportunity to support this $250 million program, they fought it tooth and nail through this chamber. So in no shape or form can they claim any ownership of or identity with this fund. This is a fund that the government has put forward specifically to benefit people in rural and remote areas, who have been second-class telecommunications citizens for too long.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of today's announcement, $15 million has been allocated for 40 projects. We got over 80 applications. I think that is a tremendous result. They cover a wide range of areas. There is $5.6 million for the National Farmers Federation for their farmwide project. That will provide 15 Internet points of presence in strategic areas around the rural community. In addition, there are telecentres in Western Australia, for example. The number of telecentres is now being expanded from 38 to 100. In every other state there are initiatives which will benefit the rural community. There are satellite telephones. Internet access at local call prices is a critical ingredient in enabling farmers, the rural community and regional towns to access a wide range of information and indeed entertainment services. They were not possible under the previous regime. They are eminently possible now.

We also persuaded Telstra to have 93.4 per cent of the Australian population ISDN‐capable by 1 July last, and we are now on track for the DRCS project to extend that number even further. So the bush is now getting a red-hot deal from this government which it was simply denied for all those 13 long years of Labor.
If I could just quote what the National Farmers Federation farmwide project had to say today:
. . . the project will provide extensive training and support, assist in local content development and provide for the trialing of a range of new communications technologies . . .
The lack of local call access to online services and the relatively high costs for Australians outside of our cities has hindered the uptake of online services.
As a result of the establishment of the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund,
people in regional, rural and remote areas will be able to capitalise on the benefits of online services and leading edge communications technologies.
Better quality access to the broad range of online services will enhance individuals' ability to utilise education, social, recreation and business services.
Today's announcement is the commencement of a new era in rural telecommunications for regional, rural and remote communities.

I could not have said it better myself. There it is: the score is on the board. For the first time people in the bush are going to be up to date in terms of access to world‐class technologies. You were not interested. People in the bush know that. They are very disappointed indeed, when they read that document that supposedly passes for a platform, to find the usual vacuous inanities like `Labor supports equitable access', `as soon as practicable we will have the equivalent of digital capability' and `all schools will be on‐line'. This of course ignores the fact that most state governments have been going down that track for six to 12 months or more. Labor somehow thinks that it is not happening but Labor in federal government will be able to deliver the goods.

The fact is that Labor has no idea. It is happening out there. It is happening because of initiatives like this fund. We will continue to deliver the goods to rural Australia. It will enable Telstra to upgrade the quality of their service, and with the introduction of new competitive services we will get an even better outcome for people in country areas. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you, Minister, for that comprehensive response, but could you also inform the Senate of the benefits for residents of my home state of Tasmania as a result of this fund?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —There are quite a number, too. Indeed, only a month or two back the very first announcement by the board—an independent board chaired by Doug Anthony—was a $4.5 million project over three years for an electronic commerce centre in Tasmania. In addition, as a result of today's announcements there will be Service Tasmania—Over the Counter Initiative; community access centres; an Electronic Commerce Initiative for the Tasmanian tourism industry; the King Island telecommunications infrastructure project; Furneaux Enterprise telecommunications; and the provision of a digital mobile network on the Lyell Highway.

ANSWER.PARA: All of these projects will be of vital importance to people outside the capital cities and particularly in Tasmania, where the highest proportion of the population live outside its capital city. An electronic commerce initiative for the Tasmanian tourism industry receiving funding in excess of $400,000 is a classic example of addressing the needs, capitalising on the local comparative advantage and using world-class—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, I refer to the recently announced Commonwealth Bank deal with the Australian Taxation Office regarding the CBA's $650 million share buyback. Are you aware that 70 per cent of CBA shareholders bought their shares for a minimum $10 per share and that, if all of them took part in the buyback, a minimum $300 million in artificial capital losses will be generated? What is the benefit of the creation of these artificial losses for Australian taxpayers? Will the proposed dividend distribution component of the buyback qualify for the savings rebate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Conroy raises the issue of the CBA buyback, which was extensively canvassed at the Senate estimates. Senator Conroy, after your performance at the Senate estimates and the difficulties you had with quite a range of figures, if you remember correctly, I would not accept your figures. I would naturally, as you would expect me to do—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —One thing is that you would not know, Senator Conroy. I do not have that figure on hand but the tax office, as you are aware as it was carefully explained to you, had very close contact with the CBA. There were discussions with the CBA to ensure that any arrangements were in conformity with taxation law. That is the reason it happened. Of course, the Commonwealth Bank was one of those institutions that Labor privatised, if I remember correctly, Senator Conroy. Your party decided—
—Answer the question!
—I have answered the question. Senator Conroy put up a figure of what he estimated the capital losses to be.
—What are you talking about?

—You were not listening. I said that I do not propose to accept the figure by Senator Conroy until I can have that checked. There were discussions with the Australian Taxation Office. It is the government's concern and the Australian Taxation Office's concern that the tax law of this country be enforced.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can you explain how the creation of these artificial losses for taxpayers is consistent with the Treasurer's statement on 20 June last year when he said, `I make it clear on behalf of this government that where anomalies and exemptions are being unfairly exploited they will be addressed'?

—Senator Conroy, you have no particular evidence at all to sustain the assumption in your question. What I have said to you is that the Australian Taxation Office has had discussions with the CBA. You can go around making a whole host of quite wild statements, Senator Conroy. Noting how keen the Labor Party was to help us close down problems with the tax law, Senator Conroy, just think of your attitude to R&D syndicates and apologise.

—My question is directed to the Special Minister of State. I refer the minister to questions on notice asked by the Democrats on 6 May and of the Queensland government on 30 September concerning pastoral leases. Minister, the answers from the Queensland government revealed that no pastoral leases have been issued in that state since 1975 and that under the Native Title Act 1993 all pastoral leases are valid in Queensland. Is it true that the proposed validation of intermediate period acts will, in Queensland, affect 3,800 mining tenements which purport to override the Native Title Act but not one pastoral lease? Minister, can you confirm that companies like BHP, Rio Tinto and Western Mining will be the chief beneficiaries of validation of intermediate period acts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —The validation regime in the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 is one of the most important parts of the bill. It follows quite closely the validation regime provided in the current Native Title Act, although it is much more restricted in that it does not generally validate legislation, it only validates acts that took place on pastoral leases. It does so because it was the clear basis of the law, following the passage of the Native Title Act, that the Native Title Act did not apply on pastoral leases. That is evident from the debate that occurred at the time, from the statements made by the Keating government and from the assurances given by the Keating government. That was clearly evident in the provisions of the Native Title Act and clearly evident from the decisions of the Native Title Tribunal and the Federal Court.

ANSWER.PARA: What happened was that the Wik decision changed the basis of our understanding of a pastoral lease. Sir Gerard Brennan, the Chief Justice of the High Court, made it clear in the Mabo decision in the lead judgment that leasehold land extinguished native title. It was therefore proper for all governments, including the Keating Labor government and the Goss Labor government, to operate on the clear presumption that the Native Title Act did not apply on pastoral leases.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were wrong.

—Sure. We now know, as a result of the Wik decision, that that presumption was incorrect. Nevertheless, governments acting in good faith issued mining leases to a whole range of interests over pastoral leases in 1994, 1995 and 1996. We now know that that was done contrary to the Native Title Act. But, as was the case with the Native Title Act in 1993, it is absolutely essential to the economic security of this nation, to investor confidence and to sovereign risk that we take action to validate those titles. We have done so in exactly the same way as the current Native Title Act does so. We have used the same category A, B, C, D regime of validation. We have provided just terms compensation wherever there is impairment or extinguishment of native title as a result of the validation of those particular titles.

ANSWER.PARA: Any suggestion that we should not validate those titles issued in good faith and involving millions of dollars of investments exercised in good faith would be, in our view, economic vandalism of the worst kind. If companies could not proceed on the basis of validly issued titles in that three-year period, and now have the situation where every one of them could be subject to challenge as being legally invalid because the provisions of the Native Title Act were not followed, it would be utterly reprehensible and simply unacceptable to any Australian government or parliament to operate on that basis. That is why I expect the ALP will be generally supporting the validation regime, because it is remarkably consistent with and similar to the validation regime provided for in the current Native Title Act.

I do think it is very important for the minor parties to understand the very serious economic consequences of any suggestion that this parliament not validate those titles issued where they may affect native title and to remember that full just terms compensation is payable for any effect on native title. No mining leases issued in that period will extinguish native title. They impair native title for the period of the issue of the lease, as is the case with the current Native Title Act. So I do call on the Democrats and the Greens to think very seriously about any suggestion of not supporting that validation regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for a comprehensive answer. I think he actually did in a roundabout way answer the question I asked. But, Minister, you leave me with a problem: I do not think you really can put a price on justice. Minister, has your government deliberately misled voters by pretending that native title on pastoral leases must be wiped out to satisfy struggling farmers when the main beneficiaries will really be multinational mining companies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Woodley seems most confused about this debate and I fear what may happen over the next two weeks. You seem to have forgotten that we decided back in May of this year that we would not be extinguishing native title on pastoral leases. We are respecting and reflecting the Wik decision in our legislation. The reason it is so complex and so detailed is because we are providing in the Native Title Act for the coexistence of native title on pastoral leases and for the coexistence of statutory rights exercisable by the pastoralists with native title rights exercisable by any native title holders. You seem not to have been around since May when we made that decision, despite the demands by some to restore the law to the position promised then by Paul Keating, and that was that native title is extinguished by pastoral leases. We are not doing that. We are preserving native title on pastoral leases.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. Minister, are you aware of widespread reports of dodgy double dipping in the Telstra share float? Is it a fact that some Telstra investors fraudulently used the names of family pets or other bogus names to obtain shares during the recent float? How many bogus applications were refused? What action is being taken to ascertain the extent of successful bogus applications?

—Thank you, Senator Schacht. I have got an answer but can I just intrude a comment that Senator Richard Alston must be green with envy. I am the one who can get questions from you, Senator Schacht, but, as the shadow minister for communications, you have not put one question—correct me if I am wrong—to Senator Alston.
—You're responsible for the float, you dope!
—Senator Schacht, you are the only player who demands that coach Robert Ray keeps you in the pavilion. You are the only one I know who does that.

BREAK.PARA: In relation to your question, I am aware of the issue you have raised and I have got a response from the minister for finance for you. People who use false names to obtain more Telstra shares are, I understand, not committing an offence under the corporations law. The Commonwealth reserves the right to amalgamate or reject multiple applications and, obviously, bogus applications were rejected. Investors will shortly be asked to provide Telstra with their tax file numbers. Investors who do not provide a legitimate tax file number will have dividends taxed at the maximum rate of 47 per cent.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister for finance therefore reject the opinion of the Law Institute of Victoria, which said in the weekend press:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . creating false names to obtain more shares was an offence under the Crimes Act 1958.
The institute's president, Geoff Provis, said:
obtaining a financial advantage by deception carried a jail sentence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you are quite right that the Law Institute of Victoria was reported in the Sunday Herald‐Sun on 23 November 1997 as saying that:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . creating false names to obtain more shares was an offence under the Crimes Act 1958.

I think he would be referring to a Victorian statute. I understand, from the advice that is available to me from the Treasury, that it is not an offence under the Corporations Act to apply for shares using a false name.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I asked the minister on 30 October about the Prime Minister's request to the Remuneration Tribunal about a new method of paying MPs' travel allowances. It now transpires that the Prime Minister had a reply on the day before I asked that question. I ask the minister: what are the contents of the tribunal's reply to the Prime Minister? Why has it taken so long to make that information public, particularly in view of the fact that in the meantime the government has been able to determine a new benefit for MPs in the form of disbursement to the electorate of free fridge magnets?

—I regret that I know nothing about the fridge magnets. I will inquire further as to the substantial part of Senator Brown's questions. As I said on the last occasion, I knew that the matter had been referred by the Prime Minister to the Remuneration Tribunal. I knew that it had delayed—because I read it in the report of the Remuneration Tribunal—some of its considerations whilst it dealt with that matter. But I will get an up‐to‐date report and let Senator Brown and the Senate know as soon as possible.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer to statutory rule 1997 No. 318 currently before the Senate, which, amongst other entitlements to MPs, refers to other printed material such as magnetised calendars. In view of the fact that the minister does not know anything about this regulation which the Senate has currently before it, will he find out and inform the Senate the nature of this new entitlement of fridge magnets to MPs.
—If Senator Brown thinks it is sufficiently important.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Minister, do you endorse the views of Mr Costello's parliamentary secretary, Senator Ian Campbell, who told the Western Australian branch of the Property Council of Australia that the recession in Canberra was `fantastic'? Does the minister agree with Mr Costello's parliamentary secretary, Senator Ian Campbell, who told the council:

QUESTION.PARA: I heard Maximilian Walsh on the Lateline program say that we, as a Coalition Government, have caused a recession in Canberra for the first time since 1925. I think that is a fantastic achievement.
Minister, why is the Canberra recession `fantastic'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner referred to a reported statement by Senator Ian Campbell which was published in the press this morning. Senator, I have made inquiries about this matter and I am able to inform the Senate that Senator Campbell has issued a statement today headed `Apology'. In that statement he says:

ANSWER.PARA: In my speech to the Property Council of Australia in Perth on October 10, I focused on the Federal Government's achievement in reducing unnecessary expenditure, reducing interest rates and cutting taxes on families and small business. It is this that I regard as an important achievement.
Senator Campbell went on to say:
In my speech, I referred to a remark by Maximillian Walsh on ABC Television when he said that Canberra was in recession for the first time in its history.
Senator Campbell then says:
I apologise for my subsequent remarks and any insensitivity they reflect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, given that Senator Campbell has now been forced to apologise, does that mean that the government and Treasurer Costello do not endorse Senator Ian Campbell's comments that a recession in Canberra is a fantastic achievement? Are you really saying, Minister, that Senator Ian Campbell's comments are all his own work made in the context that his long‐term former membership of the Australian Democrats was about to be exposed in the media?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner goes from bad to worse. That is the truth of the matter. Senator, you asked a question and you were given a straight answer. Senator Campbell has apologised for his remarks; he has issued a statement on that matter.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —He has apologised for his remarks; one can't go further than that. I have nothing further to add. The Howard government governs for all Australians. Unlike the trade union Labor Party, we govern for all Australians and the policies we have put into effect—
—Apologise for the thousands of Australians who are unemployed in Canberra.
—Senator Lundy, don't get too excited. (Time expired) .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lightfoot, Sen Phillip

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to Senator Kemp as Assistant Treasurer. I ask the minister: does he recall the Prime Minister's statement on plans to modernise Australia's tax system to promote jobs, savings and investment? My question is in two parts: is the minister aware of suggestions that Australia's tax system does not need—

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Faulkner and Senator Schacht should cease interjecting throughout this question. I call Senator Lightfoot.

—I will go back to the beginning of the question. My question to Senator Kemp is in two parts. Is the minister aware of suggestions that Australia's tax system does not need significant reform; and what would be the implications of failing to reform the current tax system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Lightfoot for that important question. I would have thought there was a general consensus in the Australian community that we have a tax system which is in need of repair and reform to address a variety of problems which most people have come to accept are inherent in our current tax system. It is true to say that a number of significant people in the Labor Party, at least up to this weekend, endorsed the principle of tax reform. Let us start, for example, with the new rising star of the Labor Party, Cheryl Kernot, who said on 5 May—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought the Labor Party would have been interested to know Cheryl Kernot's views on this matter. This is what former Senator Kernot said:

ANSWER.PARA: Without genuine tax reform we are not going to make a lot of progress as a nation.

That is from former Senator Kernot, who is being fast tracked to the front bench of the Labor Party. Then on 1 September 1997, just days before she departed the Democrats for the Labor Party, Cheryl Kernot said:
I am prepared to leave the door open on a broad based consumption tax except—
In fairness to Cheryl Kernot, she said—
we still have reservations that are left over from last time.
Former Senator Gareth Evans said on 19 May on the question of taxes on consumption and expenditure, and I quote your shadow Treasurer:
There may be a case for tax reform. Of course, we would have to look at any such proposal.
Lindsay Tanner, one of the up and coming Young Turks of the party, said this:
Faced with a threat of the income tax system unravelling, Labor must examine alternative foundation stones for our tax system.
Then he went on to say:
Labor should explore the concept of converting the income tax system into a general expenditure tax mechanism.
That came from Mr Lindsay Tanner. Wayne Goss said this:
I think Labor has to completely re‐fashion its policies. I believe that ordinary taxpayers are paying too much in income tax.
That is what Wayne Goss says. He goes on:
We need to be looking at services, we need to be looking at the black economy.

As I said, I think that in the wider community there is a general acceptance that there are serious problems with our current tax system. In fact, George Campbell said something too but, in deference to you, George, I will not bother to quote that.
Senator George Campbell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, you have, George. You have said something—
—Senator Kemp, you should direct your remarks to the chair.

—Thank you, Madam President. I was being provoked by Senator Campbell. What we had really up to this weekend was a general consensus in the community, and indeed from prominent members of the Labor Party, on the need for tax reform. The reality is that we do not know whether their new draft platform is going to be subject to change. I said `draft', not `daft' platform.
—Very funny, ha ha!
—Stop laughing, then. If you did not think it was funny, why did you laugh? (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Special Minister of State. Minister, when you were asked by Mr Matt Peacock on The World Today whether the government would release its legal advice on whether the Native Title Amendment Bill complies with Australia's international obligations, you said:

QUESTION.PARA: What matters is the constitutionality of the bill and the question of whether or not the bill benefits Aboriginal people . . .

Minister, why doesn't it matter that the Native Title Amendment Bill comply with Australia's international legal obligations? Doesn't the government regard Australia's international legal obligations under instruments such as the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination as important? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, this sounds awfully like the question you asked me last week in relation to the government's position on what, if any, advice we had had, and I refer you to the answer I gave then. What does matter, of course, is the question of the legal advice on the constitutionality of the bill. That is what matters to this parliament: can we pass laws which comply with the constitution? We have released the advice of the Solicitor‐General, your appointed Solicitor‐General, supported by David Jackson QC and his associate and supported by the President of the New South Wales Bar Association, that the legislation is constitutional.

ANSWER.PARA: I have also said, in relation to the question of Australia's international legal obligations, that they were taken fully into account in framing this bill. We were cognisant of Australia's international human rights obligations in examining our response both to the need to repair the Native Title Act and to take account of the Wik decision. And, as I said to you last week, what we have done is maintain exactly the same relationship between the Racial Discrimination Act and this legislation as you did, and that is to provide in clause 7(1) that nothing in this act affects the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act. We think that is the appropriate arrangement and relationship between those two pieces of legislation.

So I find myself repeating what I said to you last week on this matter, because your question seems quite similar to it, and I am not sure that you are in a position to seek any additional information. You have, I gather, something on the Notice Paper in relation to this matter and you are free to pursue that, but I think you are wasting the parliament's time in question time pursuing a matter you pursued last week.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. I tell the minister that I will keep on asking this question until we get a full answer. Isn't it a fact that the government has received legal advice that the Native Title Amendment Bill is inconsistent with Australia's international legal obligations and inconsistent with the Racial Discrimination Act? Minister, will you now release that legal advice; if not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the traditional practice of governments, including yours, not to speculate about what advice they may or may not have received in the framing of legislation. Obviously, in framing this very complex piece of legislation, we received a whole range of advice on a whole range of issues, and the advice that we believe it is appropriate to inform the parliament of is that relating to the constitutionality of the bill, a matter that you have challenged consistently and on which we have consistently said to you, and established, surely to your satisfaction, from your own appointed Solicitor‐General, that the bill is constitutional and a bill of net benefit to Aboriginal people.

—My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer. Today's Sydney Morning Herald reports a loss of 10,000 full‐time jobs in the banking industry in the next 12 months. Minister, isn't it true that your government's policies of financial deregulation are reducing the quality and cost‐effectiveness of consumer services in banking, are reducing the employment prospects of banking employees, are failing substantially to eat into the lending margins and overall are doing nothing but adding massively to the profits that bank managers and executives can report to shareholders each time they announce a new round of redundancies? Minister, what is your government doing to save jobs in the banking industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the opportunity to reply to the question from Senator Stott Despoja. Senator, I did read the article in the Sydney Morning Herald , or at least a summary of it. I am not aware whether it is a factual report or not, but nonetheless it did indicate that a number of banks were looking at cutting staffing. The banks presumably will respond as to whether that is accurate or not.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the financial markets, I think your question missed out that the government is already delivering very substantial benefits to Australians. The most important benefit in terms of financial markets, I think all Australians would agree, is the very large reduction in interest rates which has occurred since this government came into office. There are a number of reasons for that very large reduction. One is the fact that we have been able to put our fiscal house in order. We were left with a dreadful overhang from the previous government, the Keating government, and in our first and second budgets we set out to repair that problem.

Another reason why interest rates are coming down is the increased competitive arrangements in money markets. These benefits have flown through to a very large number of Australians, including young couples who are home owners and people in business who borrow money. I would have thought that it was widely recognised in the community—apart from in the Labor Party, who moan about everything—that this government, by putting its fiscal house in order and by encouraging greater competitive arrangements in financial markets, is delivering very substantial benefits to Australians.

BREAK.PARA: In financial markets, of course, there is a whole growth area occurring in bodies apart from banks, and employment is being created in those areas. Mortgage originators is one area which has seen very substantial growth. It is true that you can point to certain institutions which may be cutting their staffing. Equally, there will be many other institutions in the financial area which are putting on money, in part because of the very dynamic environment that this government has helped to create.

I think you can point to particular problems in particular areas regarding services. Where those occur in the market there will be other bodies which will be moving in to pick up where you might think some of the major institutions are cutting back. It is a very dynamic and progressive market. It is one which is creating jobs. In your statement you just stated the jobs which you felt the major banks were cutting back on, but you did not quote the very substantial job growth which is occurring elsewhere in financial markets. We, of course, are very anxious in the Wallis reforms to ensure that Australia has a world‐competitive financial system, a properly regulated financial system and a system that delivers a very wide range of effective services to consumers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, are you seriously suggesting that you are not familiar, specifically that is, with the number of job losses in this industry—that you skimmed an article this morning and that is the extent of your knowledge of the specific number of jobs that are being lost in that industry? Secondly, are you not concerned about the level of job losses in this industry? I can point to examples: Westpac and ANZ, which announced at recent shareholders meetings not only record breaking profits but also a massive number of job losses. Are you familiar with the Prime Minister's comments today at APEC, on the AAP wire, that he is going to lock in provisions that would allow increased foreign ownership of banks in Australia? Do you agree with the Prime Minister's comments, and will this lead to job protection and the substantial benefits to which you referred in your answer?

—Lucky I am so slow to be provoked, Senator—very slow to be provoked—or else I may have been slightly annoyed with aspects of that question, because they were extensively answered. I referred to the fact that I was aware that there was a report in the paper. I referred to the fact that in the financial services area overall there are a great many jobs. I mentioned, for example, the mortgage originators, which are picking up where some of the banks have left off. Senator, you have to have a wider view than that which you have shown. If you had fairly listened to the response I gave you, at least nine‐tenths of your supplementary question should have been cut off.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. Minister, in light of the outsourcing of Department of Finance and Administration IT to IBM subsidiary, IBMGSA, can you guarantee the security of data held by the Office of Asset Sales? Will you acknowledge that there is now sufficient concern about the sensitivity of data that some elements of the Office of Asset Sales database should be excluded from the outsourcing process? Given the Attorney‐General's statement that it is incumbent upon every agency entering into an outsourcing contract to ensure that the contractor understands the importance of the protection of individuals' personal information, can you guarantee that all agencies have met that obligation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have a brief from the Minister for Finance and Administration which touches on aspects of the question that you have raised. I will refer those aspects which are not touched on to the Minister for Finance and Administration.

ANSWER.PARA: The chief executive of OASIT, as you are aware, has indicated that this issue—independence from the IBMGSA contract with DOF—is amongst the first of the matters he has identified as requiring resolution in the amalgamation of OAS and the IT outsourcing functions from OGIT. He has indicated his intention of negotiating with the Department of Finance and Administration and IBMGSA to dispense with the services of IBMGSA following the physical co‐location of the two functions during December. OASIT would then move to appoint an appropriate contractor to manage its small in‐house desktop IT functions under arrangements that would be seen to fully protect the probity and security of access to OASIT information. The details of this change have yet to be developed.

I am advised by the Minister for Finance and Administration that OASIT would not wish this move to be interpreted as any criticism of IBMGSA, whose service to OAS in the short time it has been in place has been commendable. The Minister for Finance and Administration further advises that it could be seen as necessary to avoid any suggestion that IBMGSA could have inappropriate access to OASIT information relevant to contracts in which it may have had an interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Social Security. Is the minister aware of reports expressing concern about the impact on university students of the number of hours they are spending in paid work to support themselves? Will the minister explain how the government's proposed youth allowance addresses those concerns and assists students undertaking further education or training?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that Senator Payne has long had an interest in matters to do with students and other young people. There was an item in today's press about the high number of university students who are also engaged in employment, and the concerns that that raises about the effect of trying to juggle study and work.

ANSWER.PARA: University students are going to be among the winners with the youth allowance. It removes the inequity that currently exists in financial support for young people, depending on whether they are unemployed or whether they are university students who are continuing in training or education. It is in our national interest to provide incentives for young people to develop skills. Unskilled jobs are disappearing all around the developed world. It is definitely not in our national interest to let them just drift off onto the dole queues.

Students will understand that; they have been getting the poorer deal. They can spend several years doing their course. Currently, their Austudy is means tested. But, if they qualify for Austudy of less than $1,000 a year, they do not get anything. Their friends on the dole get more money in their fortnightly payments and access to a range of other benefits which are not available to full-time students. That sort of arrangement sends the wrong message: that you are better off on the dole than in training or education—that is, getting skills that will help you to get jobs. After all, that is the message we want to send to them.

Anybody who wants to get that sort of message around to young people today—the message that it is better to be on the dole than to be in training—is doing them a grave disservice. In fact, they should be condemned because they are quite probably condemning those young people to a life of unemployment and the margins of the labour market.

Under the youth allowance, there will be significant gains for students. For the first time they will be getting access to rent assistance where they have to live away from home for their studies. That is going to benefit an estimated 70,000 young Australians who, on average, will get an extra $31 a fortnight; but they could be getting up to $75 a fortnight extra, depending on their circumstances. That is, of course, a real boost for young people from rural and remote areas.

The $1,000 minimum entitlement requirement for Austudy will be abolished, and that is going to benefit 41,200 students. The independence criteria for youth allowance will be more lenient than applies under Austudy currently, and that will benefit 16,600 students. All youth allowance recipients, including university students, will have access to the $500 loan advance, which is currently only available to newstart recipients. Students will also have access to the pharmaceutical allowance and to the remote area allowance.

BREAK.PARA: We are also introducing an income bank for full-time students, many of whom earn an income during their vacation which they use to support themselves through the academic year. That income bank works like this: students will have an income‐free area of $230 a fortnight before their youth allowance is affected; and a student who does not use up all the income‐free area can credit the unused part to their income bank up to a maximum of $6,000 a year. It is truly good news for students in Australia. It will mean that young people will see the virtue of going for job skills rather than accepting a life on the dole. That is what the nation expects, and hopes for, for its young people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, after that good news for Australian students, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Forshaw asked me a question on 17 November in relation to therapeutic groups premiums policy. I seek to incorporate the answer to that question in the Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
QUESTION WITHOUT NOTICE
SENATOR FORSHAW—17 NOVEMBER 1997
Therapeutic Drugs

SENATOR FORSHAW—Madam President, my question is directed to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Minister, I refer to the Government's proposed therapeutic groups premiums policy which will come into effect from 1 February next year. Minister, can you tell us how many Australians are currently being treated with therapeutic drugs which will fall into the government's proposed five groups? Is it true that there are at least 1½ million such persons who will come within those five groups? And, Minister, what will be the impact on these people, and how many of them will be exempted?
SUPPLEMENTARY QUESTION

SENATOR FORSHAW—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I might say I am surprised that you are unable to provide any estimate of numbers, given that this measure is actually intended to be a budget savings measure on the PBS scheme. One would have thought that the government would have had some idea of how many people will be affected. But, Minister, you mentioned in your answer the position of the elderly. Will the government give consideration to exempting nursing home patients from the additional costs which this policy will no doubt impose?

The Government is able to advise that in 1996/97 about 23 million out of a total of 123.4 million prescriptions were processed by the Health Insurance Commission for the drugs covered by the four therapeutic groups. Prescription data is not aggregated by individual patients. It must be remembered that half the medications involved will not cost one cent more. Counting each individual brand, the drugs in the therapeutic groups amount to 6 per cent of the total number of 1,855 drugs subsidised on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Taxation Indonesia and Thailand: IMF Assistance Commonwealth Bank Shares Telstra Sale Canberra: Recession Banking Industry IT Outsourcing

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) to questions without notice asked today.

According to advice given to a Senate estimates committee, Senator Kemp—as well as his other duties as a frontbencher for the coalition—is in charge of the detailed design of tax policy. What we have had today is another, I have to say, breathtaking display of incompetence in terms of Senator Kemp's range of knowledge of the subjects under which he has the authority to reform.

Last Wednesday we had a series of questions put to Senator Kemp on taxation, just as we have had today. On both occasions, last Wednesday and today, Senator Kemp put most of those questions on notice. He does not know fundamental answers to questions about tax policy. But what we do have to acknowledge he is good at is waffling, he is good at evasion, he can draw a red herring across the path. But can he answer a straight question with a straight answer? The answer to that is: no, of course he cannot.

This is another case of the `Jim Shorts'. We had a former Assistant Treasurer in this chamber who resigned. I might say that what was catching up with him very quickly was a reputation for incompetence. This is another example of another minister equally so. It is about time that we had the `Come on down, John Watson' call because, the most competent senator on the coalition side when it comes to matters of taxation is unquestionably Senator Watson.

Ten days ago at a Senate estimates committee, the question of the government's proposal to reform the tax system came up, with reference being made to the taxation reform task force. Everyone in Australia knows that the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, has boasted long and loud in this country that tax reform will be something that he will be seeking a mandate for at the next election. We know from what Mr Howard has said that a GST will be a key feature of that tax reform. We know that the government, from what it has said via press release, has set up an in-house secret committee within the Department of Treasury to prepare a document for that tax reform.

We also know, from evidence given by Dr Ken Henry to a Senate estimates committee 10 days ago, that that tax reform committee reports to the Treasurer (Mr Costello), it reports to the Prime Minister, and it reports to the cabinet. But does it report to the minister whose job is the detailed design of tax policy in Australia? The answer to that question is: no, it does not. When asked specifically, `Do you report to Senator Kemp?' Dr Henry said, `No.' Senator Kemp then brightly chimed in—and the Hansard record of this estimates committee will reveal this as a fact—`That's right, he does not report to me.'

So the person whose job it is to design the tax policy of this nation is not included in the chain of reporting for the most fundamental review of the tax system the government has ever promised—the jewel in the crown of the government's forthcoming election policy: the total review and overhaul of the Australian tax system.

Why does the minister not get involved in this process? As has been demonstrated in this chamber over the last several days when questions on tax policy have been put to him, he does not know the answer. There is one conclusion: he is not in the loop because he is incompetent. He does not know the answer. He has no original information to bring to the issue. And it does not stop there.

We have had questions on IT outsourcing. We have had questions on the drawdown of the IMF pledge to Thailand and Indonesia. I think you will find that is an answer which he will have to amend at some future time. We have had questions on a range of issues associated with discretionary trusts and non-fixed trusts concerning rollover relief. We have had questions on the range of provisions of the fringe benefits tax and on artificial capital gains to shareholders—the way the 45-day rule in trading and franking credits works. All of these things have a degree of technical element to them, but all of these things are, front and centre, what a minister in this place should know about. They are subject to press releases by the Treasurer, and they are matters on which the minister should be able to be fluent in answering. He is not.

He said to us last Thursday that he had not yet read the Peter Dawkins' review of negative income tax. He did not know about that major debate in income tax. Today he filled in his own dorothy dixer—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Everybody in Australia recognises the need for tax reform except the ALP. Unfortunately, Senator Cook, I know that you know better. But, unfortunately, you have to conform to caucus rules.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the series of questions comprehensively responded to by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), I must inform you that, in relation to the IMF and Indonesia, surely all thinking Australians recognise the need of the importance for good relations with that country. The Indonesian archipelago nation is the fifth most populous nation on earth, spreading 5,000 kilometres from east to west, to Australia's near north and is our second nearest neighbour. Indonesia is strategically very important to Australia. It has an emerging economy with all the problems that involves. Fortunately, Australia is doing the right thing by our Asian partners: it is going to assist Indonesia and also Thailand and Korea through the IMF. I applaud the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and his government for such far-sighted initiatives. Such measurers are important not only today but also in terms of future relations between Australia and the Asian countries which we all know are so important.

Senator Conroy also asked the minister a question in relation to the Commonwealth Bank buyback arrangements. If I recall correctly, the senator asked very similar questions to the Australian Taxation Office at the Senate estimates hearing into Treasury and the administration of the ATO last week. In fact, at the estimates hearing the Chief Tax Counsel, Mr Michael D'Acenzo, advised that it was difficult to give complete and full details because of the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which prevents officers from making public information in relation to taxpayers' tax returns and affairs.

When the scheme was first announced by the CBA, it appeared particularly generous for investors because it offered two types of tax benefits. It offered franked dividend benefits coupled with capital loss deductions. It was not surprising that, under such circumstances, the Australian Taxation Office intervened, describing such arrangements as `inappropriate'. Following that intervention, the ATO arranged with the bank to substantially reduce the leakage of revenue that could have eventuated from the $650 million original proposal.

The amendments proposed seek to block schemes devised by companies to stream the payment of dividends or other distributions to shareholders so as to give the shareholders who benefit most from the franking credits a greater franking benefit or credit than those which would not have benefited to the same degree. The CBA, therefore, will modify the original buyback scheme to reduce its capital gains tax advantage and the amount of the payout of franked dividends. The sale price will now be deemed to be $7—up $5 from the original $2 proposal.

I would like to take this opportunity to commend both the ATO and the CBA on such a speedy resolution to what could have been a long litigious dispute. I commend the capable minister, the Hon. Rod Kemp, for the comprehensive answers that he provided not only to Senate estimates but also to the Senate this afternoon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Every time Minister Kemp starts giving in question time his well-known impersonation of an outboard motor you know perfectly well that he does not know the answer to the question he is being asked. I think he has now established the record for consistent inability on the existing frontbench of this government. He is referred to as `Senator Waffle' on this side of the house. The reason why is obvious to anyone who pays any attention to or has an interest in question time in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I was extremely interested today in the non-answer that he gave not to questions from the opposition but to a question from Senator Stott Despoja on staffing levels in the Commonwealth Bank. The minister treated that question in a very dismissive manner. He wiped it aside as a matter of no account and of no legitimate interest. He went on to say, again to my great interest, that he was slow to be provoked otherwise he would have given Senator Stott Despoja a real caning for daring to ask a question about restructuring in the Australian banking industry and indeed staffing problems in banks.

No opposition member was more assiduous in criticising the then government for ministers not having the detail to detailed questions than was Senator Kemp. As the Hansard record indicates, no member of the then opposition, the coalition, was more assiduous than Senator Kemp in traversing this particular matter during the Senate estimates proceedings.

I was astonished by Minister Kemp's answer to Senator Stott Despoja. I recall only too well the huge fuss Senator Kemp made in 1995—Senator Stott Despoja may not be aware of it, because she was not here in 1995, so she might like to have a look at the Hansard record—when he raised, as a matter of great importance, the question of restructuring in the Australian banking industry and attempted to lie that at the feet of the then government.

Senator Stott Despoja might want to refer to the Hansard of 6 June 1995, when a motion was moved by Senator Kemp in this chamber. It was a formal motion which demanded the presence of Commonwealth Bank officers at Senate estimates. Why was Senator Kemp extremely concerned about it then? I will tell you why. He said:

I have a particular interest in this because I am a Victorian. It is very clear that there have been massive retrenchments of Commonwealth Bank officers in that state and a large number—some hundreds, maybe up to 1,000—of forced redundancies.
He wanted to question the bank directly here, in the Senate. In what was a very prolonged speech when he moved that motion, he went on to say:

The Commonwealth Bank, I believe‐‐and the figures demonstrate this‐‐has got itself into one awful mess in Victoria. It has in an arrogant way been carrying out a massive restructuring of the bank without properly taking the public into its confidence and involving itself in compulsory retrenchments—

I sat here with some amazement today in question time, knowing the enormous importance that Senator Kemp—always renowned for his interest in matters financial; he was formerly a member of a think tank—placed on these matters. Even when he was in opposition he had a massive interest in bank restructuring and staff losses in banks, as the Senate Hansard record will show.

But today in his usual style—his usual incompetent, arrogant and contemptuous way—he dismissed Senator Stott Despoja's question out of hand and in fact went further, as we all here in Senate question time today recall, by saying that, if it were not for his great forbearance—this is his condescending way—he would have really given Senator Stott Despoja a caning over raising the issue of staff retrenchments in banks. I suspect that, having been reminded of his own concern about this when in opposition, we will not be hearing any more on the subject from this particularly incompetent minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been interested to hear in the course of this debate Senator Collins quoting at length from Hansard and Senator Cook mention that, if we examine the Hansard of estimates closely, we will find that Senator Kemp failed to answer many questions. Senator Cook, I would have thought that you would be the last one who would want us to investigate or study the Hansard of the estimates committee too closely.
—I never said—

—Yes, you did. You said that a close examination of Hansard will reveal that Senator Kemp did not answer a lot of questions. That is what you said. Let me tell you that a close examination of Hansard is not something that I would have thought that you would have wanted of anybody, particularly for the estimates hearings that we have had over the last week.

SPEECH.PARA: Out of many of the questions that were asked during the estimates, which are recorded in Hansard, there are some real highlights. Senator Conroy, certainly towards the end of the estimates for economics on Thursday, when we were getting close to the end of some 33 hours of sitting, asked a broad range of questions of the Secretary to the Treasury, Mr Ted Evans. It got to the stage where, having asked three or four of these questions in a row, Mr Evans said, `This, Senator Conroy, is not a question for estimates.' That was very typical of the sort of questioning that went on for a considerable length of time during the estimates process. It is that process that I want to make some comment on.

I am very sorry that Senator Lundy has left the chamber because she put on quite a turn on Thursday at estimates. She felt that she had been gagged, to use her own words, from asking questions. I put the case very clearly to her that the time frame that had been arranged was allocated by her colleagues, not by me, and I agreed to that time frame. Yet, when it came to 1.30 p.m., when the time had run out—the time for finishing that was suggested by her colleagues—she put on a turn and said that she had been gagged, that this was without precedent—I think that that was quoted in the paper—and that all that she had asked for was five extra minutes for questioning.

I looked at the Hansard record this morning and saw that she did ask whether we could recall officers for 30 minutes of questioning. That was her request after lunch. I said to her that, if she could not arrange with her own colleagues a better arrangement of time, it was no fault of mine, because her colleagues were the ones who selected the time that we should finish questioning of the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism so that we could get on to Treasury, which was an important matter that was coming up, and the questions that Senator Cook referred to, which were asked of both the departmental officials and the minister.

Let me tell you, Senator Cook, that one thing that came out of your questioning at estimates of Dr Ken Henry, who was involved in the tax reform task force, is that this government is determined to progress the issue of tax reform. There is no other issue that confronts the Australian public today like the issue of tax reform. An overwhelming majority of the Australian community say that we have a tax system that must be reformed.

This government will not shy away from that reform process. It is doing this in two particular ways: one, by having a tax reform task force, which involves professionals who look into the intricacies and effects of certain decisions should they be made; and, two, by having a government members task force, which I am very pleased to be a part of, which will allow people from within the community to make submissions to that task force, and the government members will listen to all of the arguments put forward by all of the groups within the community that want to have an input.

This government listens and is going to listen to the community particularly on this issue, which is something that the previous government never did. It never listened and it never bothered to consult with the com munity, all of whom have a particular view on the issue of tax reform. I cannot find anybody yet who has said to us that the present system we have is right—the system of wholesale sales taxes, which was put into place and used to such a degree by the former Keating government, where we have this untold array of taxes which nobody knows they are paying. People want a simpler, more transparent tax system where they know where their taxes are going. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to take note of all questions asked of Minister Kemp today. Minister Kemp's not atypical performance in question time today does not reflect well on the government's recently expressed self‐confidence that it has control of the nation's micro and macro-economic levers. His attacks, attempts to deflect, half answers, non-answers, taking on notice and bald claims of putting the house in order do not promote confidence in the government's economic management, especially whilst unemployment levels remain unacceptable and whilst we still lack any industry policy on which to base growth.

SPEECH.PARA: An article by Ross Gittins in today's Sydney Morning Herald prompted me as I approached question time today and Minister Kemp's performance in question time to actually pay a bit more attention at how he responds to questions in question time. There has been some discussion about the performance of the several senators in recent estimates hearings and this taking note session is not about estimates performance.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was raised.

—It certainly was raised, Senator Ferguson. It was raised by Minister Kemp as a means of deflecting attention away from what he should be applying himself to, namely his answer to a question in question time. Let us have a close look at what Minister Kemp provided to us in question time today.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I do that I want to refer to Ross Gittins' explanation about the situation referred to in estimates. He said that, whilst much concern has been raised about the use of certain language in Senate estimates—and I agree with that concern and Senator Cook has certainly already apologised in relation to that matter—we also need to look at what was involved in the situation and the extent of the provocation about Minister Kemp's lack of answers in relation to questions about a very important Industry Commission report that remains confidential. We still have no answers to those questions.

In his performance today Minister Kemp has certainly lived up to his reputation for—I pick up Ross Gittins's comment—being the `Minister for Ducking'. We have certainly called him the `Minister for Waffles'. In fact directly to the minister I have threatened to drop into the supermarket during one trip and actually distribute some in question time. The Minister for Ducking is the title given to him by Ross Gittins.

Today when listening to his responses I thought that he is actually becoming more the minister for attacking the man rather than answering the question. That was certainly today's performance. Let us look at some of those attacks on the man. He attacked Senator Conroy for his supposed behaviour in estimates. He did not actually refer to anything explicit, although Senator Ferguson made a few later comments. He attacked Labor's position on R&D syndication, despite the fact that recent evidence is showing the dramatic decline in R&D as a consequence of this current government's policies in relation to R&D. He attacked Senator Schacht and said he had not asked Senator Alston any questions in relation to communications. It was a question that was quite clearly about the handling of the Telstra float by financial institutions. How that pertains to Senator Alston is well and truly beyond me.

If we start at the very beginning, the first question he had to take on notice and was on the issue of drawing down Australia's contributions with respect to Indonesia and Thailand. He gave no answer in relation to Senator Bob Collins' question as to whether there would be different rules for revenue and capital expenditures in relation to the capital gains tax transitional arrangements. I have already mentioned his attack on Senator Conroy. He also did not answer Senator Conroy's question about whether the proposed dividend distribution component of the buyback in relation to the Commonwealth Bank would qualify for the savings rebate.

I have already mentioned his answer to Senator Schacht and that was to deflect the issue of communications to Senator Alston. If we look at his answer to Senator Faulkner's question in relation to the Canberra recession, he did not answer the issue of whether Senator Ian Campbell's comments about the Canberra recession were endorsed or not. Sure, he read a statement of apology, but then he attempted to justify this recession by saying, `We are governing for all Australians.' That response can almost justify anything. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman, Sen Grant

TALK.START.PARA: —It is instructive that this motion to take note of answers today was moved by Labor Senator Cook on behalf of the opposition. That is very instructive because we see in that process Senator Cook continuing his personal attack on Minister Kemp for which he became somewhat notorious in the Senate budget estimates hearings a couple of weeks ago.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the charge today against Minister Kemp levied by Senator Cook and his Labor colleagues? The charge is exactly the same as Senator Cook made in those estimates hearings, that Minister Kemp is not answering questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true.

—Senator Forshaw, it is not true as I will explain—that allegation is entirely false. The reality is that Minister Kemp is not giving the answers that the Labor senators want and that is quite a different issue from whether or not he is answering the questions that are put to him.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course what is frustrating the Labor senators and causing them to vent their spleen against Minister Kemp is that he is denying Labor the opportunity to create political mischief because he is giving sensible answers to the questions rather than answers which they can use to create political mischief. Of course, as a consequence of that Labor has launched this vicious and quite unjustified attack on Minister Kemp. This is just another aspect of their campaign to frustrate much‐needed tax reform in Australia.

In Australia today, we have a tax system that was designed in the 1930s for an economy that operated in the 1930s. We desperately need a tax system for an economy that is developing for the 21st century and that will successfully take us as a competitive nation into the 21st century. Labor continually attempts to frustrate that process of much needed tax reform.

It is worth noting how this contrasts markedly with the attitude adopted by the Liberal and National parties when we were in opposition. During that long period of Labor government, the Liberal and National parties gave wholehearted support to any needed and sensible reforms that were introduced by the then Labor government. Let me give a few examples: reform of the financial system and the banking system, reform of industry policy and tariffs, and labour market reform to the limited extent that Labor was allowed by its union masters to move on that issue. All of those much needed areas of reform that were addressed at various times when Labor was in office were given wholehearted support by the then Liberal and National parties in opposition.

Now that Labor are in opposition, they steadfastly refuse to adopt that commonsense approach that was adopted by our parties in opposition. In opposition, Labor are doing nothing more than adopting an attitude of wrecking and frustrating. They are refusing to act in the interests of the Australian community, and the whole process of reform is being frustrated. That is at the heart of their attack on Minister Kemp.

I have sat here and listened to Senator Kemp's answers to the questions that have been asked by the opposition, and I have also sat here and listened to answers that he has given to questions asked from senators on our side of the chamber. I certainly believe that the answers he has given are more than adequate, more than satisfactory, and demonstrate that his grasp of this portfolio is quite adequate and competent. That is the real issue.

BREAK.PARA: Minister Kemp is playing an important and integral part in this government's approach to taxation reform, reform which is absolutely essential. If the Labor opposition continue with their attempts to frustrate the reform process not only by their attack on Minister Kemp but by their absolute refusal to consider a range of policy options for taxation reform, they will stand condemned by the Australian community well into the future for adopting this attitude.

As I said earlier, probably the major area of reform remaining to be dealt with in this country is the area of taxation reform. Unless we have a taxation system that meets the needs of industry and commerce as well as PAYE taxpayers as we move into the 21st century, this country will not go forward; in this area it will remain uncompetitive with the international community. It will therefore struggle to obtain investment funds for industry development and growth. Labor stands condemned if that remains the situation. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen George

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to take the opportunity to take note of the answers given by Senator Kemp today in question time. As people in this chamber are aware, I am a relatively new senator. I came here with expectations of learning something from the process of questions being asked of ministers on a range of issues. I have to say that my store of knowledge on the issues of taxation and economics have not been contributed to one iota by any of the contributions that Senator Kemp has made in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that characterises the performance of Senator Kemp in this chamber consistently in question time is his consistent ability to play the man rather than the ball, as referred to by Senator Jacinta Collins. If Senator Kemp were a footballer, he would not get a run on the field. He would be consistently sitting on the sidelines, under suspension for the way he is playing the game. He does not endeavour—

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate the Australian Government's hesitation in signing the Ottawa Treaty to ban the production, sale, stockpiling, transfer and use of landmines.
Your petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. actively support the Ottawa process
2. immediately sign the Ottawa Treaty to ban landmines.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
