PARA.EMPHASIS: Report No. 14 of 1997‐98—Financial and Administration Control Audit—Official Travel by Public Sector Employees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, I present the committee's 11th report relating to economic and commercial cooperation with Kazakhstan and treaties tabled on 30 September and 21 October 1997, together with submissions, transcript of evidence and minutes of proceedings. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

The report I have just tabled deals with eleven treaties, including one, on economic and commercial cooperation with Kazakhstan, which we have recommended should not be ratified at this time. The latter approach is a committee first—more on that in a moment.
We have recommended ratification of the remaining ten treaties as proposed.

However, in the case of one of them: the agreement on trade and economic cooperation with Malaysia, we have recommended also a study to establish whether any other trade or financial agreements are required. In particular, the need for an investment protection agreement needs to be reviewed.
A double taxation agreement with Malaysia was signed in 1980, and the study we have recommended should consider whether this needs to be revised or replaced.

Many of our reports, and accompanying tabling statements, have made comments about a lack of consultation in the process set up after last year's reforms. Unfortunately, that shortcoming persists with some of these treaties.

For example, consultation with at least two of the states about the medical treatment agreement with Ireland appears to have been perfunctory and did not take up their concerns. We have made some comments on the matter.
On the amendments to the Asian‐pacific postal union's constitution, there was no consultation with postal unions or philatelic organisations which might have been interested.
Consequently, we will keep consultation under review until it reaches and maintains a satisfactory level.

On the other hand, it is pleasing to be able to mention a particularly good national interest analysis: for the agreement on the network of aquaculture centres in Asia and the pacific, or NALA. This shows evidence of widespread consultation with the many groups with an interest in that agreement. More importantly, it included sufficient detailed information for us to grasp easily what the agreement set out to do, and where there were difficult issues.

I think that all of my colleagues on the committee would join with me in saying that those responsible in the department of primary industries and energy did a very good job on this NIA. They were very responsive also to suggestions from our secretariat during the inquiry process.

The NALA agreement will provide a means for this country's aquaculture industry both to contribute to and receive knowledge in this rapidly growing industry. As the section on this agreement in chapter 4 of the report shows, this is a substantial subject.

During our hearing on it, concerns were expressed about the future of Australia's quarantine regime as a member of NALA. We were advised that membership `would not affect our sovereign rights to set our level of quarantine protection'.
In view of the evidence we were given about diseases in some parts of the Asian aquaculture industry, this latter advice is very important.
I return to the agreement on economic and commercial cooperation with Kazakhstan.
Of itself, this is not a very significant agreement. However, it is important because it is the first time we have recommended that a treaty should not be ratified.
Briefly, Telstra was operating within the law in Kazakhstan but found that its licence for a joint venture arrangement was revoked, suffering a loss of some $A7 million.

Although Telstra is not the only Australian company operating on a joint venture or other basis in Kazakhstan, the way it has been treated sets a generally unacceptable standard. To ratify this agreement would send the wrong message to Kazakhstan about what is acceptable in commercial relations within Australia and internationally.

We have recommended against ratification at this time because, while we do not think that any agreement would have protected Telstra totally, we do believe that it has been treated in an unacceptable way. It is difficult to be clear about the position in that country, but Telstra may, just might, get its money back. It certainly wants to remain operating in that country.

We have recommended also that this agreement not be reconsidered for ratification unless and until there are demonstrations by Kazakh authorities of good faith in its trading relations with Australia. We believe that either re‐entry into the market, or payment of compensation, would be appropriate ways of showing much‐needed good faith in this situation.

The situation in Kazakhstan may change, and ratification of this agreement could be proposed at some time in the future. If so, we have recommended that a new NIA outlining the reasons for the change should be tabled to allow the committee to consider the matter further.

The second chapter of the report reveals that we were not happy with all aspects of the evidence given to us by DFAT on the Kazakh issue. This was especially so at a hearing on 1 September, when pertinent evidence was not presented—something out of character for that department which has set a high standard in the evidence it has given.

There is one further point I would like to make on the Kazakh agreement. We were concerned that the minerals council of Australia was approached to give evidence but decided to leave this to individual member companies. This was very disappointing, as we believed it could have made a useful contribution to our understanding of the situation in central Asia, as it affects a range of Australian companies.
I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Bolkus and pursuant to notice, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Family Law Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No. 157 and made under the Family Law Act 1975, be disallowed.

The Family Law Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No. 157, represent yet another broken promise by the Howard government. In the budget, the government said that it would implement a $40 dollar per hour fee for voluntary mediation and counselling provided by the Family Court. This fee, which was due to commence on 1 January 1997 but which was delayed to the commencement of these regulations, was estimated to raise some $0.835 million in 1996‐97, rising to $1.9 million by 1998‐99. These regulations, made possible by amendments to the Family Law Act passed earlier this year by the Senate, implement that measure.

The concern that the Labor Party has about the introduction of these fees is twofold. First, there are the access to justice implications of slugging families in crisis with a $40 fee for the provision of a service which in fact ultimately saves the government money because it helps to reduce the overall rate of divorce. Secondly, we are concerned at the longer term objectives underlying this bill.

The 1996‐97 annual report of the Family Court shows that the court's counselling and mediation service dealt with 25,869 counselling cases in person and 13,809 telephone counselling cases, crisis calls and intake assessments. During the period, 57,599 interviews in person were held and 35,506 telephone interviews, crisis calls and intake interviews were also conducted. As many as 47.1 per cent of cases came to the service on a voluntary basis. This is down on the almost 60 per cent figure in the 1995‐96 financial year. In all, 18.6 per cent of the cases were referred by the court for counselling after an application for a parenting order in relation to residence, contact or specific issues was filed but prior to the matter first coming to court. A further 28.7 per cent were referred by the court after the first directions hearing.

In the estimates hearings last year, and consistent with research into the effectiveness of the service, it was revealed that 75 per cent of those cases were successfully resolved by the counselling and mediation service. Were it not for the provision of these services, one can only wonder how many more divorces we might have had. By comparison, and quite regrettably, might I say, there were 52,466 divorces last year, up on 49,700 in the year before. For the first time last year, the so‐called crude number of divorces reached exactly half the crude number of marriages. I do not want to suggest that any number of divorces is desirable, but clearly that number and that percentage is simply too high. We need to find ways of reducing the number of divorces in this country.

It is in this context that the imposition of cost recovery on this service is simply bad policy. Despite the fee waiver and refund provisions which will protect the poorest in our society, most Australians who access these services will have to incur this fee. No doubt some of the government members will point to the figures that some 40 per cent of cases received some remission of the fees under these provisions. However, these figures still ignore the very real hardship experienced by those who are not poor enough that they are on a pension or receive some form of government benefit or health care card. Increasingly, there are the working poor, whom this government continues to ignore. To say to families who earn less than $40,000 a year, parents who may be struggling to feed and clothe themselves and their children on that amount of money, that they should pay a fee to help save their marriage is obscene.

To place a barrier to accessing a service that ultimately helps keep families together and reduces the number of cases in the Family Court is simply not good policy. Not only is there the very real personal pain and financial cost of divorce; our entire society suffers when families come asunder. There are very real signs already that this cost barrier is having a substantial effect. The registrar of the Family Court advised Senator Bolkus by letter dated 20 November 1997 that, comparing the June and September quarters of this year, voluntary counselling cases have reduced by 9.9 per cent. At the same time, court ordered counselling before the first directions hearing has increased by 29 per cent and court ordered counselling after the first directions hearing has increased by 20.5 per cent.

The figures are both disturbing and yet clear. Parties are putting off taking up voluntary counselling and, as a result, more cases are waiting until they are formally brought before the court. Not only does this waste the court's and, through it, the community's resources but it also decreases the prospect of these marriages surviving.

This is a disastrous policy and even the early figures following its implementation are demonstrating that. By contrast, there are positive things this government could be doing. I note that Mr Kevin Andrews, the chairman of the House of Representatives Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, has suggested that all new couples should be given a voucher that would provide free marriage or relationship education. Why? Because, as he rightly notes, this would build and strengthen more successful relationships. Surely, then, the process of helping to keep families together is just as worthy of such a sentiment. Or does the government believe that families in crisis should be treated differently—that they should be punished in some way for the failings of their relationships? We submit that they should not.
The move to introduce these fees is a clear breach of the government's election commitment to the Australian people. In its law and justice policy, the coalition promised to:
. . . support and implement moves to increase counselling, conciliation and mediation options in the resolution of disputes.

A measure such as this one, which makes it harder for people to access mediation and counselling services, hardly supports or increases the options that are available to Australian families in crisis.

In his second reading speech on the Family Law Amendment Bill the Attorney sought to defend the government's introduction of these fees on three grounds. The first was by referring to the need for fiscal consolidation, a problem that exists largely in this government's mind alone, with the exception of the $3 billion hole their bungled handling of the economy has cost us. It is a fiscal consolidation which, it has been shown, simply went too far and thus has brought the Australian economy to its knees.

The second was by claiming that the previous Labor government had foreshadowed that it might consider such a proposal in the 1995‐96 budget statements. Indeed, the portfolio budget statement for that year did state that the review of court and tribunal fees initiated by the previous government would examine the suitability of fee regimes for voluntary or optional services which a court might provide. However, what the Attorney failed to say was that the previous government, in light of that review, rejected the introduction of fees for these services.

Finally, the Attorney argued that failing to impose these fees was a form of discrimination for people living in rural and regional Australia. This argument ignores the fact that the Family Court provides extensive mediation and counselling services in rural and regional centres, either through permanent offices or via circuits. Upon closer examination, the Attorney's rhetoric on this point is not only hollow but it is also hypocritical.

If the Attorney really cared about providing services to people in rural and regional centres he would not have cut funding to the Family Court by $3.5 billion last year. Nor would he have cut the provision of family skills training services that were to be opened under Labor's justice statement this financial year in the Richmond‐Tweed area, central Murrumbidgee, Shepparton, Mooroopna, Bendigo, Ballarat, the Gold Coast, Wide Bay, Burnett or the Green River region. He would not have cut the adolescent family mediation services that were to be provided this year and next year in Newcastle, the Clarence, Geelong, Whyalla and Preston, nor would he have cut the family mediation services which were to be opened in Gosford, Newcastle, Wollongong, the northern outer suburbs of Melbourne, Geelong, Bendigo, Ipswich, Wide Bay, Burnett or the Perth south‐east and metropolitan areas.

But the Attorney's insupportable arguments do not end there. In a desperate attempt to further defend his floundering case the Attorney, in reply to the speeches given by my colleagues Mr Melham, Mrs Crosio and Ms Macklin in the other place, argued two further points. Firstly, he argued that it was necessary for there to be greater coordination between the counselling and mediation services provided by the Family Court and those provided by the community sector. However, the Attorney failed to give any reasons as to why the imposition of a $40 per hour fee would encourage such coordination. That is because there is no causal nexus between the two, nor obviously could there be. Secondly, he argued that there was something inconsistent about trying to encourage people to use mediation and counselling services to avoid going to court and having those services co‐located and administered by that court.

The logical failing in this argument is manifestly obvious; it demonstrates clearly the Attorney's complete lack of understanding of the role the services actually play. His arguments ignore the reality that many people facing difficulties in their relationships turn to the Family Court as a first point of call, simply because they do not know where else to go. Co‐locating a service which can deflect people in crisis from the doors of the court or which provides them with another option from proceeding with a case is one of the best forms of intervention and, ultimately and hopefully, resolution that is available.

Further, by his comments, Mr Williams seems unable to understand the very simple point that the referral of people to the Family Court's mediation and counselling services means that these matters are decided outside the courtroom. The Family Court and the court's mediation and counselling service are different yet complementary services. Co‐location of the services is one of the very real reasons why the counselling and mediation service is so successful.

For this Attorney‐General to pretend that this bill will mean fairer access to justice when he has cut over $320 million from access to justice programs over the next four years is the height of hypocrisy and must be rejected by the Senate. However, I am afraid there is a more sinister agenda afoot here. The introduction of these fees is, I believe, the first step in a campaign to remove from the Family Court its ability to provide mediation and counselling services altogether. The release by the Attorney‐General of his discussion paper on the future of the counselling and mediation service is testament to that.

The Attorney‐General has said that he would like to see mediation and counselling become the primary means of dispute resolu tion in Australia. The truth is that, well before this government came into office, the Labor government was well on its way to establishing that ideal as a reality. Only five per cent of Family Court cases are resolved by way of court imposed solution. In the overwhelming majority of cases the parties reach an amicable solution.

The reality of modern family law is that the court imposed solution is now the alternate dispute resolution mechanism. But, in the last few months, public attention has been focused by the actions of this Attorney on the role of mediation in our court system. The Attorney indicated his view on 2 October 1996, when he said:
We would like to see a reduction in the volume of mediation and counselling services provided in the court and the transfer of those to the community.

This was a view he did not derogate from in his more substantive speech to the National Press Club on 15 October 1996. Whilst he did back down somewhat from his previous comments by committing himself to extensive consultation on the issue, he went on to say:
There is much to be said for the view that the Family Court should be freed up to concentrate on its primary function—that is, to hear and determine legal disputes in family law matters.

This approach is at odds with the well recognised need to further integrate mediation into court processes. Chief Justice Brennan, in his speech to the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration on 24 September 1996, said:

Mediation and arbitration will continue to be familiar and prominent features of the system of dispute resolution in the future. There is no reason why, in the vast majority of cases, mediation should not be compulsory in the sense of being a condition of the right of any party to have the dispute brought to trial. But let it be court attached mediation—
and I emphasise those words—
‐ either the mediator should be a court officer or a private mediator selected by the parties by lot or by rotation. In either case the fees should be a charge on public revenue.

In direct response to the Attorney's comments and in support of the approach suggested by the Chief Justice that I have just read, Ms Jenny Boylan, the Chair of the Family Law Council, has also publicly stated that the council had already advised the Attorney that the court should retain its counselling services. She did this by way of letter of advice to the Attorney on 30 June 1996, and that letter is annexed to the council's 1995‐96 annual report. Quoting from Ms Boylan's comments when talking about the Attorney's recommendations, she said:

If implemented, this recommendation would destroy the successful conciliation aspects of the court's operation. It would hamper the settlement of matters, particularly those involving children, and result in the loss of a significant degree of expertise within the court which has benefited the interests of children as the legislation requires. The recommendation ignores the important role played by court councillors, mediators and registrars and omits any reference to the extent to which the conciliation services are integrated with the litigation process. It fails to differentiate between voluntary and court related counselling, each of which requires particular skills and knowledge which the court counsellors have acquired and built over the two decades of their operations. The council believes that what is required is the provision of appropriate primary dispute resolution processes at both the community and court levels rather than the either/or approach adopted by the JSC.
Earlier this year the Chief Justice of the Family Court, Mr Justice Nicholson, pointed out that:

Recent research being conducted by Professor Brown and others at Monash University has demonstrated that the only intervention which clearly leads to an early and long lasting resolution of disputes involving child abuse allegations is a reliance on family reports prepared by court counsellors and the use of child representatives. When both are used together they are even more effective. Primary dispute resolution services provided by the Family Court have obvious and direct benefits to very vulnerable families.
We often talk in this place of the need to establish world's best practice in the administration of our Public Service; it should be no different for our courts.

It is interesting to note that the government of Singapore recently decided to review the use of alternative dispute resolution services attached to its courts. After studying various models in the United States, Europe and New Zealand, Singapore has decided to adopt conciliation counselling and mediation services based on those provided by the Family Court of Australia. Fiji and South Africa also are currently examining the Federal Court model. Surely if these services are good enough to export, if they are thought by others to be worthy of imitation, we should retain those services here in Australia. But unfortunately it seems that Mr Williams, the Attorney, does not understand this. Rather, the Attorney prefers to disregard the plethora of expert advice warning him against this approach.

Mr Acting Deputy President and Senators, we can put into practice the advice that this Attorney fails to listen to. We can stop the passage of this bill and, in doing so, we can send a strong message to this government that its old‐fashioned view that `a court should be a court and nothing but a court' is simply inappropriate in this day and age.

The primary object of any dispute resolution service, such as that provided by a court, must be timely, efficient and fair resolution of disputes. We as legislators are obliged to put in place the best mechanisms available to enable ordinary Australians to sort out their problems for themselves as quickly and as cheaply as possible. Counselling and mediation is an integral part of the Family Court. It is a service that must be accessible to all. The imposition of the fees is already creating a barrier to accessing a service which saves both individuals and the public purse money.

Mr Williams has said that, on average, families in crisis will only have to pay $240 to access this service. But, even with the exemptions that are proposed under the regulations which will protect the most impecunious in our society, $240 is still a significant amount of money for your average Australian family to find at a time of crisis.

Surely it would be better to invest this money in saving our families now rather than paying for the considerable human and economic costs of divorce. This is particularly so when the service in question is successful in 75 per cent of cases—a standard equal to, or better than, that of its private sector counterparts. This is a demonstrably regressive measure, and I urge the Senate to support this disallowance motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Murray.
—Aren't we going to hear a response from the minister?
—Senator Murray is the next speaker.
—I am happy to concede, if that assists the Senate.
—It is usual for the minister to respond at the end.
—If the minister wants to do that, that is all right.
—The minister can speak as she chooses.

—by leave—I do have some remarks that I would like to make, but I might also want to make some remarks that relate to what Senator Murray has to say. Senator Harradine, you may want to make a contribution and say something then. I understand it is for that reason that the usual practice is for the minister to respond at the end. I think that might be most appropriate.

—by leave—I am very anxious to hear what Senator Murray has to say, but I acknowledge that the usual thing in these particular areas is for the minister to sum up. There appears to be nobody on the government's side who may be able to give a response, at least in my consideration of this particular matter. Bearing in mind that this is the last day upon which this particular disallowance motion can be considered by the Senate, I would have liked to have listened to what the minister had to say and then adjourn the matter for the day. But, as it happens, I will need to make my contribution without hearing the minister.

—by leave—With the Senate's indulgence, I would be happy to speak now. If I need to respond to something that Senator Murray and Senator Harradine might say, if I am allowed to come back and do that, I am happy to speak now. It is a matter for the Senate really.
—Is it the wish of the Senate that the minister responds now? There being no objection, I call the minister.

—I thank the Senate. I want to highlight that the proposals to consider charging fees for counselling and mediation services in the Family Court were contained in the portfolio budget papers of the former government for 1995-96. That was not something which one might have easily picked up from Senator Forshaw's contribution. Nonetheless, proposals to consider charging fees for these services were contained in those papers. The proposals were also considered as part of the review of fees and charges in Commonwealth courts and tribunals—which was again commissioned by the previous government.

BREAK.PARA: The cost of running the Family Court is now in the vicinity of but exceeding $100 million and has increased in recent years. The introduction of these fees needs to be seen in the context of the deficit crisis that we inherited from the previous government—Beazley's black hole of some $10 billion. The public purse can no longer continue to shoulder such an expensive burden. Groups such as Relationships Australia, Centacare and others like them have traditionally charged fees for similar services to those offered by the Family Court. These are community groups.

Prior to 1 July this year, there were no fees payable for the counselling and mediation services provided by the Family Court. That was not an equitable situation because it meant that some people could get a service for nothing while others were paying. It was often residents of rural and remote locations who had to pay. Despite Senator Forshaw's comments, people are not conveniently placed around family law services. It was done purely on the basis of geography, because they did not have access in the same way that metropolitan people do to the Family Court's free services.

On 1 July this year fees for the voluntary use of counselling services and mediation services provided by the court were introduced. The fees for counselling are $30 per person per session, which is, as I understand it and am advised, on average, 1½ hours when two people attend. The fees for mediation are $50 per person per session, which is, on average, 2½ hours. In community based organisations I am told that the average fee for counselling and mediation is about $40 an hour.

So the fees that are payable for the counselling and mediation services provided by the Family Court are equivalent to the average fees payable for the services provided by community based organisations. There are, however, some differences and it is appropriate to point them out. The main one is that in the Family Court there is a flat fee for counselling or mediation sessions, whereas in community based organisations there is usually a sliding scale of hourly fees, with the fee per hour dependent on the level of income of one or other of the parties.

In the Family Court, as Senator Forshaw pointed out in a somewhat dismissive way, there are significant numbers of people who are exempt from paying the fees—as they should be—for counselling and mediation services, including people who have been granted legal aid, people who hold a card issued by the Department of Social Security or the Department of Veterans' Affairs that entitles them to Commonwealth health concessions, people who are in receipt of Austudy or Abstudy and people who are under 18 years of age. Payment of fees can be waived if the payment of the fee would cause financial hardship to the person. In addition to set categories of people who do not have to pay fees, there is provision for fees to be waived if there is hardship. As I am advised at the moment, about 45 per cent of all fees are waived by the Family Court.

Under the Family Law Act the parties can go to counselling either by consent or when ordered or directed to by the court. However, parties only go to mediation by consent. So attendance at mediation is always voluntary and fees for this service are therefore always to be payable. It is important to note that fees for counselling services provided by the Family Court are charged only when those services are used on a voluntary basis.

I was not here for all of Senator Forshaw's speech, but I did not hear him draw that distinction. Let me repeat it: fees for counselling services provided by the Family Court are charged only when those services are used on a voluntary basis—that is, when the parties consent to counselling. Parties can consent to go to counselling either before having filed an application in the court or after.

The Family Court reports that approximately 50 per cent of the people who use the court's counselling services do so before they have filed an application in the court. Therefore, they use the court's counselling services without having made any contribution to the costs of providing the court services—they have not even filed.

After an application has been filed, the court can also order or direct, without the consent of the parties, that counselling take place. In these circumstances, as I have highlighted, no fee is payable. If people wish to avoid paying fees, they can voluntarily choose not to go to counselling and can wait for the court to order counselling after an application has been filed. However, when people file an application, in most cases they are required to pay a fee. So, even if they do not pay the fees for counselling and mediation services, they will have made some contribution to the costs of providing the court services.

Most people want to resolve their disputes as early as possible, especially where children are involved. It is clear that many people see counselling as a valuable process and will attend voluntary counselling even if fees are charged. After all, many people have been choosing to go to community based counselling services for which they traditionally have had to pay fees.

The government believes there should be a greater reliance on the prevention of disputes arising, and on alternative dispute resolution rather than court actions. We are providing money for marriage education to try to give people the necessary skills to better deal with conflicts in a marriage situation. In addition to that, we are maintaining the expansion of the community mediation programs to assist people to resolve disputes at the local level without the need for courts.

In summary, it is a case of people paying fees for voluntary counselling not being required to pay fees for court ordered or directed counselling. Those people who are undertaking court ordered or directed counselling do not pay. Out of all of those who are choosing to pay, there is a large group which automatically is exempt, and in addition to that there is a waiver opportunity. I repeat that this puts the users of those services more in line with the users of community based providers of those services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I thank you for your helpful remarks and thank the opposition for theirs. At the heart of this debate are two questions: one is where the burden of the cost of justice should fall; the other concerns the modern temptation—maybe it is a practice—to treat justice and the practice of law as a business. I separate those deliberately.

SPEECH.PARA: First, it is the Australian Democrats' position—I think it has been an Australian tradition—that the cost of justice should fall on the community as a whole. That is to ensure that those who need access to justice, those who desire or have to use the services provided in our legal systems, will be able to access justice as cheaply, as easily and as freely as possible in the interests of the community and in the interests of greater social cohesion. I think that principle goes back a very long time in history and is fundamental.

The second issue is the modern practice of treating justice, or the practice of law, as a business. It is true that in many respects the profession is dead and the business reigns. But that is not so throughout the practice of law and has certainly not been so in our courts. The philosophy of treating justice and law as a business produces an inclination, a motivation, towards user pays kinds of doctrines and towards recovering costs wherever they can be recovered. The Minister for Justice (Senator Vanstone) quite rightly makes the point that justice costs a great deal. She quite rightly makes the point that the bucket is not limitless and that the pressures on our judicial system are affected by other budgetary and fiscal needs.

This area of family law deals with one of the three great institutions which hold our society together. The resolution of contractual disputes—that is what it is—needs to be treated in as careful and sensitive a manner as possible. The minister has made it clear in her remarks that the imposition of fees is conditioned, if you like—or the effects are limited—by exemptions and waivers so that up to 45 per cent of users under the present system are not required to pay fees.

She makes the point that it is the voluntary services which will attract fees, and so on. She made a comparison with community based services. Of course, community based services frequently have no other means of funding, apart from donations, some government largesse and fees, whereas government has access to the coercive pressure of the taxation system. Whilst I hear a reasonable discourse from the minister, the Australian Democrats remain wedded to a long and committed view that the cost of justice should fall on the community as a whole and we remain opposed to a user pays mentality.

We opposed these fees in, and the second reading of, the Family Law Amendment Bill 1996. In particular, we paid attention to one of the themes that the opposition picked out, which was the theme that five per cent of cases before the Family Court are now litigated; in other words, 95 per cent are not. That is an extremely attractive percentage to retain and maintain and I personally, on the precautionary principle, would not like to see the introduction of fees put at risk counselling, mediation and the non‐litigation resolution of such matters. We should see counselling and mediation as preventive measures, we should see them as preferred to the adversarial system and we should see them as buffers against costly and time consuming litigation.

I regret, Minister, that despite your observations—many of which are very sound—we will continue to hold the view that fees in this area should be minimised or, if possible, not present at all. Accordingly, we will support the opposition in their motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had to have another serious look at this question and, as I did on the last occasion, I have considered the matter carefully. As I indicated before, I believe that I and the Senate should carefully look at what emerges from the Attorney‐General's Department, office or whatever, having regard to the fact that one of the latest statements made by the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) has been proven to be demonstrably false. I do not want to go into that, but, when the public and the parliament are misled by the Attorney‐General, the first law officer of the Crown—as they were—it is a very serious issue which requires members and senators to carefully examine what emerges therefrom.
—And thereafter.

—And thereafter, yes. I am also interested in what has occurred as a result of questions at the estimates committee hearings. But, before I go on to that, I want to look at some matters that Senator Forshaw has raised in his speech.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true, as the minister said, that there is difficulty in maintaining services where cost cutting measures needed to be implemented to overcome the problem with which the government was faced. She commenced her comments in opposition to the motion put forward by Senator Forshaw by clearly saying that this is a question of costs and that we have a deficit crisis. She questioned whether it is appropriate for persons accessing the conciliation and mediation services of the courts to do so on the public purse, particularly as there are exemption provisions and that 43 per cent—I think that is the figure she mentioned—of the persons who access this service have their fees waived. The minister will clarify that at a later stage if she wishes.

I will come back to that question in a moment but, before I do, I want to note that Senator Forshaw indicated that 47.1 per cent of cases came to the service on a voluntary basis, as compared with 60 per cent last financial year. I take it that those figures are since the court fees were introduced. He also indicated that 18.6 per cent of cases were referred by the court after applications for parenting orders, orders in relation to resi dence and certain other aspects, and that 28.7 per cent were referred by the court after the first directions hearing.

I am not sure whether the minister can clarify in her response whether the 18.6 per cent who were referred by the court after applications for parenting orders would have been required to pay an application fee. I imagine that is the case in regard to parenting orders and orders in relation to residence, contact or specific issues.

They would fit in with the concept that was being advanced and expressed by the minister in her response when she said that, at least, those who access the counselling services of the court should pay something to the system. That is one way of looking at it, I suppose. Senator Forshaw says, `What about looking at it another way? What about the costs saved by voluntary access to the mediation services of the court?' He said that, as a result of questioning at the estimates committee last year, it was revealed:
. . . 75 per cent of those cases were successfully resolved by the counselling and mediation service.
He went on to say:
Were it not for the provision of these services, one can only wonder how many more divorces we might have had.

I presume Senator Forshaw meant how many more contested and litigated divorces we might have had. The point was that account was not being taken by the government of the savings that would be made in court costs as a result of the work of the mediation services.

Other figures emerged from the estimates committee hearings and these figures were mentioned by Senator Forshaw in his speech. They are worth being considered by the committee. It is not for me to repeat them but, nevertheless, they do give an indication that there has been a considerable drop in the number of persons accessing the mediation counselling services since the fees were established on 1 July.

From memory, there was almost a 10 per cent drop in the number of persons voluntarily accessing the mediation services. I put it to the minister: isn't it better to have more people voluntarily accessing mediation ser vices? I was impressed with Senator Forshaw's reference to His Honour, Mr Justice Brennan, of the High Court. Judge Brennan said:

Mediation and arbitration will continue to be familiar and prominent features of the system of dispute resolution in the future. There is no reason why, in the vast majority of cases, mediation should not be compulsory in the sense of being a condition of the right of any party to have the dispute brought to trial. But let it be court attached mediation. Either the mediator should be a court officer or a private mediator selected by the parties, by lot or by rotation. In either case, the fees should be charged on public revenue.

The Chief Justice of the High Court made this comment which, of course, we are not bound to observe. As you would know, Madam Minister, it was not a judgment; it was a speech to the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration. There has been a lot of nonsense talked about our being bound by certain specific aspects of the common law, but that will be for a debate down the track—possibly in the next two weeks.

I put it to the minister that in the latest figures that have been obtained through the estimates committee there has been a drop in the number of voluntary requests for mediation and conciliation. Obviously, we would like to see more emphasis on reconciliation counselling. The more that can be done for that, and for marriage education, the better. Let's face it: this was a neglected area in the administration under the previous Labor government. It was shameful. On marriage education, we need to constantly bear that in mind.

I believe, quite frankly, that where you have voluntary mediation, you obviously are likely to get a better outcome. That clearly stands to reason. Whether it is in the industrial relations area, whether it is in this area or whether it is in other areas, it does not matter. If you have a voluntary approach, you are more likely to get a more satisfactory outcome which those accessing the mediation counselling are prepared to accept.

As has been indicated, the estimates committees showed that since the introduction of the fees not only has there been a drop in the voluntary access to mediation counselling but also there has been a substantial increase in the number of orders to the parties for conciliation. I want to put those figures to the Senate again. The Registrar of the Family Court has stated that, in comparison to the June to September quarter of this year, voluntary counselling cases have reduced by 9.9 per cent. At the same time, court ordered counselling before the first directions hearing has increased by 29 per cent and court ordered counselling after the first direction hearing has increased by 20.5 per cent.

In my mind those figures show that we are going backwards. It does not uphold the well‐known view that voluntary efforts for mediation and conciliation are more likely to prove successful than compulsorily directed counselling and, indeed, are more likely to save other costs involved with court proceedings in the long run, particularly in this case. I intend to support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to respond, Mr Acting Deputy President. In your absence, when someone else was in the chair, I indicated that I would speak earlier, at Senator Harradine's preference. I asked whether it was possible to respond later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, I urge you to reconsider on this matter. The two sets of percentages that you referred to bear some comment. The first are the figures referred to by Senator Forshaw, which anyone can find at page 28 of the annual report of the Family Court. You mentioned that Senator Forshaw points out that as many as 47.1 per cent of all cases seen came on a voluntary basis. Apparently, he compared that with last year's figure of 61 per cent. You take that to be a reduction in people going voluntarily. You then referred to some of the other figures that follow on from that—18.6 per cent referred to counselling by the court and a further 28.7 per cent referred by the court after a first directions hearing.

SPEECH.PARA: Those figures are figures up until 30 June this year. They have no relationship to the fees imposed. I do not recall hearing—I might have been here—that portion of Senator Forshaw's comments, but these fees were introduced on 1 July this year. That drop from 61 per cent to 47 per cent has no relationship to these fees at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were actually contemplated to come in from 1 January.

—Senator Forshaw interjects that they were contemplated to come in from 1 January. Nonetheless, it does not detract from the point that the fees were not introduced until 1 July. Senator Forshaw, I will take the opportunity to go back to the Hansard to see what you said. I would hate to think that you were trying to mislead people. I am not suggesting that you did, but I will take the opportunity of having a look. For Senator Harradine's benefit, he was the one who referred to these figures and that is what I understood him to be saying.

SPEECH.PARA: Then Senator Harradine referred to the registrar of the court, I think in estimates, referring to a drop of about 10 per cent for voluntary counselling for the June and September quarter compared to last year. There are a number of things I would urge you to take into account in that respect. First of all, as I am advised, the use of counselling and mediation does fluctuate. Whenever you take a small period of time and compare it with a small period of time in a previous year, you will necessarily get aberrations. I am not at all confident therefore that we can rely on that comparison. As I am advised, there are quite noticeable variations and fluctuations during the year, for which there is no apparent explanation.

Furthermore, if that voluntary counselling has gone down, we certainly cannot assume that those people are therefore not getting counselling. They may have gone off to Centrecare. Faced with a choice, they may have chosen the community provider. That is another aspect that perhaps has not had as much concentration in this debate as I would have liked.

This is not a case of charging for a service that only the Commonwealth can provide, where people are restricted and must come to court counselling and must come to court mediation. They can go to the community service providers—not that it is the Commonwealth's job to redirect clients in order to keep community service providers going. Equally, on the other side of that coin, it is certainly not the Commonwealth's desire, let alone task, to provide such services free to take away the market, if you like, from community providers.

I acknowledge the figures that were provided at the estimates committee, but with their being based on such a short period, neither you nor any of us can rely on them as a clear indicator. Secondly, even if we could, we do not know that those people have not got counselling. We simply know that they are not doing it voluntarily through the Family Court. They may be going to community providers.

Senator Harradine referred to the increases, apparently, as I understood him to say, that the registrar referred to. As I indicated in my remarks, where there is court ordered counselling no fee is payable. We are talking here about a fee for voluntary counselling—not court ordered counselling.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that.

—I am just making a point as a consequence of the figures that you raised. Because it is voluntary, people can choose to go to the Family Court or to the community service providers. We say in those circumstances where it is entirely voluntary—it was not court ordered and therefore paid for by the court—people can choose where they go and they can choose to go to a community provider and pay and, if they choose to come to the Family Court, they should have to pay something there. But we recognise that there needs to be an acknowledgment of those who simply cannot afford to pay, and that is why there is such an extensive range of people who are excluded from payment or for whom waivers of up to around 45 per cent, which is the figure I quoted, can be provided. So I encourage Senator Harradine to reconsider in this matter on those bases.
—The power that the Commonwealth has to deal with the subject matter we are dealing with is under 51(xxi) and 51(xxii), which say that the Commonwealth has:

BREAK.PARA: . . . power to make laws for the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to:
(xxi) Marriage:
(xxii) Divorce and matrimonial causes; and in relation thereto, parental rights, and the custody and guardianship of infants:

So it is, in my view, central to the Commonwealth's task to provide laws that deal with marriage and with divorce and matrimonial causes. That includes the custody and guardianship of children, which indicates just how important all this is.

The Joint Treaties Committee is looking at the Convention on the Rights of the Child. There has been a remarkable interest in the community about those matters. In my view, one of the worst things that can happen is for parents to get into ongoing legal cases in the Family Court. I am sure judges do not like them. I am sure the community cannot afford them. I am sure it brings great tragedy to the parties and to the children involved. In cases involving two or three marriages, the children are all mixed up.

The best way to dispose of contention, as Senator Harradine said, whether it is industrial contention, contention over the land—we are about to debate that in the Wik matter—or, most importantly, contention over matrimonial relationships, is for parties to agree when it is fundamental to the concept of law under which we operate.

Indeed, if I recall correctly my catechism as a youth, Luke has Christ saying that if you are off to court make sure you settle on the way, otherwise you are going to get into all sorts of trouble. It seems to me that this is the sort of issue we face here. Surely to goodness, if parties can get together on a voluntary basis or with the help of other people and settle the matter, isn't that a good thing not only economically, as has been pointed out, but also socially and for the marriage and the children involved?

TALK.START.PARA: —It's good for the economy.

—And good for the economy, as Senator Forshaw says. The other point I want to make before I sit down is that this, again, is a restriction by government on money necessary to run that part of government involved in settling disputes. It is an essential part of the function of government. Making laws is what we do; carrying out those laws is what the executive does; and interpreting the laws and applying them is what the third arm of government does. Conciliation and mediation is a central means by which that is performed, and we are starving that section. People in community legal centres are desperate for funds. I freely acknowledge the situation in Victoria, but the situation down there is getting so bad that it can no longer be tolerated and the whole system looks like toppling over.

BREAK.PARA: If we are not going to provide proper assistance for people to go to court—I take up what Senator Harradine and Senator Forshaw have said—surely we can at least help people take a course in mediation and conciliation, which is cheaper than going to court. I just think we are giving the wrong signals if we start charging people for a service that can do so much socially, economically and more for people.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a successful service.

—Especially when it is a successful service, it just seems to be wrongly headed. It seems to be not looking in a broad way at what is needed and what the community is entitled to have from legislators like us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply, I will clarify something I said for the advantage of the Minister for Justice (Senator Vanstone), because I think she said that she did not hear that part of my speech. At the outset I quoted from the 1996-97 annual report. I quoted statistics which related to the number of counselling cases dealt with in person by the service, the number of crisis calls, the number of counselling cases and the number of interviews. Then I said:

SPEECH.PARA: As many as 47.1 per cent of cases came to the service on a voluntary basis. This is down on the almost 60 per cent figure in the 1995-96 financial year. In all, 18.6 per cent of the cases were referred by the court for counselling after an application for a parenting order in relation to residence, contact or specific issues was filed but prior to the matter first coming to court. A further 28.7 per cent were referred by the court after the first directions hearing.

That is precisely what I said. I then went on and, as Senator Harradine quite correctly noted, referred to the advice provided at the estimates hearing and since the estimates hearing by way of letter dated 20 November 1997 from the Family Court of Australia's chief executive officer. As Senator Harradine quoted, in that letter the statistics were 9.9 per cent in relation to the reduction in the number of voluntary cases from June to September; in the same period, a substantial increase of 29 per cent in court ordered counselling before the first directions hearing; and 20.5 per cent after the first directions hearing.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's since the fees came in.
—Since the fees came in. So, Minister, just to put your mind at ease, at no stage was I seeking to either misinterpret or mislead the Senate on the figures that I quoted.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vanstone interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a suggestion that you had not heard it but you thought you had better go away and check. I will jump up and defend precisely what I said; it is here in writing if you want to have a look. The other point I made at the outset was that originally it was intended to come in on 1 January.

SPEECH.PARA: I will make just a couple of other quick comments. You stated, Minister, that the previous government had considered fees. Again, I did actually deal with that in my remarks. I referred to the fact that this issue had been foreshadowed in the 1995-96 budget statements. There was a review of court and tribunal fees initiated by the previous Labor government. However, as is quite clear, the previous government rejected the introduction of fees for these specific services.

I do not think I need to respond to anything else. I think it has been adequately dealt with by the remarks of Senator Murray, Senator Harradine and Senator Cooney. I make the final point—as has been said I think by all the speakers in support of the motion—that this is ultimately about what is good public policy. It is about ensuring that those who wish to voluntarily access the service can do so free of cost or of charge that in many cases is an impost upon them at a most inappropriate time.

At the end of the day, the statistics show that that service very often leads to successful outcomes. That may be successful outcomes in the prevention of contentious litigation or in reconciliation or in establishing sensible and appropriate outcomes for the custody of and other arrangements for children. All of that, at the end of the day, is something that is in the interest of the community and in the interest of the economy. Frankly, to resort to the arguments of black holes and budget deficits only really is no support for the measure that was contemplated here, given the obvious social and economic benefits that the service currently provides.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Forshaw's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with section 5 of the Parliament Act 1974 , the Senate approves the proposal by the National Capital Authority, on behalf of the Domestic Property Group, to lower the parapets on the Administrative Building.

I want to put a couple of things on the record about the controversial parapet proposal, which A Current Affair seems to have taken an interest in. I congratulate Senator Faulkner, a member of the waste watch committee of which I was a member for six years. When I ran stories about the previous government's waste in relation to office space, I found that A Current Affair —

TALK.START.PARA: —A waste of space, it was.

—Yes, a waste of space—or space waste, as it was called. A Current Affair always took an active interest in these matters. I encourage Senator Faulkner to weed out waste in the Commonwealth government where he can find it. But, although his intentions are absolutely impec cable in relation to this matter, I do not think he has stumbled up against any waste.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality with the Administrative Building is that both sides of this chamber recognise—the Australian Labor Party certainly did when it was in government—that the building does need to be refurbished, that it can be put to better use and that it can achieve an economic return as office space once it has been refurbished and brought up to a commercially occupiable level. Clearly, as part of that, repairs to and retrofitting of the building are required.

Anyone who bothers to go to look at the building will see that the removal of the parapets is absolutely essential to the repair, rectification and modification of the building to fit it out as a suitable modern office environment. This particular motion is seeking approval to remove these parapets, which is basically the bricking up of a number of windows. I am told that this removal work will allow light to come back into this section of office on the second top floor of the building and make it habitable office space.

The cost of removing the eight parapets—to correct the A Current Affair report—is actually $98,000. The tenders that have come in bring the cost of the work required to $98,000. On the advice I have had and from my own experience in office leasing I know very well that if you do not remove these bricks you are affecting the value of the property.

TALK.START.PARA: —What—Commonwealth to Commonwealth?

—Senator Ray knows a lot about a lot of things but he does not know much about this. What he should realise is that when you have a piece of office space, whether it is owned by the Commonwealth and leased to the Commonwealth, or owned by the Commonwealth and leased to someone else, or owned by someone else and leased to the Commonwealth, there is a value involved.
—Yes.
—Senator Ray, if the Commonwealth owned the building and leased it to someone else it would have a rental value. If it does not have that rental value it has an opportunity cost.
—Tell us about the 15 per cent social opportunity cost.
—Senator Ray, when you find some waste in relation to office space and show us a case where we waste money, you tell us and we will fix it. This is not one of them.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the A Current Affair story, one of the things they did when they ran our space waste stories was that they always got the Minister for Administrative Services on to give the alternative point of view—they always had Senator McMullan, when he was Minister for Administrative Services, and even Frank Walker once. But when the minister, Senator Nick Minchin, offered to brief A Current Affair and put the government's point of view the program took absolutely no interest whatsoever.

I noticed when I was watching that program last Thursday night that they said that the parliament had approved this money. Again, they did not pay any cognisance to the information the government had put to them. I can only say that they join with the Labor Party in supporting the fact that this money should not be spent. They want to make sure that the rental return on that space—the value—is not maximised. So to save $98,000 they would prefer to see the rental return rate on this property reduced to the tune of hundreds of thousands of dollars over the life of the building. That is the economic absurdity of what these people are proposing.

There is an analogy which even Ray Martin and possibly Senator Robert Ray may be able to draw on. This is the best way for people to understand the famous parapet issue. The analogy is: when you are going to buy a three‐bedroom house in your suburb, how would you value a house that had most of the windows bricked up to above eye level compared with a house that had windows that you could see out of and that let the light in? That is the comparison. Those blokes say, `Look, we have this building and in the interests of the Commonwealth let's knock down these parapets and let the light shine in.' Those opposite say, `No, don't spend that money'—even though the value of the house may improve massively because light can get back in through the windows, people can have their desks by the windows and actually see and it can be commercially viable office space again.

Senator Ray's lunatic economic assessment of this is that because it is a Commonwealth lease of a Commonwealth building you do not have to actually improve the rental value of it. He is saying to Commonwealth public servants who might go and work in that building, `Sorry, it is okay for everyone else in this building or any other Commonwealth building to have offices with windows where light can come in but, if you are going into this building, it is bad luck. You can work in a bricked‐up office—you can have your windows bricked up.'

What we should do for Senator Robert Ray so that he appreciates this issue is get the Parliament House services company to go around and brick up his windows—put a few parapets in his windows—and see how he likes it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'd like to open a window. You can't even open a window here.
—Senator Ray, if you think opening the windows is a good idea, you and I agree on that much.
—Have you seen the inside of the building?
—Yes, I have been inside the building.
—All right. When did you go?

—I went there when I was part of an inquiry into the whole Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade building. I do not know the exact date but it was when Peter Wilenski was there. So it was some time ago.
—You have not been there since the refurbishment?

—No, I have not. But I am fully aware of the issues. Firstly, this refurbishment was agreed to under the previous Labor government. Secondly, the $98,000 we are talking about to remove some layers of bricks from these parapets is 0.1 per cent of the total contract price of the refurbishment. It is something that anyone who has ever looked sideways at a building or spent a day in one knows makes a lot of commonsense. I am quite sure that had the Australian Labor Party been in power they would have proceeded with this full refurbishment to bring the building back to a habitable, sensible commercial state.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite clearly, the most important point is that not to spend this money would diminish the rental value of this building. Senator Faulkner is very well intentioned in trying to draw people's attention to any waste of Commonwealth moneys. As I said, if he can bring us a case where there is a waste of money—and not just a cheap political exercise—then we will take it seriously. But we cannot take him seriously when he draws attention to these sorts of matters.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a typical performance from Senator Campbell: attack the messenger. It has not been a good day for Senator Campbell, has it?
—Canberra bashing.

—I think we ought to get in order what he has managed to do today. He has been unable to advise the Senate of any reason why the Native Title Amendment Bill has not been brought before the chamber. It has been one of the weakest performances we have seen in the history of this place from a manager of government business—and Senator Bob Collins would know that that really is saying something—to try to explain it. It was a very weak performance in relation to the appalling situation we have on the important issue of the Native Title Amendment Bill debate and the incapacity of Senator Campbell to honour the commitment of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to bring that matter on for debate—
—I wanted to bring it on at 9.30 this morning and you said no.
—But you would not bring it on even at 12.30 this afternoon.
—I said to bring it on at 9.30 and you said no.
—That is not true and you know it. You would not bring it on for debate at 12.30 p.m. That is failure No. 1.

BREAK.PARA: We have had Senator Campbell exposed as a Canberra basher. This is the man who was delighted that, as a result of federal government policies, Canberra found itself in a recession. Eventually, as a result of the opposition exposing Senator Campbell, Senator Campbell was forced to apologise. Did he come into the Senate chamber and apologise himself? No. Of all people, he got poor old Senator Kemp, struggling, as we know, at question time, to come in and present the apology on his behalf. That was problem No. 2 for Senator Campbell today.

Problem No. 3 for Senator Campbell today is the fact that he has been exposed as a strong supporter of the Australian Democrats, if not a member of the Australian Democrats, earlier in his political career. It really does put the lie to all the attacks we have heard in the chamber over all the years from Senator Campbell about his political opponents in the Australian Democrats.

Now problem No. 4 for Senator Campbell on this most inauspicious day for him in his parliamentary career is that he is now proposing to have to defend on behalf of the government the government's plan to spend what we were told was $185,000 to adjust the parapets on one of Australia's most historic—certainly one of Canberra's most historic—public buildings just to provide apparently a more pleasant view for a few senior bureaucrats who will have to occupy that floor of the Administrative Building. What we say is that it is absolutely indefensible. It is a ridiculous proposition at a time when Australians are being punished by a raft of government decisions.

What does Senator Campbell do today? He comes in and says, `Look, there are a whole lot of reasons to do this.' It is a pity that, when the opposition asked for details about this particular proposal, those reasons did not appear. There is only one reason that appears in the official documentation attached to a minute to the minister which was received by the opposition. I quote directly from the document:

The works are considered necessary to improve the amenity of the 4th Floor of the building as the present height of the parapets currently obstructs the views to the north and south from substantial parts of the proposed office space floor area. The lack of amenity has caused concern with prospective tenants. This is the main reason given by the DPG—
that is, the Domestic Property Group—
for the current inability to find a tenant prepared to commit to a lease over the area.
That is what the official documentation of the government says. In the same official documentation, on the last page, under the subheading `Cost of works', it says:
The Domestic Property Group estimate the cost of the proposed works at $185,000.

Magically, that estimate has now changed. It is now, magically, a different reason why they want to remove two courses of stone. Let me explain the situation. There are two courses of stone around these parapets with a stone capping. The idea is to remove two courses and put the capping back on. We found these figures in the government's own official documents. We found the reasons, the argumentation in support of this particular proposal, in the government's own official documents.

What does Senator Campbell do? He comes in and attacks the messenger. He decided he would attack A Current Affair. He asked why A Current Affair did not ask the responsible minister, Senator Minchin. Possibly one reason is that Senator Minchin is not the responsible minister; it is Mr Fahey. Mr Fahey was asked by A Current Affair, and what did Mr Fahey do? He refused to give any information to A Current Affair. He absolutely refused to provide any comment because, in his own words, $185,000 of taxpayers' money was a trivial amount. But I do thank Mr Fahey, who invited me to go on an inspection of the building, which was a kind offer that I took up. I was accompanied by a member of Mr Fahey's staff. This might all be of interest to Senator Campbell, who knows nothing about the issue which we are talking about.

I went down and had a look. Do you know what I thought? I thought that $185,000 for what was proposed would, for example, cover a number of up‐front fees for elderly Australians to enter a nursing home. That is what I thought. When I inspected the site on Friday, I was not at all impressed by the new arguments that had been put forward by the government in the House of Representatives debate last week. I have seen the work area there, and the truth of the matter is that there is plenty of light pouring into it. Any attempt to use occupational health and safety reasons is just unacceptable; it is a nonsense. Is the government seriously maintaining that there are occupational health and safety questions involved? This is something that the Labor Party always takes seriously. Unlike this mob on the other side of the chamber, we care about these sorts of issues. If they have got any evidence, put it up. There is no evidence, and in the official documentation we have received none.

The same government that sacked 30,000 public servants in its first two budgets, purportedly to save money, is now proposing these completely cosmetic changes to a historic, heritage‐listed building in Canberra—an important building—just to improve the views.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't forget the bus shelter.

—Senator Ray raises the issue of the bus shelter. I am glad you did, Senator Ray, because that gives you an idea of the priorities of this government. What is the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet concentrating on? The big issues of the day; those particular issues that are causing the Howard government to unravel? No, he is putting all of his effort into communicating with—or heavying, really—the ACT administration to get them to remove the wall from the back of a bus shelter. Those are the priorities of the Howard government: changing the size of the parapet and removing the wall at the back of a bus shelter. That is where they can really get some action. They cannot fix the major political issues of day. Mr Moore‐Wilton may not be doing much of a job on any of the key issues but, yes, he can deliver the removal of the wall at the back of a bus shelter. That is his one achievement since he has been in that position.

BREAK.PARA: The government acknowledges not that the bus shelter should be refurbished but that the building should be refurbished. We accept that. Yes, this building needs refurbishment. No, we should not spend this extra amount of money just to improve the amenity. This is a loony scheme that the government is proposing. I would compare it to Mr Howard's proposal to bring the Speaker's chair from the old House of Representatives chamber into the new one. It is as loony as that particular proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —No—naming Treasury after Sir William McMahon, yes.

—Senator Ray, you obviously misheard the nuance of my contribution. I described it as being as loony as the House of Representatives Speaker's chair proposal; the Sir William McMahon building proposal is more loony. So I do not think that is a valid comparison to make.

BREAK.PARA: The Australian Heritage Commission, on whom governments depend for advice on these sorts of issues, has raised concerns with the government that the lowering of the parapets would adversely affect part of the national estate; that is, the architectural integrity of these buildings. We heard the government, in the House of Representatives, try to say, `Look, really those parapets were put around there for security concerns at the time ASIS occupied the top floor of the building.' Oh, really, is that right? Of course not; it is another furphy, another lie and another deliberate attempt to deceive us.

The truth of the matter is, as the Australian Heritage Commission have confirmed in their documentation—and, I am pleased to say, it was confirmed at the inspection on which I went with a member of Mr Fahey's staff on Friday of last week—that the parapets have been there since the building was built in the 1940s. That was the information I was given. I am sorry that a senior minister has misled the House of Representatives on that issue. No doubt an apology, such as the one Senator Campbell made today, will be forthcoming in the not too distant future.

This building previously housed the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, but it is being refurbished for the Department of Finance and Administration—DoFA. That particular department is going to occupy part of the building. This is the government department that is so keen to make all other government departments cut back their budgets. But, of course, under Mr Fahey, the minister responsible for finance, they splurge on themselves. The same principle does not apply to the Department of Finance and Administration itself.

The only reason that we are being asked to give this the tick is so a few senior bureaucrats sitting on the top floor of that building can see a few more treetops. That is what it is about. Well, the Labor Party will not have a bar of it. It is a waste of taxpayers' money. The government stands condemned, having had it exposed by the opposition.

There was criticism by A Current Affair—the unjustified criticism of journalists taking an interest in a matter like this. The government laugh off the issue of a waste of taxpayers' money as not being serious, but I reckon that ordinary Australians, whether it is $185,000 as the government once said it was or whether it is over $90,000 as they now say their estimate is—they got it wrong in the first place—would think that that sort of expenditure was unjustified on a matter like this.

No, we do not accept what the government says on this. No, we are not going to tick off on expenditure for these absolutely preposterous reasons. No, we do not support the motion before the Senate. But, yes, we do believe that Senator Campbell, having been struck out for the fourth time today, really ought to go around and have a look at whether he is in the right place at the right time doing the right job. It has been a very poor performance from Senator Campbell today on this and a range of other issues. He and the government stand condemned for what they are proposing.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Ian Campbell's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.
