SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook in his remarks also accused the government of undermining confidence in superannuation through the introduction of a surcharge. I have to say: I wonder what evidence Senator Cook had to make this assertion? Certainly, statistics produced by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission suggest that last year was, as they say, `a super year for super'. By the end of June 1997 superannuation assets had passed the $300 billion mark—in fact, Senator Cook, during the year, they were growing by almost $1 billion a week. Contributions, Senator Cook, also grew strongly during the year, rising by 12 per cent, with the strongest growth coming from member contributions, which increased by 17 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Allison noted in her speech that Democrat support for the surcharge had been on the basis that low and middle income earners would not pay the surcharge and that the government would consult on reducing administrative problems with the legislation when they arose. On the first issue, I have already noted that the Democrat amendments to the legislation will act to achieve this goal. I reiterate that collection rates of tax file numbers are currently in line with expectations at this stage of the process, and this is before the tax office undertakes the expensive and time consuming processes which resulted from the amendment moved in the Senate. On the second issue, a number of amendments to the bills are being made in response to industry concerns raised during the significant consultation both the government and the ATO had with the industry.

I do not think Senator Conroy raised any new issues in his remarks. I think he quoted at some length the responses given by the government and officials at the Senate select committee hearings, although he was conspicuous by his absence at those hearings. Senator Cooney suggested that the bills undermined the security of tenure of judges. The government does not agree with this proposition. Current judges are exempt from the surcharge because, under the constitution, their remuneration cannot be reduced. However, as the constitutional protection does not apply to newly appointed judges, they will be subject to the surcharge like all Australians. Applying general measures equally to judges does not offend the principle of judicial independence.

In his contribution to the debate, Senator Quirke commented that elements of this package of legislation would favour Commonwealth employees and parliamentarians over their state counterparts. I note for the information of Senator Quirke that the government has already indicated that it will be moving an amendment which will address any such perception on this issue. I would urge senators, if they believe strongly in the question of equity, as I assume most senators do, to support this legislation and its passage through the Senate.

One comment from the opposition which I thought was of particular interest was that of Senator Evans, who has just returned to the chamber. If I am summarising his views correctly, he said that the Labor Party would keep the surcharge but would look at alternative ways of collecting it. I interpreted that from your speech, Senator Evans, and I am looking straight at you. Are you agreeing or disagreeing?

TALK.START.PARA: —I was suggesting there was a course that the government ought to follow at this juncture.
—So the Labor Party is not proposing to keep the surcharge.
—I do not speak for the opposition. I am not the official spokesman.

—I think that will be of interest. I have to tell you, Senator, that your party looked with great effort at finding an alternative collection mechanism. In fact, right up until the last moment the Labor Party was going to move some amendments in relation to an alternative collection mechanism. In the end I think they wisely decided—for reasons which were not stated but I assume for reasons of which we were aware—that this mechanism would be impossibly complex. So those amendments were not ultimately moved. I will restate those lines in your speech, Senator, because when I read them I thought they were quite significant.
—I am glad to see that you are hanging on my every word, Senator Kemp.

—No, I am just saying that if they have been misinterpreted, we note your comments. Equity is important. As senators would know, it has surprised me that there has been a vigorous debate on this issue, but ultimately the Labor Party opposed the imposition of the surcharge. For a party which highlights as one of its key values the value of equity, I have to say that that came as a surprise not only to me but also to many Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans referred to correspondence of the Select Committee on Superannuation from the Institute of Actuaries which suggested that it was not possible to apply the surcharge equitably to defined benefit funds. Firstly, the government disagrees with the assertion that its intention that no member of a defined benefits scheme pay the surcharge of more than 15 per cent cannot be achieved with the current legislation. Advice to the government is that the trustees are the appropriate people who have responsibility for ensuring that the surcharge is applied equitably to members of defined benefit funds.
I would also like to place on record that the Institute of Actuaries has been working with the government throughout this process. In particular, on 29 July 1997 the institute advised the government:
It is appropriate that the standard for the calculation of an NSCR should be published by the government.
It went on to state:
The institute is of the view that a fairly prescriptive approach is appropriate.
In addition, it said:
The institute supports this approach as appropriate in the circumstances and in line with our recommendations to the government in broad terms.

The institute wrote to me recently, following its earlier letter to the committee, saying that it recognises that there were some ambiguities in its letter to the committee. It has now stated that it is not claiming that it is impossible to introduce a surcharge. The institute has also acknowledged that it has been extensively consulted during the whole process.

I repeat that the measures in these bills improve the equity and efficiency of the operation of the surcharge. Many of the measures in this bill arose from comments by stakeholders and industry, so the bill in itself represents the end product of a high degree of consultation.

The debate on these bills has been delayed for too long. We had been anxious, as I think senators will attest, to have this debate earlier. For reasons which people in the chamber will know, this unfortunately was not possible. It is time that we enacted the measures in this bill. As I have said, they resulted from consultations with industry. We believe that these bills are an important equity measure. In this context, it is important both for the sake of the industry and for the sake of ensuring greater equity in our superannuation system that the legislation be passed as quickly as possible.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (1) clarifies that constitutionally protected superannuation funds must report to the commissioner the employer‐financed component of benefits that accrued after 20 August 1996 for a member when a lump sum or pension becomes payable to the member.

Amendment (2) replaces the 15 per cent cap for the surcharge liability with a cap consistent with that which applies to superannuation schemes operated by the Commonwealth. The amendment provides that the cap for constitutionally protected superannuation funds is 15 per cent of the employer‐financed component of that part of the benefits payable to the member that accrued after 20 August. Amendment (2) follows consultation with the states. We believe that, in responding to those requests, we have been able to meet some of the concerns that the states have put to us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will be supporting both these amendments to the Superannuation Contributions Tax (Members of Constitutionally Protected Superannuation Funds) Assessment and Collection Bill 1997 . I would like to say a few words about the government amendment concerning the 15 per cent cap on state constitutionally protected funds. Labor will be supporting this amendment. The amendment relates to the 15 per cent cap which these amended bills appear to apply to some undefined benefit schemes, particularly Commonwealth superannuation schemes and some state superannuation schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: Specifically, two of the amended bills in this package, the Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Superannuation Contributions Tax) Bill 1997 and the Superannuation Contributions Tax (Members of Constitutionally Protected Superannuation Funds) Assessment and Collection Bill 1997, impose a 15 per cent cap on the surcharge tax liability which a fund member is liable to pay. However, the wording used to apply the 15 per cent cap in the two bills is quite different, and it is unclear whether there is an inconsistency in the operation of the cap between the Commonwealth schemes and the state schemes.

In the Commonwealth schemes, the 15 per cent cap seems to apply to the surcharge tax liability which is accrued after 20 August 1996, which was when this measure was announced. In other words, a member will not have their superannuation benefits reduced by a surcharge tax liability of more than 15 per cent of the employer financed component of that part of the benefit accrued after 20 August 1996.

The 15 per cent cap in the state superannuation schemes affected by these amendment bills appears to operate in a different way, which may still see the cap apply, but to benefits accrued both before and after 20 August 1997. This amendment will apply the 15 per cent surcharge tax liability cap to those benefits accrued in a constitutionally protected superannuation scheme after 20 August 1997.

While this amendment does provide some consistency in the 15 per cent cap to the Commonwealth and state defined benefit schemes, it is still quite noticeable that the cap does not apply to all funds, and we will be interested in asking the government why this is the case. However, we will be supporting this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quirke, Sen John

It was put to me that Commonwealth persons in these particular defined schemes were given an explicit legislative protection which indicated that they would not be subjected to the surcharge, or any part of the surcharge, before 20 August 1996 which, as I understand, was budget night and when this was announced.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments that were circulated earlier today are, if I remember rightly, amendments to clause 12 of the first bill. The original concerns that I raised were about the protections in clause 15. I accept, as the minister tells me, that these persons have nothing to fear and everybody is going to be treated equally in all of the states as well as the Commonwealth, so that particular issue has been put to rest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

We were going to move on that anyway, but we graciously note that you raised that issue. The wording in the bills will be the same and the effect of them will be the same.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment will defer the application of the surcharge tax to allocated surplus amounts until after 1 July 1997. I also foreshadow further Labor amendments to allocate surplus reserve measures, which will make the measure simpler and still achieve the government's policy objectives.

Senators should note that this is an amended version of that originally circulated, which would have seen the allocated surplus tax apply from 1 July next year. After discussions with the Australian Democrats and the government, we agree that it would be better to begin the measure in the 1997‐98 financial year.

The Superannuation Contributions and Termination Payments Taxes Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 introduces a requirement into the Superannuation Contributions Tax (Assessment and Collection) Act 1997 for accumulated benefits superannuation funds to report contributions which are made to a member from allocated surplus reserves. I wish to stress that this is a new requirement, introduced by these amendment bills, which is supposed to operate retrospectively from 20 August last year. Until now superannuation funds and fund members did not have this liability to meet. I understand that the government claims that this measure is designed as an anti‐avoidance measure which will stop certain superannuation funds from avoiding paying the superannuation surcharge contributions tax by going on a contributions holiday.

If that is the intention of the government's proposed amendment, we support that in principle because we believe that some high income earners should not be able to avoid tax by virtue of being in a certain type of fund. However, we believe that the way this measure has been designed not only puts an additional complicating burden on superannuation funds by requiring, for the first time, accumulated funds to use the services of an actuary, but also will unnecessarily increase compliance costs, which will be passed on to low and middle income earners. In addition, the design of this measure will tax superannuation fund earnings, even though this is supposed to be a tax on contributions and it could also be a double taxation burden.
On top of all of this, it will apply retrospectively to 20 August 1996, over 15 months since the government first announced its superannuation tax measure.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 7.30 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —When we broke for dinner I was in the middle of persuading the Senate to vote for my amendment concerning allocated surplus reserves and had made the point that we believe the measure, as presented by the government, puts an additional complicating burden on superannuation funds by, in many cases, requiring them for the first time to use the services of an actuary and as well to unnecessarily increase compliance costs which would be passed on to low and middle income earners. I was saying that, in addition, the design of this measure will tax superannuation fund earnings even though this was supposed to be a tax on contributions—and it could have a double taxation burden.

SPEECH.PARA: On top of all of that it will apply retrospectively from 20 August 1996, over 15 months after the government first announced its super tax measure. Labor believes that this measure is more than just a taxation avoidance measure; we believe it is an attempt by the government to grab more revenue by trying to sneak an additional tax past us again—a tax on fund earnings. We are not going to let that happen. Labor's amendment is designed to apply the tax on allocated surplus reserves from 1 July 1997 with further foreshadowed amendments to apply a simpler anti‐avoidance measure from the same date. This will make things simpler for funds to administer. It will be less retrospective and more reasonable given the long period of time which has passed. It is also designed to reduce the compliance costs on superannuation funds and also to stop the double taxation of contributions.

I have to say that many accumulation type funds have what are called investment fluctuation reserves which are built up in the years in which there are high investment earnings. In those years, when the fund earns well, the trustees do not credit the whole of the investment earnings to the members' accounts. Rather, some of those investment earnings are set aside in the investment fluctuation reserve or what the government has called allocated surplus reserves. Then, in years that the returns to the fund are not so high, trustees transfer amounts out of the allocated surplus reserve into members' accounts. That is what this amendment bill, if allowed to pass unamended, will tax: the transfers out of the investment fluctuation reserves into members' accounts for high income earners or for others who do not supply their tax file numbers.

In evidence to the Senate superannuation committee, Mr Ray Stevens from William M. Mercer recommended that this measure if introduced apply from 1 July 1997, which would reduce the retrospectivity and allow time to sort out and publicise what is really meant by the measure and how it would be administered. He went on to give his reasons for that recommendation:

Otherwise, I believe we will have chaos and delays with returns for 1996‐97 for accumulation funds, and an ongoing reaction from members and former members who are advised they now have a new tax liability they were not previously advised of.

It is fair and reasonable that this measure apply from the 1997‐98 financial year rather than applying from 20 August 1996 when superannuation funds did not know, until the draft amendment bills were produced, that they would have to meet this burden. With those words, I commend my amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to indicate the Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be handy if we could get an indication on these other amendments. If we can avoid divisions in this area it will be of assistance. That may not apply on this amendment. The amendment proposed by Senator Cook was to defer, including for allocated surplus amounts, the surcharge contributions until 1 July 1997. As Senator Cook said, representations have been made suggesting that the allocated surplus amounts in the accumulation funds should be included in surchargeable contributions so people do not enter into behaviour to avoid the surcharge. Such amounts are surchargeable contributions, as defined benefit funds. This measure is an anti‐avoidance measure. This was alluded to by Senator Cook.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has reflected on this issue in the last couple of days and has had discussions. The government will not resist this amendment as it will take allocated surplus amounts out of the amounts thatmust be reported on 15 December and, therefore, relieve some pressure on that date. So the government will not be resisting this amendment.
I might point out, however, that because this amendment will now get through there are some consequential amendments which will have to be moved, including to the bill

BREAK.PARA: which has just gone through the committee stage. I might seek further advice—and the opposition might. It seems to me that a number of those amendments, if they go through, are not complete in the sense that there will have to be other amendments moved elsewhere. We are not interested in delaying the proceedings but it may be worth taking that on note. Perhaps, before we close this committee stage, we could have consultations to see how we can clear up those problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I thank the government. I am not quite sure what your words were, Senator Kemp. You said you will not oppose the amendment which I take to mean that the chamber will therefore carry this amendment, with you remaining silent. I appreciate the point about the consequential impact that this will have in other areas of the six bills that are before us and that we are debating cognately. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TAB.TAB: (iii) subject to subsection (2A), are specified roll‐over amounts that constitute amounts accrued after 20 August 1996 that are eligible termination payments under paragraph (a) of the definition of eligible termination payment in section 27A(1) of that Act; and

BREAK.PARA: (3) Schedule 4, page 8 (after line 32), after item 6, insert:

PARA.TAB: Insert:

(2A) If an eligible termination payment within the meaning of subparagraph (2)(c)(iii) has been made or is made to or for a taxpayer after 20 August 1996 and before 20 August 2001, surcharge is payable only on the part of the eligible termination payment that is worked out using the formula:

BREAK.PARA: Post ‐ 20 August 1996 period X Eligible termination payment Total period
where:
post‐20 August 1996 period means the number of days in the period of the taxpayer's employment for which the eligible termination payment was made that occurred after 20 August 1996.
total period means the number of days in the period of the taxpayer's employment for which the eligible termination payment was made.

These amendments would be colloquially known as the golden handshake amendments. The purpose of these amendments relates to inconsistencies in the surcharge tax treatment of eligible termination payments financed by an employer—payments that are known as golden handshakes—when taken as cash or when rolled over into a superannuation account.

This issue has been raised by Labor in several forums and was the subject of a submission to the recent hearing of the Select Committee on Superannuation looking into these bills. When a golden handshake is paid to an employee by an employer, that employee may choose to take that payment in cash or may choose to roll it over into a superannuation account. If an employee takes the golden handshake in cash, only the post-20 August component of the payment is subject to the surcharge tax. Of course, the payment itself is subject to a range of other taxes which an employee would have to consider when deciding how to take the payment.

However, if the employee chooses to roll his or her golden handshake payment into a superannuation account, the entire payment—that is, the pre- and post‐20 August component—is subject to the surcharge tax. This is clearly an inconsistency in our view which the government should have fixed itself. It is also an unfair measure in that it is a retrospective tax on benefits already accrued, something which should send alarm bells ringing amongst all the other senators in this chamber.

However, the government has exercised a sleight of hand in implementing this inconsistency. The press release of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) of 20 August 1996 did not mention anything about there being a different surcharge tax treatment depending on whether the golden handshake is taken as cash or whether it is rolled over. For example, the Treasurer's 20 August 1996 press release, in describing the surcharge tax, stated:

These changes are entirely prospective and do not impact in any way on already accumulated superannuation benefits . . . or `golden handshake' . . . with respect to service before today's announcement.
The press release went on to say:

This surcharge will not affect people already in retirement nor will it affect already accrued superannuation benefits, including all past contributions and earnings on those contributions. Further, it will not affect benefits paid under an unfunded or constitutionally protected scheme or `golden handshake' with respect to service—

before the budget announcement. However, by 5 February 1997 the Treasurer had changed his mind. In the Treasurer's press release issued on that day, the government announced that it would be treating golden handshakes differently in that they would be subject to a five-year transitional period. That meant that golden handshakes received after 20 August 2001 would be fully subject to the surcharge tax—that is, the post-20 August 1996 component and the pre-20 August 1996 component.

Now, of course, the government is entitled to change its mind about the way it treats golden handshakes. In fact, we expect this government to change their mind because they are becoming known as the government by press release: they announce a policy measure, realise after the event how wrong they have got it, then change it by issuing a press release. However, on this occasion they have not fixed the matter up. The announced five-year transition period for golden handshakes does not fix the inconsistent tax treatment when a golden handshake payment is taken in cash or is rolled over. These are important consequences for Australia's national savings levels.

As Noel Davis, superannuation lawyer with Clayton Utz, has pointed out—that is the law company of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard)—this measure will impact on the superannuation system and our country's national savings. Davis said of the inconsistency:
It will encourage people to take the money out of super, which does nothing to encourage long-term savings.

This government has shown that it does not have much regard for national savings. If it did, it would not have abandoned Labor's three plus three superannuation contribution scheme, which would have added some $3.7 billion to Australia's national savings. But it did abandon Labor's measure and in its place it introduced a savings rebate which will benefit mainly high income earners at the expense of low and middle income earners and, as Treasury officials admitted in Senate estimates committee hearings, will do little to assist national savings levels. So it comes as little surprise that this government has given little regard to the impact its surcharge tax measure will have on national savings.

Many people have been affected by this anomaly. The Senate superannuation committee heard evidence from Mr Bruce Harris who, acting on the advice in the government's press release of 20 August 1996, rolled his golden handshake into a superannuation fund. Much to Mr Harris's dismay, when the surcharge tax bill came into force on 5 June this year, he discovered that his decision at the time, made with knowledge based on the Treasurer's press releases, would actually see him paying more total tax than if he had taken the payment in cash. This is a particularly galling issue for Mr Harris because he has worked in the superannuation industry for some 10 years and considered that he knew it and its rules and regulations quite well.

That leads us to assume that, if this happened to Mr Harris and indeed several other superannuation experts who we know have been affected by this measure, there can be no doubt that many other people who may not have such in-depth knowledge of superannuation will also be affected. Here, again, like the many low and middle income earners who will have to unnecessarily pay the surcharge tax, we have another group of people who have been disadvantaged by this shambles of a measure. But what the inconsistent treatment of golden handshakes means is that it is more tax effective to take a golden handshake as cash rather than rolling it over into a superannuation system. This has potentially devastating consequences for superannuation as a savings vehicle.

That particularly disappoints Labor, given the efforts and successes we have had in building up superannuation as a savings vehicle which greatly contributes to achieving Australia's economic goals while contributing to building better retirement incomes for all Australians. Our amendments simply ensure that golden handshake payments are treated on an equal footing regardless of whether they are taken as cash or rolled over into a superannuation account. I commend these amendments to senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting amendments 2 and 3 from the opposition. They are essentially the same as our amend ment No. 1, which I will not put if this proceeds. These amendments seek to ensure that eligible termination payments are treated in the same way whether or not they are rolled over.

SPEECH.PARA: When this tax was introduced back in August 1996, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) made it very clear that it would not apply to eligible termination payments which had accrued prior to budget night. But, as we all know, when the legislation was drafted this was only really the case if the ETP was cashed out and, if rolled over, the whole amount became taxable. These amendments correct this anomaly by making it clear that only the amount rolled over after 20 August will be taxed, thereby avoiding the retrospective taxation implicit in the government's approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to what the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats said on this matter just now, and prior to that I have had a good look at it. When this measure came to the chamber before, I opposed it, as senators would probably recall, but it was passed into legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill is to sort out a few problems and to impose the surcharge on members of constitutionally protected superannuation funds. I will be very interested to hear what the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) has to say about the matter, because I am inclined to support the amendments that have been moved by Senator Cook.

On the principle as stated by Senator Cook, I cannot see any reason under these circumstances for dealing differently with the types of golden handshakes that have been referred to by Senator Cook. Therefore, I am inclined to support his amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I do not know whether the Greens will be taking part in this debate but it would certainly speed the journey if we could get an indication of how they plan to vote on particular items.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to Senator Cook's comments on national savings, national savings collapsed under the Labor government and national savings were plundered by the massive deficits which the Keating government ran. There is no argument with that. One of the ways we have been able to repair national savings is by returning the Commonwealth budget to a surplus. So Senator Cook lecturing on national savings is a little out of court, to be quite frank.

Senator Cook mentioned the Labor Party proposal—the co-contribution, the three plus three. My understanding is Labor has dropped that scheme. Former Senator Evans, if I recall correctly—and if what I am saying is incorrect perhaps a Labor member can indicate it—has indicated that it is unlikely that the Labor Party would proceed with that program and that the unions have lost a degree of enthusiasm for it. So that scheme, which followed the l-a-w tax cuts, was never able to be implemented and my understanding is that the Labor Party has dropped it. So it adds little to the debate to raise that in this context.

The amendments moved by Senator Cook will add pressure to the ability of funds to meet the reporting date. Funds will be required to calculate the post 20 August 1996 component of golden handshakes rolled over so they can report the appropriate amount to the commissioner by 15 December. Such a change in the reporting requirements at this late stage of the proceedings, frankly, may cause confusion about what has to be reported.

The amendments treat golden handshakes rolled over consistently with those taken in cash. Golden handshakes rolled over are essentially the same as employer contributions to a superannuation fund and therefore should be treated the same as an employer contribution to a superannuation fund.

The amendments will encourage employers to defer superannuation contributions until retirement and give an employee a golden handshake at that time. In contrast to what Senator Cook said, this could impact on the amount of money going into the superannuation system.

Also, the amendments will cause complaints from people who took golden handshakes in cash after the surcharge legislation was introduced, because they made a choice—they preferred cash rather than the superannuation implications of rolling over. These people may well feel that they have been unfairly treated. From the government's perspective, these amendments are preferable to the Democrat amendment because they recognise the five-year transitional rule for golden handshakes taken in cash. We will be opposing the amendments. If we could hear what the Greens are going to say, that would decide whether we will call a division or not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to put the matter into perspective: as the government will recall, in May 1997 I moved an amendment that would have had pensions and annuities excluded from the surcharge. I remind the chamber that the government and the Democrats at that stage did not support the amendment. It was your government that suggested that my amendment was actually discriminating between funds, as members of certain funds only would be excluded. The amendment was defeated. I am not arguing that point again here and I do not intend to place any further amendments before the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: But on this particular matter I think Senator Cook has made out a very good case for treating the payments consistently. To do what the government is proposing, I believe, is an inconsistent approach to the subject. With respect, the excuse that was suggested that perhaps some people have taken one form of payment in the expectation it will not have the same tax treatment as another is no argument to be taken on board for all future decisions that might take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) will support ALP amendments 2 and 3.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not call a division; I recognise the numbers. The government opposes these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not move our amendment No. 1. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 4, page 9 (after line 26), after item 9, insert:
Insert:

PARA.TAB: (2A) The notification date for the 1996‐97 financial year in respect of defined benefits superannuation schemes is to be no earlier than 15 February 1998.

SPEECH.PARA: This is probably the most important amendment that we will be moving. It seeks to extend the reporting date for the 1996-97 financial year by two months. All superannuation funds have reported great difficulty in meeting the reporting deadline. No doubt we have all had a great number of letters on this subject. The problem is particularly acute for defined benefit funds, which are required to complete at what are at times very complex actuarial investigations, particularly if their scheme has more than one benefit design, prior to 15 December.

It should be pointed out that the legislation passed in May technically failed to require defined benefits funds to report, with the result that many trustees have not commenced the work of complying with the reporting requirements because they are not legally compelled or even allowed to do so. While the ATO has indicated that it will be lenient with funds facing genuine problems, I think it would be very poor policy in this first year to set an unreasonable deadline and ask the funds to comply. My concern is that the government will not be as lenient as it should be, because of the desire to collect the revenue in this financial year. We do not really care if the revenue in respect of 1996-97 slips into being paid in the first few months of the next financial year.

This amendment will give the funds an extra two months to report. It does not mean that they will pay less tax; it merely means that they have a little more time to comply with the legislation. The amendment allows funds to report early. I am sure that many funds will have completed their work and would prefer to get the reporting out of the way so that the tax office can proceed with its data matching. But I think it is unreasonable to require Australia's 15,000 defined benefits funds to complete their work in the 15 working days left to 15 December when there are only 150 actuaries in Australia capable of doing the work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out for the information of the Senate that the government has already extended the reporting date from 31 August to 15 December. These bills give the commissioner the discretion to extend the reporting date where the circumstances warrant it. Where there is a particular problem and these circumstances are brought to the attention of the commissioner, these bills give him the discretion to extend that reporting date. The Senate should be aware of that.

SPEECH.PARA: The accumulation funds are required to report by 15 December. Delaying the reporting for defined benefit funds will create a significant inequity for members of accumulation funds compared with members of defined benefit funds and may impact on the revenue, as was conceded. It also means that accumulation funds are likely to incur extra administrative costs. Accumulation funds that have allocated surpluses will have to report again once the amendments are passed. Also, if an assessment has been issued to an accumulation fund, the ATO may find it necessary to issue amended assessments to account for additional member contributions reported at a later date by defined benefit funds. People can be members of both accumulation and defined benefit funds.

If all funds do not report by 15 December, those funds that have both accumulation and defined benefit members will incur additional costs by having to report the surcharge information twice. We do not agree with the amendment, and I point out to the Senate that these bills give the commissioner the discretion to extend the reporting date when the circumstances warrant it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will not be supporting this Democrat amendment. Although this is not our main argument, we note that extending the reporting deadline for all funds will create revenue problems for the government. The ATO will have less time to process information received from funds and to calculate the surcharge tax liability.

BREAK.PARA: However, when this Superannuation Contributions and Termination Payments Taxes Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 was last before the Senate, the date for the deadline was 15 October. With the support of the chamber, we moved an amendment which changed that to the date that now appears—15 December. Sooner or later, there has to be an end time when you draw the bottom line across this and say, `That is the date.'

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be an end time.
—I am afraid that will come to all of us. It is probably the one unanswered question we do not know about life. This must be Monday night and we are getting philosophical, Senator Harradine.

BREAK.PARA: However, the point I make as to why it is reasonable to insist on the current provision is that the tax commissioner has the discretion to extend the reporting deadline on an individual basis. While there is evidence that many of the defined benefit funds will not be able to meet the 15 December deadline, where that is the case they can seek, and hopefully obtain, an extension of time from the commissioner. Provided the commissioner grants extensions on a needs basis, there is no need then to seek a blanket extension that applies to everyone. It is for those reasons that we do not, on this occasion, support the amendment from the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) believe that the deadline for reporting for defined benefit funds could well be pushed out to 15 February 1998 for the first year. This would recognise that these funds have a harder time getting their results in as a group because they need actuarial calculations instead of using hard information. The actuaries have really only recently devised anything like an appropriate system. In fact, the actuarial guidelines are still being questioned, as late as this debate. It does seem unreasonable to expect reportage on the results of methods that are yet to be determined. Obviously, they are working in somewhat of a mess and trying desperately to unravel what they are doing. I see that the minister is shaking his head—he obviously thinks it is all very clear. However, I can count as well, so it looks like we are on a lost cause. But I think the message is that there are still problems, even if the minister does not believe there are.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Schedule 4, item 14, page 10 (line 16), after "regulations", insert ", provided that the regulations must not impose requirements on a provider with which the provider cannot readily comply".
(4) Schedule 4, item 15, page 10 (line 21), after "regulations", insert ", provided that the regulations must not impose requirements on a provider with which the provider cannot readily comply".
(5) Schedule 4, item 16, page 11 (line 8), after "regulations", insert ", provided that the regulations must not impose requirements on a provider with which the provider cannot readily comply".

These items have caused some concern amongst trustees that they will add significantly to the reporting requirements, and thereby compliance costs, because they will allow the commissioner to require any further additional matters by regulation.

The government says that this provision was requested by elements of the industry to deal with the situation where members' funds were rolled over from another fund, allowing the ATO to pursue the information from the appropriate fund. The single draft regulation that has been prepared confines itself to information which was readily accessible to the fund. On balance, I think the draft regulation is probably reasonable, but we are reluctant to approve a wide regulation making power to sustain a single reasonable regulation. Therefore, my amendment proposes to restrict the regulation making power to the current very reasonable circumstances; in other words, to information which is readily accessible by the fund. I commend the amendments to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —In reference to Democrat amendments Nos 3 to 5, I point out that the ATO seeks only information necessary for the effective and efficient operation of the surcharge legislation and regulation 12 of the superannuation contributions tax assessment and collection regulations. The legislation allows the commissioner to require further information, if necessary—I think that was alluded to by Senator Allison. The provision of the bill requiring a receiving provider to report certain information to a transferring provider was inserted at the request of the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The only information that will be required to be given under the regulations will be the superannuation fund member, the member account number, and the client identifier. This information should be readily accessible to the receiving provider. The regulations also provide that the information need be given only where it is requested by the transferring provider. We do not think these amendments are necessary, and the government will not be supporting them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Labor Party will not be supporting these three amendments. The items mentioned grant the power to make regulations in respect of the act which would require a superannuation fund to provide additional information to the tax commissioner for the financial years 1996‐97 and 1997‐98.

SPEECH.PARA: The provision allowing the Commissioner for Taxation to make regulations which allow the commissioner to seek more information could result in fewer people paying the surcharge tax as further information could clarify whether a person is liable for the superannuation tax. The fewer lower and middle income earners who pay this tax, the better. In that sense, the government's amendment is a good thing.

While it is possible that the commissioner's request for more information could place an additional burden on the superannuation funds, there is a legislative safeguard already in place to prevent that happening. That is, the regulations tabled in the Senate could or would be disallowed by the Senate if it chose to do so. The Senate may choose to do so if indeed the regulations are too onerous on funds. In other words, the Senate could scrutinise the regulations when they are tabled and agree to disallow them.

BREAK.PARA: Given the government's recent experience with Senate regulations on the early release of superannuation, they could be wise to seriously consider the implications of any regulations that they make. Consulting with the opposition, the Democrats, the Greens and the Independents prior to the introduction of regulations could result in better regulations being implemented in the first instance.

In addition, the Democrats' amendments include words which would be difficult to make a determination on, leading to further uncertainty with this whole measure. For example, who would determine whether a request for information was something with which the `provider cannot readily comply'? Would it be the Commissioner of Taxation determining whether a superannuation fund could agree with his own regulations? That would defeat the purpose of having the amendment there in the first place.
For these reasons, Labor will not be supporting these amendments. I point to the remarks I have made about the regulations and the disallowance possibilities that relate thereto.
Amendments not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 4, page 13 (after line 10), after item 22, insert:
Add:

PARA.TAB: (13) If the Commissioner calculates that the surcharge payable on a member's surchargeable contributions for a financial year would be $10 or less, the calculation is taken, for the purposes of this Act other than subsections (9) and (10) to be an assessment on which a nil amount of surcharge was due and payable.

TAB.TAB: Modified assessment

PARA.TAB: (14) Where a superannuation provider, after receiving an assessment from the Commissioner but before paying the surcharge, becomes aware of information which, if known to the Commissioner, would cause the Commissioner to modify the assessment, the superannuation provider may pay what the super annuation provider believes, in the circumstances, to be the modified amount and provide to the Commissioner the additional information together with the modified amount.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment was expressly requested by the industry. The funds face very substantial costs in calculating and processing their assessments and it is only reasonable that the tax collected should not be less than the cost of complying with the tax. We have therefore proposed a de minimis rule whereby if the tax payable in respect of an individual member in a year is less than $10 then the commissioner must make a nil assessment. This will see that funds are not required to develop elaborate paper trails to chase very small amounts of money.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) will support this Democrat amendment for compliance reduction. As has been mentioned, the amendment basically means that where tax payable is less than $10 the funds do not have to go to the trouble of collecting it and sending it to the ATO. Obviously there is a cost per unit issue here. The second section says that where information comes to the fund after an assessment has already been made the fund may make a revision to the assessment and submit that along with a modified surcharge tax amount. That is fine by the Greens (WA).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor will not support these amendments. We oppose them on two grounds. First, having a nil assessment of those surcharge liabilities determined to be $10 or less would mean that this amendment would be inconsistent with Australian Taxation Office provisions which give the commissioner the discretion to determine whether a tax liability is worth collecting.

SPEECH.PARA: The commissioner may make a decision not to collect a tax liability after considering a range of factors, including whether the cost of collecting the tax liability would be more than the liability itself. Given the widespread belief in the industry that the administration of this tax will cost more than the tax collects in revenue, the tax commissioner may choose to call the whole thing off in the first place, saving everyone a lot of work and confusion. Nevertheless, with that sort of discretion in place, having an inconsistent tax ruling for the surcharge tax from general income tax provisions is not a desirable situation. That is our first reason.

The second reason is that having superannuation funds act as the Taxation Office is also not a desirable situation. That is what the Democrats' amendment will, unfortunately, do. If a fund believes that there is information which, had the Australian Taxation Office known about it, it would have issued a different surcharge tax liability, then the Democrat amendment would give the superannuation fund the power to adjust the tax liability before the Australian Taxation Office has had a chance to adjust its assessment. This is not a precedent we would want to set in taxation policy and we will not be supporting this Democrat amendment because of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook got it broadly right so I do not wish to detain the Senate. I note that this is a suggestion for a de minimis rule. I point out that the surcharge, like other fiscal imposts, is subject to a threshold and, as with other taxing statutes, once the threshold is exceeded the impost applies. We will not be supporting the amendment moved by the Democrats.

PARA.TAB: Amendment not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 4, item 25, page 14 (after line 4), at the end of the item, add:

PARA.TAB: (4) Where an amount of advance instalment is to be paid under this section to the holder of the contributions, the Commissioner must make any such payments within 28 days of the assessment being made.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment seeks to insert into section 17 a requirement on the commissioner to refund any overpayment of advance payments of surcharge within 28 days. The industry, as senators would be well aware, is stridently opposed to advance payments. These are payments made on an estimate of the following year's liability rather than on actual contributions paid. If the commissioner subsequently finds that they are overpaid it is entirely reasonable to require a quick refund. The taxpayers' charter of rights sets a best practice benchmark of 28 days for repayment of overpayments and, given the nature of advance payments and the way they are calculated, this benchmark should be made compulsory for the ATO.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to Democrat amendment 7, advance instalment is required to be paid for the following year if there is a surcharge assessment for the current year. Advance instalment will be applied as a credit against the following year's surcharge liability. The following year's surcharge liability can only be determined when the commissioner calculates the member's adjusted taxable income for that year; that is, after the member has lodged an income tax return and funds have reported for that year. If no surcharge liability is calculated for the following year then the amount paid as an advance instalment will be immediately refunded in line with the performance requirements set out in the taxpayers' charter. So there is no need for this amendment, in our view, and therefore we will be opposing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition is attracted to this amendment although we do have some questions about it and our attraction is qualified to the extent that those questions are answered. This amendment says that overpayments of advance instalments should be refunded within 28 days of reassessment by the tax office.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not sure whether the Democrat amendment is entirely workable. Perhaps, through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, Senator Allison might wish to comment on this proposition: isn't it the case that the Australian Tax Office will not know that an advance instalment was too much when collected until the following year? That is my first question. The second question relates to the taxpayers' charter. Isn't it also the case that the taxpayers' charter requires the Australian Tax Office to be prompt in repayment anyway? Those are the considerations on my side in determining whether we actually support Senator Allison. I might say we do need to hear a little bit more about it but we are not at all opposed to this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —While Senator Allison is consulting, I reiterate the point on the role of the taxpayers' charter. If no surcharge is calculated for the following year, the amount paid as an advance will be immediately refunded in line with the performance requirements as set out in the taxpayers' charter. I do not know if that gives you any great comfort, but we think therefore that the amendment that has been moved by Senator Allison is unnecessary.

—In answer to the question raised, it is our understanding that this would be workable, given that the payments would have been made within 28 days of assessment. So presumably there is a time at which assessment is made and the payment would follow 28 days later.
—I indicate that the opposition will support this amendment.
—I would also like to indicate that the Greens (WA) will support this amendment.

—Could I ask the minister a question on this as far as the amendment is concerned. The question of advance instalments is one that has had a lot of things said about it and there is a lot of interest shown in it, I would think, in the funds area. The advance payment is required to be paid for the following year if an assessment is actually made for the current year. That is the situation, isn't it?
—Yes.

—The question then arises as to a refund of overpayments of the advance payment of the surcharge. What does the government see to be the obligation, under its legislation and amendment, on the Taxation Office? It is a question of whether the committee feels that is reasonable or not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —As soon as an assessment is made and if there is an amount to be refunded, it will be refunded, and the taxpayers' charter gives the standard of performance in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (8) Schedule 4, page 14 (after line 21), after item 28, insert:

PARA.TAB: Insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 19A Surcharge must not exceed 15% of benefit

TAB.TAB: Where a person is a member of a defined benefits superannuation scheme and the sum of the surcharge amounts paid by the member ( amount A ) exceeds 15% of the value of the superannuation benefit that would have been payable to the person if the surcharge amounts had not been deducted ( amount B ), the Commissioner must refund the person the difference between amount A and amount B.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is another important one. It requires that, where a member receives a defined benefit on retirement and the surcharge is paid and is found to be more than 15 per cent of the final benefit, the commissioner must fund the difference.

Throughout the debate on the surcharge, the government and the minister have gone to great pains to point out to us that it is not the government's intention to tax any person more than 25 per cent of their final benefit. We have been assured that this is impossible time and time again. However, the Institute of Actuaries has written to the Superannuation Committee refuting this argument. They claim that, given that the notional surchargeable contributions are based on averaging principles, it is possible that some people will pay more than the 15 per cent of final benefit. The government's response is that the funds can pay this out of reserves or surpluses or other income, or the employer can make up the difference. But really the source of the revenue is not important; it is the fact that the surcharge would still be more than 15 per cent of the benefit.

That is why we have moved this amendment, because the government's argument we think simply does not add up. The argument that the trustees can raid any old hollow log to pay the surcharge does not detract from the fact that the government still requires the surcharge to be paid. There must be an evening‐up when the benefit is paid. I recognise that there are problems at the end, but let us fix the issues as they arise rather than say it is all too hard. This amendment is a step in the right direction again of making sure that the legislation matches the government's rhetoric.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will oppose this amendment but we do have a number of questions that we would like the government to answer on it.
—I was going to get up and say I thought it was eminently reasonable.
—You might well persuade me since you are speaking following me, Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment goes to another of the inconsistencies which exist as a result of this complex legislation. In this case, the inconsistency is that some defined benefit superannuation funds have a 15 per cent cap on the surcharged tax liability in respect of the benefit payable to the individual but others do not. This is an issue that was raised in the Senate superannuation committee and is yet to be answered by the government. I might say there are a lot of other questions that were raised in that committee on the surcharge tax issue which are also yet to be answered. However, in that committee, evidence given by Mr Ray Stevens of Mercer that putting a cap on all superannuation funds would only make the situation more complex and potentially less workable is, in our submission, notable.

While this Democrat amendment appears to apply only to defined benefit superannuation funds, it fits into the unworkable category. For example, how would the Commissioner of Taxation know `the value of the superannuation benefit that would have been payable to the person if the surcharge amounts had not been deducted'? This seems to make this measure more complicated rather than less complicated. For that reason, we will not support it.

BREAK.PARA: As I said, we do have a couple of questions. Perhaps I should ask you, Minister, to note down these questions and answer them. Firstly, there is a cap on Commonwealth funds and state constitutionally protected funds. Why is there a cap on those funds but not on other funds? Secondly, can you explain what steps an individual could take if they discovered that they had paid more than the 15 per cent in surcharge tax? Thirdly, what is the government's response to the letter from the Institute of Actuaries on this matter?

TALK.START.PARA: —We recognise that this is a difficult area but, nevertheless, we put this to the government and invited them to frame up an amendment to achieve our ends. As I understood it, the ALP has also, on numerous occasions, supported this as an outcome. It surprises me that we do not have ALP support. I would like to toss this back to the government and ask why it is that this is unworkable and why the amendment was drafted this way if that is case?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook, in relation to the letter from the Institute of Actuaries, I wrote off a detailed reply to the committee and to Senator Watson. We are getting a copy of that letter and I will seek to incorporate that letter in Hansard . I think it provides a detailed reply to the issues which were raised.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to this amendment, the Commonwealth public sector funds are generally defined benefit funds. The amending bill ensures that the defined benefit payable to a particular member of a Commonwealth public sector fund can be reduced to reflect the amount of the surcharge payable. The 15 per cent cap on the amount of surcharge payable by a member of a Commonwealth public sector fund allows the trustee of that fund to ensure the impact of the surcharge on a particular member is imposed equitably. The trustee is still liable to pay the full amount in the member's surcharge debt account.

The government is moving an amendment to ensure the 15 per cent cap on the amount of surcharge payable by members of constitutionally protected funds is the same as that which applies to that operated by the Commonwealth. A 15 per cent cap is not necessary where the liability is on the fund because the trustee of the fund is able to ensure that the impact of the surcharge on a particular member is imposed equitably. Senator Cook gave some of the evidence in relation to this matter before the committee. The trustee of a private sector superannuation fund could place a 15 per cent cap on the amount that could be drawn from a member's account to pay the surcharge. Before the Senate select committee, witnesses indicated it would be very difficult to apply a cap of this nature on private sector funds. With state funds, the imposition is on the member. With regard to the Commonwealth funds, the amendments are to the act under which the scheme is administered.

I think that covers the matters that you raised, Senator Cook. You asked for a response to the Institute of Actuaries letter. With the concurrence of the committee, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter addressed to Senator John Watson, chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, regarding the correspondence received by the committee from the Institute of Actuaries of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The documents read as follows—
ASSISTANT TREASURER
PARLIAMENT HOUSE
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Senator John Watson
Chairman
Select Committee on Superannuation
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear John

In response to your letter of 17 November 1997 on the correspondence received by the Committee from the Institute of Actuaries of Australia, I have sought the advice of the Australian Government Actuary. This letter reflects that advice.

In summary, the Government disagrees with the assertion that its intention that no member of a defined benefit scheme pay a surcharge of more than 15% cannot be achieved with the current legislation. While the letter may be misconstrued as raising issues which relate to the implementation arrangements for the surcharge as a whole, this interpretation would pay insufficient attention to the flexibility provided to trustees in dealing with implementation issues, particularly equity issues.

During the development of the taxation ruling (SCR97/1) which sets out how the NSCFs are to be determined this issue was discussed with actuaries. It was well understood that there would be cases where the equity of the surcharge would need to be dealt with. The question was whether this should be addressed in the determination of NSCFs (through notifiable events and such like as well as a more rather than less flexible calculation methodology) or whether it would be more effectively addressed in determining the application of the surcharge to benefits.

It was the advice of the actuaries to the Government Actuary and to the Government that the NSCFs should be more prescriptive rather than less so and that the treatment of equity in such cases should properly rest with trustees and the application to benefit alteration.

PARA.EMPHASIS: "Without specific attention, it is likely that some members would effectively pay the surcharge on benefits which they never receive. For example, in a scheme which provides relatively poor resignation benefits and generous retirement benefits, those who resign may have their benefit reduced by surcharge liabilities on contributions which actually benefit the other members who stay on to retirement." The advice went on to suggest "that fund trustees should take responsibility for ensuring that the surcharge is applied equitably in these circumstances."

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Francis' letter also relies on a particular interpretation of the SIS Act and of terms such as "fair" and "equitable". Clearly, there is scope for a range of views as to the precise application of these obligations by trustees. But it has been the advice to Government that it is trustees who are the appropriate people to undertake this responsibility and that trustees will be aware of their responsibility to ensure that the surcharge is applied equitably to members of defined benefit funds.
The regulation of a particular approach for the reduction of benefits would have the following problems.

. Such an approach would restrict trustees (and employers for single employer funds) in the manner of benefit alteration which could be administratively more complex than allowing greater flexibility.
. A prescribed approach would mean that members of some schemes could be burdened with greater difficulties in communicating the benefit impacts.
. Where schemes were to apply a prescribed approach it could be less equitable than if trustees were able to take into account the individual circumstances of schemes.
. Such an approach would lead to greater record keeping and administrative burdens for schemes where a simpler mechanism would be appropriate.

. Some schemes may choose to absorb the surcharge and not adjust benefits. Representations were received that this should be an allowable, but not compulsory, option. Many employers contributing to defined benefit funds took this route when the previous 15% contributions tax was introduced.

I stress, in contrast to an impression that may be given by the letter, that the Institute of Actuaries has been working with the Government and its advisers throughout the process. In particular, on 29 July 1997, the Institute advised the Government that "it is appropriate that the standard for the
calculation of an NSCR should be published by the Government". This letter went on to state that "the Institute is of the view that a fairly prescriptive approach is appropriate."
In addition, "The Institute supports this approach as appropriate in the circumstances and in line with our recommendations to the Government in broad terms."
A copy of the Institute's letter to all members is attached.
It remains our view that the surcharge can be applied in an equitable and workable manner. The Government has consulted widely. I thank you for the opportunity to restate the Government's view.
Yours sincerely
ROD KEMP
Institute of Actuaries of Australia
Superannuation Surcharge Update
Dear Member

The Institute has advised the Government that it is appropriate that the standard for the calculation of an NSCR should be published by the Government and it is expected that this will be finalised over the next two weeks.

The Institute continues to believe that a standard is necessary for this calculation, and has discussed the detail of the basis for the calculation with the Government officials. In addition, the Institute is of the view that a fairly prescriptive approach is appropriate.

The prescribed approach includes a specified funding method (generally Projected Unit Credit), economic assumptions and an objective methodology for determining decrement assump tions. This approach will provide objective certainty to the calculations.

It is expected that actuaries will apply the specified basis to individual scheme benefit designs. This process will not necessarily require an actuary to calculate individual NSCRs for each member, but rather that the normal approach would be to prepare a table of contribution rates (dependent, inter alia, on age and duration of membership) which could be applied by fund administrators from time to time.

The Institute supports this approach as appropriate in the circumstances and in line with our recommendations to the Government in broad terms. The Superannuation Practice Committee will meet on Tuesday 5 August with a view of making final comments to the Government on the draft methodology and any members with particular comments should contact the Chairman, Paul Francis.
Trevor Matthews
President
29 July 1997

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment was required by the industry, and it seeks to ensure that there is a complaints process for dealing with any disputes about the surcharge. Quite bizarrely, a superannuation provider has no right to object to any aspect of the assessment procedure.

A taxpayer may object to the Taxation Office and ombudsman against their calculations of taxable income, or to the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal against the trustee's calculation of contributions, but, if a superannuation provider—the person who actually pays the tax—has a problem, they have absolutely no recourse to complaint.

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Schedule 4, page 14 (after line 28), after item 29, insert:
Omit "the member may object", substitute "the member or a superannuation provider may object".

The purpose of this amendment is to allow the superannuation provider, as well as an individual fund member, to object to an assessment made by the Commissioner of Taxation in respect of the calculation of a member's adjustable taxable income.

Section 24 of the Superannuation Contributions Tax (Assessment and Collection) Act 1997 already contains measures which provide for an individual fund member to make an objection to an assessment of adjusted taxable income made by the Commissioner of Taxation. The opposition believes that it would be prudent to allow a superannuation provider to make an objection on behalf of a member in respect of the calculation of a member's adjustable taxable income.

It should be remembered that the surcharge tax is a tax incurred by the actions of an individual, a superannuation fund member, but payable by a third party, the superannuation fund. Therefore, a superannuation provider's liability to pay the surcharge tax is based on the Australian Taxation Office's assessment of an individual's adjusted taxable income for surcharge tax purposes.

If an individual's adjusted taxable income is above the surcharge tax income threshold, the fund has a liability to pay the surcharge tax. The fund may then pass that liability on to the individual member. However, as this is a tax accrued by an individual but payable by a third party, it is important that the third party has an opportunity to object to the extent of the tax liability in the first place. This opposition amendment will give the third party superannuation providers the opportunity to do just that. They may or may not choose to use the opportunity but, given the complexity of this legislation, it is appropriate to have this particular safeguard in place.

SPEECH.PARA: What I am about to say will relate to both opposition amendments 5 and 6. I foreshadowed the amendments earlier. They are designed to simplify the complex definition of allocated surplus amounts which will reduce the need for accumulation funds to use an actuary and also introduces an anti‐avoidance measure which prevents superannuation schemes from avoiding the surcharge tax.

Firstly, the amendments will alter the definition of allocated surplus amounts to something simpler but which still achieves the same anti‐avoidance purpose the government intended. Secondly, Labor's amendments will introduce new anti‐avoidance measures into the bill, which are designed to prevent some superannuation funds from avoiding paying the surcharge tax by virtue of taking a contributions holiday.

Labor is concerned the measure to tax contributions from allocated surplus reserves could effectively be a double tax on fund members. If a member's contribution is surcharge taxed on the way into a fund then some of that contribution is set aside in an investment fluctuation reserve and it will be a double tax if it is further surcharge taxed again when it returns to a member's account. Labor believes this measure will impact adversely on members of accumulation funds and is an unnecessary complication on top of what is already a complicated policy. In addition, it will further increase the collection costs of the surcharge tax, which will be passed on to all fund members regardless of their income. Our amendments are intended to fix this policy measure while achieving the same policy intention the government is hoping to achieve.

As I said earlier, these amendment bills put a new burden on superannuation funds to calculate the amount which is transferred from an allocated surplus reserve to an individual member's account. This is something which superannuation funds did not know they had to do until these amendment bills were introduced into the parliament a short time ago. If the measure is designed to prevent superannuation funds from avoiding the surcharge tax while on a contributions holiday then we support it in principle.

However, the way the government has decided to go about achieving its policy objectives is more complex than it needs to be; that is, something which is consistent with all of these bills though, I guess, the government response to this measure is no different from any other. Mr Noel Davis, lawyer from Clayton Utz, gave evidence to the superannuation select committee on this issue. Mr Davis's evidence is worth revisiting because it is quite instructive on the nature of this measure. About it he said:

I will read you the definition of an allocated surplus amount, because that is what the bill will tax. What you are being asked to pass is a defini tion of an allocated surplus amount that is in this form:

`Allocated surplus amount in relation to a member of a superannuation fund in relation to a financial year means an amount that is allocated by the relevant superannuation accumulation benefits provider for the benefit of the member in respect of the financial year other than an amount paid for or by the member to the provider to the extent to which the allocated amount exceeds an amount that in the opinion of the eligible actuary, according to Australian actuarial practice, is reasonable having regard to the amounts paid by or for the member to the provider in the funds investment earnings related to the member's interest in the fund and any other relevant matters.
He goes on:

What does that mean? Some people are going to ask me for advice on what that means and I am going to have to tell them that I have no idea. It may as well have been written in Russian. It is rubbish! Yet it is being put to you, having been passed by the House of Representatives, as legislation that you should pass in exercising good government. What bunkum that is!

Mr Davis went on to say that what this additional taxation on accumulated surplus amounts now requires is that accumulation funds that have never needed the services of an actuary are going to have to incur the expense of obtaining an actuarial expert on what is the taxable allocated surplus amount for members of the accumulation fund. Mr Davis also said:

How bad can this legislation get when that sort of concept is being put in it? You will notice, if you were listening, that it has in it a requirement that the actuary `determine the taxable amount having regard to actuarial practice'. Of course, there is no actuarial practice. You are being asked to pass legislation which, again, is unworkable.

That evidence, it has to be said, is pretty damning. I would have thought that the government may have wanted to respond to the issue. To my knowledge, the minister has not yet done so. However, Labor's amendment is designed to simplify the definition of allocated surplus amounts to include only those amounts credited to a member's account which have been used to offset contributions which would have been otherwise payable. In addition, we are proposing to insert an anti‐avoidance provision which specifically prevents persons from undertaking schemes which would allow a superannuation fund to avoid the surcharge tax. We believe it makes the provision much simpler and much less of an administrative burden on superannuation funds and the government's proposed amendments. It achieves the same policy outcome in a much less onerous manner. I commend it to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to opposition amendment No. 5, we believe that the proposed anti-avoidance measure is not necessary. If that is what is intended, the amendment needs to have a penalty clause inserted to be consistent with other provisions in an act. A penalty of 60 penalty points—that is, 6,600 for an individual trustee and 33,000 for a corporate trustee—would be needed if the logic of the penalties elsewhere applies.

The amendment does not cause the government undue concern. However, it is unclear when it would be applied and, frankly, whether it can be applied effectively. As I said, we do not think opposition amendment 5 is necessary.

In relation to opposition amendment 6—the definition of an allocated surplus amount—the concept of a surplus in a fund is an actuarial one. Therefore, an actuary needs to be involved to determine whether the surplus is surchargeable when allocated to the member. The current definition ensures that surpluses in accumulation schemes will be treated consistently with surpluses in defined benefit schemes. It is unclear whether the amendment will achieve the same outcome.

The Commissioner of Taxation, in consultation with the Australian Government Actuary, will issue a ruling to identify the circumstances in which a fund may have an allocated surplus amount. Certification from an actuary will be required only if a fund makes an allocation from surpluses. The ruling will also outline the methodology for working out the amount of surplus that is a surchargeable contribution. In broad terms, surplus amounts allocated to a member will be surchargeable contributions only if they are sourced from employer contributions. The current definition achieves the outcome sought by the opposition amendment.

The amendment proposed by the opposition is vague and does not reduce the degree of uncertainty. The commissioner will still need to issue a ruling to clarify its operation. The opposition amendment relies on an anti-avoidance provision which is equally vague and uncertain. The amendment's very vagueness may allow the commissioner to issue a ruling to explain its operation. However, in the government's view, the current definition is far preferable.
I know that the Democrats have withdrawn their amendment No. 11. In our view, opposition amendment No. 6 is preferable to Democrat amendment No. 11, but the government is still opposed to it.
