TAB.TAB: or (iii) that were retention bonuses and benefits for members of the Australian Defence Force;

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment refers to military retention bonuses. This amendment is similar to the amendments that were moved in the Senate when the legislation was first presented to this chamber—the original first tranche of legislation dealing with superannuation contributions and termination payments taxes.

The purpose of this amendment is to exempt from the calculation of income certain payments that are received by members of the Australian Defence Force. These are payments that are received as retention bonuses. Retention bonuses are made available to members of the services for very good reasons of requirement of the government. These are bonuses paid to people in the services to retain the services skills that are in short supply, and individual people who the services have determined are important to be retained. These individuals are being asked to continue their service in the defence of Australia and, in consideration of their willingness to serve future years, are receiving a financial payment.

This government has already determined that retention bonus payments are to be included as income for surcharge tax purposes, which will place virtually all of the recipients over the threshold above which the additional superannuation tax will by incurred—that is, unless this amendment is supported. In our submission there is no justification for, on the one hand, asking service personnel to give extra years service and, on the other, hitting them about the head with an extra superannuation tax. In the case of, say, pilots in the RAAF and in the army and air traffic controllers, where there has been an acute shortage for some years, the government has actually gone out of its way to entice those people to stay on by offering them a special superannuation bonus. Having offered them a special bonus, it intends to slug their superannuation when they finally get it.

What is particularly galling about this measure is that no advice is being given to people in the services about the effects on their superannuation of accepting the bonus. It is bad enough that the government is actually doing this, but what is absolutely underhand is that the government is not even advising the service personnel that, if they do what the government asks them to do and stay on in the service of the defence forces, they are going to get hit with extra tax on their superannuation benefit, which for many people in the services is a fundamentally important condition of service.

They are not even being given the advice that their superannuation is going to be reduced if they agree to stay on. You have to ask yourself how honest that is. You have to ask yourself what would happen if the government actually came clean with those pilots, air traffic controllers and people in other key positions and told them, `You do what we ask you to do. Stay on and fly a Hercules aircraft or an FA18 for us instead of going off to Qantas or Cathay and earning big buckets of money, because we want your special skills.' But the government keeps tight lipped about what it is going to do with their superannuation.

It is important to understand that these payments that the government is going to include—which will take people over the income threshold for superannuation tax purposes, which will reduce their superannuation payment because the government is going to grab extra tax from them—do not actually contribute to their superannuation benefit. Yes, they get a cash payment. They get a bonus on their income. But that bonus is not actually included to improve their superannuation benefit at all. So it is not as though it goes into their income calculation to boost their superannuation benefit—and then you take a slice of that. They do not get any superannuation increase out of this money. What they get is extra tax imposed on them by virtue of this legislation, which will strip away some of their superannuation benefits.

If the government is not willing to support these amendments, it should at least be honest and open with the defence personnel of Australia. When it says to them, `We want you to stay on and we will offer you a bonus,' it should at least be honest and open and say about it, `And if you accept it you will go over the threshold and incur an additional tax on your superannuation benefit.'

The retention benefit is available also to those service personnel who are in the MSBS, which was introduced by the former Labor government in 1991. The scheme provides that people with 15 years service who undertake a further five years service also get a retention payment. That bonus is not given to them just for length of service. It is given to people selectively on the basis that they have skills to contribute that we want to retain. The simple fact of life is that the government of the day and the chiefs of the Defence Force identify individuals whom they want to retain. In just about every one of the cases, those people are individuals who have some very marketable skills. The reason the government offers them a retention bonus to stay on is precisely that they have marketable skills that see them highly sought after by the private sector. There has been a drain of those key persons and key positions within the defence forces.

The fact then remains that the government provides a significant financial incentive to keep those people, because they have very marketable skills that the private sector head hunts. If they agree to stay on in the service, they will have an additional 15 per cent tax on their superannuation imposed on them. Many of those people do not currently go over the $70,000 threshold; their wages are not that high. Some will, but many will not. It is precisely those people whom you are going to slug with one hand as you try to entice them with the other.

People in the defence forces, particularly the ones we are talking about, are not stupid. They may not be aware of the pea and thimble trick you are playing on them in this legislation when they sign on. But one thing is certain: as they draw closer to their retirement from the services, they will become aware of it. They will think back on the deception that you have perpetrated and will be very disgruntled long-term service personnel. There are enough problems with morale in the defence forces at the moment because of decisions that this government has taken and the ineptitude in the whole range of areas in terms of policy development and structural reform. That ineptitude is causing its own set of problems.

I seek from the government, if it is not willing to support this amendment, a clear statement about its intentions as to the advice it will provide defence personnel, those who have already accepted a retention bonus and those who will be offered the retention bonus in the future. I seek from the government a clear commitment that it will provide full details to each of those individuals who is offered a retention bonus of the impact the acceptance of that retention bonus will have on their superannuation and, in particular, the impact this 15 per cent superannuation tax will have on them. In the course of the debate, I would appreciate a clear statement from the government on that important point of principle. I urge the Senate to support this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats cannot support this amendment from the opposition. It seeks to remove the retention bonuses from the definition of `assessable income' for the purposes of the superannuation surcharge tax. The argument is that these bonuses paid after 15 years of services in the armed forces and then every five years bump many service personnel into the surchargeable range for a single year. We recognise that problem; but we do not believe that exempting retention bonuses is completely fair, given that they are part of salary and they are income. I foreshadow our amendment No. 10, which is a compromise and I think solves the problem in a much more satisfactory way—that is, that bonuses would be averaged out over that five-year period. That would ensure that one year would not be exceptional and would not push the income up in a way which the current legislation does.
—I indicate that, given the choice of two, the Greens (WA) would prefer to support the Democrats' amendment No. 10 which does average the retention bonus over five years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had this debate before. Generally, allowances, including military retention bonuses, form part of assessable income of taxpayers. There really is no rationale to exempt bonuses paid to one group of people from the income test for surcharge purposes. There are many people who receive allowances for a variety of reasons. Members of the defence forces who receive a retention allowance in a financial year, as stated, may well be high income earners in that year. The surcharge was intended to apply to high income earners.

SPEECH.PARA: To exempt military retention bonuses will create significant administrative difficulties as, I am advised, there is no ready way of identifying this particular allowance. This will be a particular problem in the period 20 August 1996 to 30 June 1997. The government opposes this amendment. We think people have failed to develop the rationale for it. There may well be seen by other groups an inequity because allowances which they receive may be included as part of assessable income of the taxpayer. We are opposed to this amendment.

If one could say one thing in its favour, it is slightly preferable to Democrats' amendment No. 10 for administrative reasons. The Democrat amendment requires the bonuses to be averaged over five years. I think we would have to see how that could be best achieved. But we are opposed to both amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —What needs to be clearly understood here is that, while a retention bonus is paid and certainly while that forms part of income for taxable reasons, the defence forces make no superannuation contribution on behalf of the recipient of the retention bonus to their superannuation fund. I think that is an important point to weigh in consideration when this matter is voted on.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a reservation, since we are in anticipation of the Democrats' amendment, which also relates to the point touched on by the minister, that is, that you average it out over five years. By doing that, in certain circumstances it could conceivably push a person into a bracket in which the surcharge tax is payable as opposed to a year on year event when it may not in some years do that. I think that is a defect in the Democrats' amendment.

Having said that, in my remarks in introducing this amendment I drew attention to the fact that when retention payments are offered to key personnel to retain them in the services of Australia's defence—these are people who are sought after in the private sector and are actively head hunted—no indication, on my advice, is given to them that the retention benefits will have this impact. Will the government at least do the honest thing by those defence service personnel and advise them of that so they can make a decision in full possession of all the facts at the time?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I think I can assist you to a certain extent in this matter. I am advised that the recently issued information statement sent to all members of the Australian Defence Force included information about the superannuation surcharge. The information indicated that the surcharge would be based on tax assessable income. Such income would include any taxable bonus. The tax office and Comsuper, which is the scheme administrator for the military superannuation schemes, will provide members with ongoing information in relation to the surcharge. Comsuper also periodically sends a newsletter to service pay centres on topical issues affecting members' superannuation entitlements. In relation to the comments you made, that should provide some comfort.

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor will not be supporting this amendment. It is important to remember why we moved our amendment in the first place. We moved it to exclude military retention bonuses from income for surcharge tax purposes. Military retention bonuses are paid to encourage serving military personnel to be retained in the military for a further period of time. Therefore, taxing it additionally is contrary to the purpose of giving it in the first place. Once armed forces personnel become aware that their retention bonuses are going to be subject to an additional tax, which if they are low or middle income earners they would not normally be required to pay, that could adversely affect their decision to stay in the armed forces.

SPEECH.PARA: But what is completely inconsistent about including military retention bonuses as income for surcharge tax purposes is that these bonuses are not included as income used to determine an employer's superannuation obligation on behalf of an employee. That means that, according to the government, it is okay to tax these bonuses but it is not okay to give an employee an additional superannuation contribution based on their higher income level. That is an inconsistency which disadvantages military personnel.

The Democrats' amendment misses the point by suggesting that military retention bonuses should be averaged over five years. In addition, the averaging of retention bonuses over five years could see someone just under the surcharge tax income threshold limit pushed over that threshold for five years in a row instead of for one year only. So there is a potential for this amendment to make it worse for those military personnel just below the surcharge tax threshold. That is why we will not be supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments are necessary because of the continued insistence of the government to disregard the orders of the Senate. These are amendments that call the surcharge a tax. When these bills were last in this place the titles of the bills were amended through an agreement between the government and the Democrats to reflect the reality that the measure which the government was calling a `surcharge' was in reality a tax. Because the word `tax' is in the title of the acts of parliament governing this measure one would think that that is what the government would use when describing it. But that is not the case. Senator Kemp continually refers to this measure as a `surcharge' when he knows full well it is a tax. In recent advertising campaigns run by the Australian Taxation Office we see the word `surcharge' continually used instead of `tax'. I showed Senator Kemp a copy of that ad in the estimates process.

The advertisement is reminding people that if they do not quote their tax file number they will be subject to the superannuation tax. I have a copy of the ad here. The tax office has chosen the slogan, `Don't make an expensive mistake'. That is an appropriate slogan to use because we all know that it will be an expensive mistake for a low income earner who does not quote his or her tax file number. They will incur the full 15 per cent superannuation tax on their superannuation contributions. Even if they do quote their tax file number and do, by some miracle, avoid paying the 15 per cent superannuation tax they will still end up paying for the superannuation tax through higher fees and charges as a result of the government's mistake in the collection method.

So the advertisement is misleading. It says that you can avoid paying the superannuation tax by providing your tax file number to your superannuation fund. But that is not true. Many people will pay for this tax in many different ways and there is no way to avoid it. There is no way to avoid the tax unless the government wants to reconsider changing the collection method it has chosen for this measure—which it seems very reluctant to do.

Nevertheless, this approach tries to inject some further honesty into the government's approach to this measure by inserting into the many bills which govern the superannuation tax measure the definition that wherever the word `surcharge' appears it means a tax. This definition is currently in only one of the superannuation tax bills, the Superannuation Contributions Tax (Assessment and Collection) Act 1997, but not in any of the others. This amendment might help the Australian Taxation Office itself to get the message right because it seems a little confused as to whether the super tax is a surcharge or a tax.

I refer to an ATO press release of 9 September 1997 launching the Australian Taxation Office's tax file number advertising campaign entitled, `Quote your tax file number to avoid 15 per cent tax'. I have a copy of that here should honourable senators be interested in seeing it. According to the title of the press release, the tax office seems to think that the government's surcharge is a tax. But even the ATO is a bit confused on this one because further into the press release it calls it a 15 per cent surcharge.

If the ATO is confused about what this measure is supposed to be, what about ordinary taxpayers who may not be across the ins and outs of the debate on this issue? Perhaps they think they will be slugged for two measures—a surcharge of 15 per cent and, in addition, a superannuation tax of 15 per cent. We hope that this amendment will clarify any confusion the ATO may have, but more importantly, any confusion that may be in the minds of individual taxpayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think perhaps the Australian Taxation Office was having a bob each way to try to avoid the claim of false advertising. But we have supported calling the surcharge a tax in the past and I will support these amendments this time.
—The Democrats will not support these amendments. I think we are now starting to become a bit pedantic, and the point was already made in the previous debate about the surcharge back in May.

—I will not be going over old trails, but this is a matter which, as I recall it, we did seek to deal with last time this matter came before the chamber. We are hoping to call a spade a spade, a tax a tax. I have no doubt that the taxation department knows what it is on about. It is their area, and they are perfectly clear in their minds that it is a tax. I believe that it is incumbent on the government to support the taxation department in its assessment of what they are on about. We talked about end times at the beginning of this debate, and I am not going to talk about the beginning of time, but from time almost immemorial there have been tax collectors. I will not say generally speaking, but quite often it has been a respectable, honourable occupation, I guess, if they are seeking to work for the betterment of public polity and to collect taxes which have been democratically decided upon for the purposes of benefiting the community as a whole. Some of my best friends are tax collectors, and it is a most onerous task.
—You are not taxist.

—No, I am not taxist; I will acknowledge that. But it is an honourable and onerous task, and by and large they perform their functions admirably. On this occasion, the advertisements that have been read out by the shadow minister, Senator Cook, clearly show that the taxation department is prepared to call a spade a spade. I think the onus really is on the government, on the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to stand up for his people and accept that particular fact and therefore accept the amendment that has been put forward by Senator Cook.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we have had this debate for a fairly long period of time, if I remember correctly. I am not too sure this was not the first question that was ever asked of me in this chamber. Senator, you can call a spade a shovel but it is still a spade. The opposition has had innumerable bites at this cherry, and this is yet another bite at the cherry. It shows you perhaps how poorly drafted the first range of amendments on this issue was. We are now back onto it. We will, of course, be opposing this, as you would expect. It is a surcharge, and that remains the government's view. It is widely known in the community as a surcharge. The funds refer to it as a surcharge typically. So it is a bit of an effort at point scoring here, but the fact of the matter is that it is generally accepted in this area as a surcharge. We naturally are opposing amendments Nos 8 to 10. I have some comprehensive notes on this which I do not think need to be shared with the committee, given the late hour, but we will oppose it. It is a surcharge and the government stands by its position.

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN MACDONALD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —The environmental problems being experienced in some Asian cities are enormous, but I am pleased to say that I believe that the governments in the region are aware of the problems and are starting to take positive steps to correct those problems. Last week I had the honour of representing the Australian government on the Joint Working Group on the Environment in Jakarta, Indonesia, initiated by the Australian Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, and the Indonesian Environment Minister, Mr Sarwono, during the Australia‐Indonesia Ministerial Council meeting earlier this year. The joint working group was chaired jointly by Ms JoAnne DiSano from Environment Australia and Mr Harry Horsono from the Ministry of Environment, Indonesia.

SPEECH.PARA: It was a pleasure for me to attend the opening session and to meet initially with the leader of the Indonesian delegation, Mrs Neike Ismardani Kuryana of the Indonesian House of Representatives, and Mr Sudarsono, the Secretary Minister for the Environment. The working group involved officials from Environment Australia and the Indonesian Environment Ministry, together with business people from both Indonesia and Australia. Twenty‐nine Australian businesses accepted Senator Hill's invitation to be part of the working group.

BREAK.PARA: The working group discussed a wide range of matters and ended up with conclusions in six areas. These were: air pollution; waste water treatment and water supply management; marine environment and pollution control; environmental management and auditing; renewable energy; and community education and specialist training. A communique issued following the working group's deliberations highlighted the progress that had been made in both the development and consolidation of a multi‐stakeholder approach to addressing the six areas of priority. Another initiative was the identification of joint coordinators from Indonesia and Australia to progress activities under the six areas of cooperation. Finally, the importance that was attached to the development of partnerships not only between private sector representatives but also between governments and private sectors of both countries was indeed a really positive result from the working group.

Recently, because of haze problems, environmental management and the involvement of key sectors of the community have been more in the minds of both the Indonesian and the Australian people. The Indonesian government has been encouraging the private sector to play more of a role in the environment through various programs such as proper Prokasih, which is the business performance rating, the blue sky program and Adipura. With this private sector focus, the market potential for environmental products and services in the coming years is growing rapidly. Australia is, of course, well positioned in the market to play an active and positive role.

While in Jakarta I took the opportunity, in my capacity as parliamentary secretary with responsibility for the Bureau of Meteorology, to visit the Indonesian meteorological and geophysical organisation, Badan Meteorlogi dan Geofisika or, more simply, BMG. The close working relationship between the Australian Bureau of Meteorology and BMG has resulted in many positive activities, not the least of which was the help that the Australian bureau gave to the Indonesian government at the time of the recent bushfire problems. I enjoyed and benefited from my meeting with the Director‐General of BMG, Mr Sri Diharto, and his senior officers. We are hopeful of further collaboration between the weather organisations of our two nations in the time ahead.

I was also pleased to be able to represent the Australian government at the official opening of the Seventh International Exhibition on Equipment and Systems for Pollution Control and Environmental Improvement and to visit the Australian exhibitors at the exhibition. The conversations I had with Australian exhibitors showed that they were very keen to do business with Indonesia and were looking for a government to government relationship to ensure that the regulations which the Indonesian government had wisely promulgated were enforced.

Many Australian businesses are doing business in Indonesia in the environmental field, and particularly in planning and managing water and sewerage projects. The city of Jakarta is about to embark on an ambitious program to sewer the whole of the city of Jakarta within the next 10 years and I was able to have discussions with the vice governor on that matter. I was also able to meet with a group of Australian business people who have become associated with this project through the New South Wales government and Jakarta city government sister state relationship.

While problems, particularly in Jakarta, are immense, my discussions with the Minister for the Environment, Mr Sarwono, and his senior officers showed that the Indonesian government has a keen understanding of the problems and a desire to do something about them. Minister Sarwono, in my discussions with him, indicated the steps that the Indonesian government would be taking to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in that country. The minister indicated that Indonesia wanted to play its part in achieving a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions.

A city that has expanded as rapidly as Jakarta has is bound to have a lot of social and housing problems. I was pleased and privileged to inspect a new housing township, Lippo Karawaci, on the outskirts of Jakarta in an area that is providing its own water and sewerage. Hopefully, this is a demonstration of how clean water and proper disposal of sewage and waste can be achieved in Indonesia.

The people of northern Australia, where I come from, live closer to the 200 million Indonesians than we do to our fellow Australians in the southern population centres. It is important, therefore, that both Australia and Indonesia work cooperatively together to protect and enhance the regional environment. I am encouraged by my discussions with the minister as to the work which we can do jointly to look after the environment in our part of the world.

On my way to Jakarta I was also pleased to be able to attend the first round table on cleaner production, which was being hosted by Thailand with the support of the United Nations environment program and the World Bank. A round table that was expected to draw about 50 people had an attendance of over 200 people from all over the world who were interested in cleaner production in Asia. The conference and the related exhibition generated considerable discussion on how Asian and Pacific countries can work together to tackle some of the problems of cleaner production. I had the honour of delivering the closing address to the first round table and, in doing so, indicated the desire of the University of Queensland and the Queensland cleaner production task force to host next year's second round table on cleaner production and the associated trade fair in the Queensland capital of Brisbane.

My short time in Bangkok allowed me to obtain a first‐hand understanding of the severe pollution problems that city has. Again, I am encouraged that, whilst there is a long way to go, there is an understanding that clean water, modern sewerage systems, a reduction in energy use and better disposal of waste are all matters which need to be addressed.

I was also encouraged by the good work which the Thai meteorological service does in its weather and climate forecasting in South‐East Asia. That region suffers from typhoons and floods, as we do in Australia, and there is a lot each country can do to help the other with in this area. Interestingly, the King of Thailand takes a very keen interest in meteorological matters and I am told that the palace is actually directly linked to the met services computers.

On a less positive note, the recent currency crisis in both Thailand and Indonesia has caused real economic and social problems. High‐rise building work has simply stopped mid‐floor and I was told that over a million unskilled labourers had recently been made redundant and dismissed. Because of the drought, these unskilled workers, who principally come from the country, are unable to return to their homelands, thus exacerbating the unemployment and difficult social problems in Indonesia. As Australia's eighth largest export market, the health of the Indonesian economy is of vital interest to Australia. It is certainly in Australia's interests as well as the interests of the people of both Indonesia and Thailand for the Australian government to give appropriate financial assistance to overcome the more immediate impacts of the currency crisis.

Governments in both countries are tightening their belts in a way that Australia has done since the advent of the Howard government. The experiences of these two countries at least provide graphic illustrations of what can happen if countries spend beyond their means. I am pleased that Australia is able to help our neighbours in their financial difficulties and also that we are able to join with our neighbours in promoting a better environment in our region.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to refer to the Abstudy changes that took place in this year's budget, and also to table a document from an Abstudy summit that took place in my home state of South Australia on 30 July this year which examined some of those proposed changes by the government. I thank all sides for agreement to table that particular document by SAAETAC, the South Australian Aboriginal Education and Training Advisory Committee.

BREAK.PARA: The cuts to the Abstudy budget of this year total $48 million. They are some of the most savage cuts, I believe, of recent budgets in that they target those in the community who are most marginalised. Also, they are completely at odds with the direction in which we should be heading as a nation—that is, we should be investing in the talents and the skills of Australians of all ages. But, in particular, we should be seeking to increase rates of participation of those traditionally under‐represented or unrepresented groups in our education and training systems. Clearly, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians must be encouraged to participate in education and training.

Unfortunately, the government seems to have pursued rather a different direction—that is, hiking up fees and charges and, of course, introducing up-front and full cost fees. Also, a minimal number of scholarships will be provided over the four years to students, presumably being those from previously under‐represented socioeconomic and other ethnic groups in our society, in order to encourage them to enter into and participate in higher education specifically, but education and training generally.

According to some statistics from the groups that I have spoken to, it is my understanding that, out of the 4,000 scholarships based on merit that will be available over the next four years for those particular groups, an Aboriginal and Islander person hoping to attend a university like Sydney will have a one in 4,000 chance. They are their estimated odds, and they are not particularly good.

I do note, however, that the former Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Amanda Vanstone, had some sense of the dramatic and likely negative impact of these changes on participation rates of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in higher education specifically. To her credit—and I will give her credit where credit is due—she was commencing negotiations, with a number of Aboriginal and islander groups and education sector representatives, designed to ameliorate some of the worst aspects of the proposed changes. So I just put on notice tonight that I would be very curious to hear what stage those negotiations are at, if they are still proceeding, and what hope there is for those students who are uncertain about either aspiring to a higher education or continuing in education because they are uncertain that their Abstudy benefits would be available to them.

The SAAETAC summit on 30 July this year noted their concerns about the possible impact on participation rates. It also noted their considerable concern at the lack of consultation that had taken place with education providers, Aboriginal educational advisory committees and, of course, Aboriginal community organisations. So the government failed to consult widely with these organisations.

These are concerns I have heard echoed not only within the context of the summit but more generally around the country from a range of groups and, specifically, I have to say, the Bachelor College in the Northern Territory. That is a college that provides education for Aboriginal and Islander students, and they are very concerned about the potentially devastating impact on their college.

The main criticisms surrounding the government's changes include the introduction in the abatement rate for the Austudy living allowance and dependent spouse allowance. This is without a clearly defined threshold. So, even though these groups welcome the indication of the change with an abatement rate, without any clear ideas as to the threshold level, there are some great concerns as to what impact that might have.

The away from base allowance is now being reduced, supposedly, to two trips per year. This is expected to have a severe impact on residential schools or on those courses which are referred to as `block release' courses, particularly in remote communities. There is added concern about changes to compassionate travel. I should note that this is not a particularly compassionate move by the government but it is one that may negatively impact on students who may need to fulfil cultural obligations during their course or a semester.

The conclusions reached as a result of these proposals and the suggested changes or amendments by the summit are most adequately represented in the group's report—and I strongly commend it to you, Madam President, and the Senate. The authors and the key participants in the process include Mr Frank Lampard, the chair of SAAETAC, Mr Rod Williams, Ms April Blair and Mr Alwin Chong. I commend them for their work in the production of the summit paper.

I would take this opportunity to refer briefly to the tragic death in recent days of Australian singer Michael Hutchence, a performer admired and respected by many Australians, regardless of their age—but particularly young Australians to whom I have spoken in the last 24 hours and who have expressed their concern. I ask all in this place to remember that, certainly over the last two decades, many young Australians have grown up with the music of Michael Hutchence and his band INXS. I think it is worth remembering at this time his song Original Sin, which is a song opposing racism.

I also wish to express my concern tonight at some of the newspaper and media reports of this tragic event. In particular, allegedly, one prominent Australian performer was informed on camera of this man's death. I would have thought that—certainly in light of the tragic death of the Princess of Wales and the consequent media and privacy debates and discussions that have taken place—perhaps people would have been a little more caring in the way they treated this issue. I have also been concerned to see the very detailed reports of the method by which Michael Hutchence died. The incidence of copycat deaths means that the media needs to be more mature about how they choose to report a case such as this.

This death follows not long after that of popular footballer Peter Jackson—also another young man, well known and liked, with a young family, who appeared to have a lot to live for but who died alone. I wish to refer briefly to the editorial in today's Advertiser—yes, my home‐town paper—and to what I think is quite a fitting comment. It states:

In the end, however, it is not a superstar who makes that terrible exit but another human being, happy or sad, contented or tormented, achiever and victim and, in the end, alone just like us. His name, his talent, his antics and lifestyle make him front‐page news around the world. In the end, though, his death is a tragedy not for those reasons but because all young deaths are a tragedy.

In remembering these people, we eulogise their lives, not the manner of their deaths. I thank you for allowing me to pay a brief tribute to a wonderful performer who, no doubt, lit up the lives of many Australians and, of course, paved the way for a sort of unique brand of funky 80s and, more recently, 90s music and, of course, broke into the US charts as a top Australian performer—no mean feat, I might add.

I believe it is the role of parliament and all honourable members in this place to remember proud and prominent Australians regardless of their age but because of their commitment, their passion and their work. I acknowledge that many young Australians are looking for a way through, not a way out. So I take this opportunity to commend the work of Lifeline services, including their 24-hour counselling service which operates nationally on 131114. It is specifically targeted at young people aged five to 18 years. They also have Kids Helpline. I seek leave to table the Abstudy summit report from the conference of 30 July 1997.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —As we stand here tonight, this nation is being held to ransom. It is being held to ransom by a group of activists who have absolutely no interest in honestly discussing issues with the Australian people. Perhaps the worst of that group of activists is Mr Noel Pearson, the head of the Cape York Land Council.

SPEECH.PARA: I was disturbed to find Mr Pearson saying on the weekend that the possible compensation bill for the extinguishment of native title as a result of the amendments that the government proposes would be in the vicinity of $2 billion. If you do not live in Far North Queensland and are not familiar with Cape York Peninsula, you might believe some of this nonsense. I want to take this opportunity tonight to outline to the Senate how patently false, dishonest and immoral this particular scare campaign is. Because it is all of those things. In fact, it disgusts many people who are familiar with the facts. The facts have never bothered Mr Pearson, as he has shown again on the weekend.

First of all, under the schedule of leases which the government proposes will extinguish native title, hardly any of the leases on Cape York Peninsula will appear because most of them are non-scheduled leases. In other words, it is not possible for those leases to extinguish native title. Let us leave that aside. Let us just talk about the value of the leases that exist in Cape York, because I do not want to transgress on any bills before the chamber. There are 105 pastoral leases of more than 500 hectares on Cape York Peninsula. They amount to some 14 million hectares of land. On an unimproved land value of about $1 a hectare, their total value would be about $14 million—$1 a hectare for 14 million hectares equates to $14 million.

If, however, you took a survey of those leases at roughly the market rate, which seems to be about half a million dollars a lease, simple mathematics tells you that 105 leases at half a million dollars a lease works out at roughly $52½ million. That is the total value of all of the pastoral leases in Cape York put together. I do not know where Mr Pearson did his mathematics, but you do not have to be Albert Einstein to know that, if those leases are worth $52 million in their entirety, you could buy those leases 40 times over with $2 billion. You could buy them 40 times over. Yet he had the audacity to go on national television and scare the voters of this country by saying that the compensation bill for the passage of this legislation would be $2 billion.

There could be nothing more grossly dishonest than that. It is part of the typical scare campaign that we see from the Cape York Land Council. Mr Pearson and the Cape York Land Council have broken just about every promise they have ever made to a government in this country. It is a fact that Mr Pearson promised in November 1993 that they would not make claims against pastoral leases in Queensland. It is also a fact that in March the following year Mr Pearson was a signatory to the Wik claim that made claims to pastoral leases over all of Cape York Peninsula in spite of the undertaking he had given at the National Press Club in November. That is how much Mr Pearson's word is worth. It is not worth the paper it is written on.

You have to ask yourself another question, Madam President. Mr Pearson has constantly told this country that native title is not a land grab by Aborigines; it is about the right to fish, hunt, gather and carry on traditional ceremonies. If it is just about the right to fish, hunt and gather, how could the compensation bill be $2 billion? If it is merely a right to access the land to go fishing or bowl over a few roos or conduct a ceremony here and there, there is no way that the compensation bill could even approach the market value of the leases over that land—absolutely no way.

What is Mr Pearson's agenda? Is it outright dishonesty in misleading the Australian people about the potential size of any compensation payment? Or is Mr Pearson's real agenda about something more than a right to hunt, gather and fish? I think Mr Pearson has not only a glaring credibility problem but also a glaring consistency problem. He has been caught out by his own dishonesty. Either this native title right is a fairly minor right, in which case it could hardly give rise to much compensation at all—as you would know, Madam President, having been a very distinguished lawyer in this territory—or, on the contrary, he is asking for something much more. But even then it would not come to $2 billion. So you have to ask: what is Mr Pearson going on about?

I do not think he has any credibility left, especially when you consider this one additional factor. The Cape York Land Council, an organisation of which he is a titular head, was involved in something called the Cape York Peninsula land use study, or CYPLUS for short. It is interesting to note that the CYPLUS recommendations which are endorsed by the Cape York Land Council argue that the number of cattle on Cape York Peninsula should be increased from 115,000 to 400,000.

Mr Pearson is saying, `We, as Aborigines, believe you can increase the size of the cattle industry and you can make it more intensive.' Yet in the Wik claim he is saying, `This is horrible; this is transgressing the rights of Aboriginal people.' In the CYPLUS the Cape York Land Council signed off on a report which recommended not only more than trebling the size of the cattle herd in Cape York Peninsula, but also the increased use of fencing and increasing the area of improved pasture to 80,000 hectares.

Where is the consistency here? Either you believe that there is some enormous threat to Aboriginal interests by allowing the pastoral industry to continue as it is or you believe that the intensity and scale of the pastoral industry should be increased. But the two positions are not consistent.

It makes me form the view that Mr Pearson has a position for wherever he is. But the positions are not always consistent. As always, there are some people in the press gallery who give this sort of nonsense from Mr Pearson much more credit and credibility than it deserves. It is about time that Mr Pearson apologised to the Australian people for the appalling displays we have seen from him of late. It is yet another outburst from a man who obviously has difficulty reconciling the facts with his own emotions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade: Salary Packaging

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 4 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the department negotiated or indicated a willingness to negotiate salary packaging for its employees.
(2) Has the department informed any staff of its intention to offer salary packaging schemes to its employees.
(3) Can a copy be provided of the communication in (2), as well as information regarding: (a) when it took place; and (b) what developments have occurred regarding implementation of salary packaging.
(4) Can details be provided of any salary packaging arrangements which have been made available to employees of the department.
(5) Can details be provided of the number of salary packaging arrangements which have been entered into by employees.

(6) (a) Are salary packaging arrangements being offered to all employees or only selected employees; (b) if selected employees, what class of employees is being offered salary packaging; and (c) what are the salary ranges applicable to these employees.
(7) What percentage of an employee's total salary is allowed to be taken as non‐salary benefits.
(8) Please list the options or items that are allowed to be salary packaged under any department arrangement.
(9) Do any of the arrangements offered benefit from an employer exemption from fringe benefit tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Question 1
. DFAT

. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade indicated in a discussion paper issued to staff on 25 August 1997 that remuneration packaging may be considered in the context of developing the Department's certified agreement.
. AusAID
. AusAID has made no decision regarding salary packaging, nor has it indicated a willingness or unwillingness to negotiate salary packaging for its employees at this time.
. Austrade

. Yes. The Australian Trade Commission (Austrade) Enterprise Bargaining Agreement provides for the introduction of flexible salary packaging for Austrade's senior executives. The Agreement also provides for consideration of the extension of the provision to all staff.
Question 2
. DFAT

. The Department has informed staff that it is prepared to consider offering salary packaging, and has asked for their views. A decision on salary packaging will be taken in the context of the negotiation of the certified agreement. A representative of a private firm was invited to speak at a public meeting of staff on 3 September to explain the concept of salary packaging.
. AusAID
. Not applicable.
. Austrade

. All staff are aware of the provisions of the Enterprise Agreement, but the option has not yet been formally introduced. Austrade has also indicated that the extension of salary packaging to all employees is on the agenda for a new workplace agreement.
Question 3
. DFAT
. Not applicable.
. AusAID
. Not applicable.
. Austrade
. Not applicable.
Question 4
. DFAT
. Not applicable.
. AusAID
. Not applicable.
. Austrade
. The option of salary packaging as negotiated under the Austrade Enterprise Agreement has not yet been formally introduced.
Question 5
. DFAT
. Not applicable.
. AusAID
. Not applicable.
. Austrade
. Not applicable.
Question 6
. DFAT
. Not applicable.
. AusAID
. Not applicable.
. Austrade
. (a) As indicated above the Agreement provided for the introduction of the provision to selected employees with the commitment to consider extension of the provision to all employees.
. (b) The agreement currently provides for application to Austrade's senior executive staff.
. (c) The salary ranges are as follows:

. DFAT
. Not applicable.
. AusAID

Question 8

Question 9

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs: Training for Employment Program

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 19 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) How much money was expended on the Training for Employment Program (TEP) in the 1996‐97 financial year; and (b) how much has been committed in the 1997‐98 financial year.
(2) How many job seekers have received assistance through the program since 1 July 1996.

(3) (a) How many contracts did the department sign with training providers during the 1996‐97 financial year; (b) how many contracts have been signed in the 1997‐98 financial year to date; (c) who were the providers; (d) what was the value of each contract; and (e) what was the cost per trainee in each contract.

(4) What procedures did the department follow to satisfy itself that these training providers had the necessary organisational background and capacity to deliver the training specified in the contract.
(5) Did the procedures in (4) identify any providers considered unsatisfactory; if so (a) how many training providers were found to be unsatisfactory; and (b) why were they unsatisfactory.

(6) As part of the above process, did the department seek advice concerning all companies offering to provide training services under the TEP from the Australian Securities Commission and the appropri ate State Corporate Affairs office; if so, what was the result, if not, how did the department satisfy itself that these companies were properly managed and their directors appropriately qualified.
(7) Did the department refuse to enter into an agreement with all operators that failed to meet the necessary standards.
(8) How many providers failed to satisfactorily perform the training they contracted to deliver in : (a) the 1996‐97 financial year; and (b) the 1997‐98 financial year to date.
(9) What action has been taken, or is planned, by the department in respect of non‐performing contractors.
(10) (a) How many training providers received advance payments; (b) what was the justification for advancing funds; and (c) what percentage of the contract price was advanced in each case.
(11) Can details be provided of the rules the department is obliged to follow when providing advance payments under the TEP.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) $36.617 million. This amount includes payments to providers and income support paid to participants.

(b) The Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs' computer information system records that as at 31 October 1997 the level of commitment made in 1997‐98 for TEP was $32.340 million.
(2) As at 31 October 1997, the total number of job seekers who have commenced under TEP since that program began on 7 October 1996 was 29,436.

(3) Under TEP the Department can purchase training in two ways—by contracting a whole course from a training provider (contracted course) or purchasing an individual place on an existing course (established course).

(a) The Department's computer system records the number of projects run by providers not the number of contracts. The number of projects will be greater than the number of contracts as in some cases providers can run several projects under one contract. In the 1996‐97 financial year 1208 projects were approved.
(b) In the 1997‐98 financial year 572 projects had been approved as at 31 October 1997.
(c), (d) and (e) see attached table **.
(4) Volume 6, section 1, the core guidelines for Labour Market Programs includes:

"To qualify as a suitable provider of LMP services, organisations must demonstrate the necessary organisational background and capacity (eg management and financial) to deliver the specified training or services. In approving providers, the Department considers the following:

. High preference for providers who are (or in the process of being) incorporated under the Australian Corporations Law, State Associations Incorporation Law or Aboriginal Councils & Associations Act, Government Instrumentality, Semi Government Authority, or Local Government Authority.
. The organisation must not be in receivership, being wound up or liquidated or subject to a deed of arrangement with creditors.
. Office holders, directors or managers of the organisation must not be an undischarged bankrupt.
. Where relevant, high preference for previous service delivery experience as an organisation (eg. a minimum of twelve months experience in delivering appropriate services)."

PARA.TAB: Volume 7, section 3, the guidelines specific to TEP also include:

ANSWER.PARA: "unless a Government Instrumentality, Semi or Local Government Authority, providers must be incorporated under Commonwealth, State or Territory legislation."

(5) There are various reasons why potential providers are not offered a contract under TEP: for example, the proposal is unacceptable because of local labour market demand or supply, capacity to undertake the required training to local established CES standards, cost considerations or previous unsatisfactory performance, as well as the application of the detail of the guidelines set out in answer 4 above. Detailed records of such reasons are not available for publication because it would be a breach of confidence.
(6) No. See answer to question 7.
(7) The CES core guidelines Volume 6, Section 1 state that:

"The Department should not enter into a contract with a LMP provider unless it is satisfied that the provider is able to undertake the services and there is reason to believe that Departmental funding will not be at risk."

There may be some situations where a need for training has been identified that can only be met by a particular provider. If the Department believes the risk is manageable the project would go ahead, however action would be taken to further minimise any possible risk by:
. making all payments in arrears;
. making smaller but more frequent payments instead of one or two large payments; or
. arranging a one‐off contract rather than a larger agreement to establish the provider's bona fides.

(8) and (9) Under TEP it is a provision in the contract that providers are required to complete a performance acquittal. The provider must state that they have delivered services in accordance with the contract before any further payments are made. This must be certified as correct by a DEETYA officer.
Volume 6, Section 1 of the CES guidelines states that:

"Where a provider has failed to meet their contractual obligations, there are a range of measures available to DEETYA under the contract, ie payment may be withheld, recovery action may occur or the contract may be terminated. The advice of Legal Group is sought before initiating any action.

An investigation must occur within five working days if it is suspected through a monitoring visit, or a complaint or information is received that a provider or employer is breaching the provisions of the Contract or Agreement or the objectives of the program. Action may change depending on local circumstances. All allegations or suspected breaches must be:
. negotiated and remedial action agreed where possible,
. discussed with Legal Group where appropriate, and
. fully documented.

In any case where there may be reason to suspect fraud, staff must not attempt to carry out their own fraud investigation The Region/Branch Office Manager must seek the assistance of the Fraud Prevention Unit in their State/Territory."

Legal Group's first priority is to protect the Commonwealth's funds and all necessary actions are taken to this end, as was done, for example, on 12 September 1997 in the Federal Court of Australia in relation to South Pacific Cruise Lines Limited.

(10) As advised in answer to question 3 above training purchased under the TEP program can be either a contracted or established course. Under an established course it is normal commercial practice to pay course fees prior to commencement of the course. Places on established courses make up approximately one third of the business written under TEP and this information is recorded on individual files. The Department's computer system records that since the commencement of the program on 7 October 1996 some 336 training providers received advance payments under TEP for various projects under their contracts.

(11) Volume 6, Section 1 of the CES guidelines and the Volume 7, section 3 of the TEP guidelines include: "payments in advance may be made if the Commonwealth gains an advantage from such an arrangement, eg the job seeker will only be accepted onto a course if payment is made prior to course commencement.
Wherever possible payments should be made in arrears. For contracted courses, providers should be instructed that if they require an advance payment it should be included in their tender.

For courses up to 13 weeks, a maximum of 50 per cent may be paid in advance and 50 per cent in arrears. Courses 14 to 26 weeks may be paid a maximum of 50 per cent in advance, 30 per cent during the course and 20 per cent in arrears. Courses over 26 weeks may have up to 40 per cent in advance, 20 percent as a second payment, a further 20 per cent as a third payment and the final 20 per cent in arrears.
The first payment cannot be made until the contract has been signed, and not earlier than two weeks before the date of the course commencement.
The final payment (which is to be made in arrears) is to be made after:
. the course has finished,
. receipt of an invoice,
. receipt of a satisfactory acquittal of any earlier advance payments,
. a performance acquittal has been completed by the DEETYA Project Officer, and
. receipt of a satisfactory post‐course report from the training provider.

For bulk contracts, ie. a single contract with a provider for a number of courses, the payment of any advances must be linked to course costs and commencement dates of individual courses, not the contract value as a whole."
** Copies of all tables are available from the Senate Tables Office.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Kakadu National Park World Heritage Area

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that a group of 20 major Australian and overseas environment groups recently wrote to the World Heritage Committee in Paris, asking that the World Heritage Kakadu national Park be listed as `World Heritage in Danger'.
(2) Is the Minister aware that the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Gundjedehmi Aboriginal Corporation wrote similar letters to the World Heritage Committee.
(3) What would be the effect of Australia's international environmental reputation if Kakadu National Park were to be listed as `World Heritage in Danger'.

(4) What will be the effect on Australia's international reputation, including as a tourist destination, if an additional uranium mine is established on a mineral lease excised from, but in every way contiguous with, the Kakadu National Park.

(5) What will be the effect on Australia's overseas reputation, including as a tourist destination, if an additional uranium mine is established on a mineral lease excised from, but in every way contiguous with, the Kakadu National Park if Kakadu's World Heritage status is declared to be `in danger'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 2 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the Eurogold mining project near Bergama, in Turkey:
(1) (a) What support did the previous government give to the Eurogold consortium; and (b) what support has been given since March 1996, through lobbying, financial, technical or other assistance.
(2) Can the Minister confirm that the department attended a meeting of Turkish politicians in Turkey in 1994 to lobby for the Eurogold project; if so: (a) who attended the meetings; and (b) why.
(3) Did the Australian Ambassador lobby Turkish ministers in support of the Eurogold project; if so, why.
(4) (a) Is the Minister aware that the project involves the use of cyanide; and (b) has the Australian Government supported the project knowing that it would use cyanide.
(5) Is the Minister aware that a Turkish court has ruled that the project cannot commence with the use of cyanide.

(6) Can the Minister confirm that: (a) there has been strong resistance to the project from local communities, including an occupation of the site; and (b) the Turkish community in Australia is also strongly opposed to the project; if so, why is the Australian government supporting the project against the wishes of the local community.

(7) (a) What powers does the Australian Government have to control overseas activities that may breach Australian environmental standards; (b) how have they been applied in this case; and (c) who was consulted.

(8) What criteria are applied to assess the environmental acceptability of projects such as this, in order to determine whether the Australian Government should support them in any way; (b) how were the criteria applied in this case; and (c) who was consulted.
(9) Can a list be provided of the date and nature of all documents held by the department that relate to the environmental evaluation of this project.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The previous Government supported the Eurogold consortium. During the visit by the then Turkish Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hikmet Cetin, to Australia in 1994 Australian Ministers expressed to him full support for the project. The project was also raised during his visit to Turkey in April 1995, for the third session of the Australia—Turkey Joint Economic Committee for Trade, Economic and Technical Cooperation, by the then Australian Minister for Trade. The minutes of that meeting referred positively to the venture.

(b) The present Australian Government has maintained this positive support against the background that, by March 1996, after some years of detailed analysis and consideration, the Turkish Government had completed the process of granting approvals for the full implementation of the project. While lobbying has continued, there has been no financial, technical or other assistance. Normal EFIC cover was offered for the export of some equipment from Australia to the project, but not taken up by the exporters.

(2) (a) and (b) The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is unable to identify such a meeting. However, Mr Allan Griffiths, MP, visited Turkey in August 1994. He had discussions with Ministers, members of the Turkish Grand National Assembly and others, in which he supported the Australian involvement. The Australian Ambassador was present at the meetings. Mr Griffiths was, at the time of his visit, a former Minister.

(3) Yes. The Australian Ambassador in Ankara has had discussions with Turkish Ministers concerning the Eurogold project. It is a normal function of Australian diplomatic representatives abroad to interest themselves in significant undertakings entailing Australian commercial involvement in the countries of their accreditation. The French and Canadian Ambassadors have also made representations, given that Eurogold is a consortium of French and Canadian as well as Australian interests.
(4) (a) Yes. The Government is aware that the project involves the use of cyanide.
(b) Yes. Australian Governments have supported the project knowing that the process of extraction involves the use of cyanide, as is used widely in gold recovery in Australia.

(5) Although a number of court cases which had been brought against the project and its environmental clearance had been resolved in its favour, the Turkish High Administrative Court, on appeal, found some merit in a challenge to the use of cyanide and called on the Izmir Administrative Court to review its earlier decision. Only on 15 October, 1997, did the Izmir Court overturn its earlier ruling and find against the cyanide leaching method.

6) (a) Yes. The Government is aware of the opposition by sections of the local community to the project. The Government is aware that this opposition has included invasion of the mine site. It has also included damage to equipment at the site in Bergama and the indiscriminate explosion of a bomb at the headquarters of Eurogold, in the city of Izmir.

(b) A petition against the project by members of the Turkish community in Australia has recently been sent to the Prime Minister. Judged by the number of signatures, opposition to the project in the Turkish community in Australia would appear to be confined to a small minority.

Despite any opposition from sections of the local community, it is appropriate for the Australian authorities to interest themselves in a significant overseas investment by an Australian company. It is for the Turkish authorities to make a final decision as to whether the project should go ahead. The Australian Government expects that any decision by the Turkish authorities will take into account such factors as the environmental impact, the economic benefits and the views of the local community.
(7) (a) The Australian Government has a limited ability to control the overseas activities of Australian companies that may breach Australian environmental standards.

If the proposed overseas activities involved action by an Australian agency covered by the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, then the provisions of that Act would apply. The Australian Government may, if necessary, refuse assistance, including the use of aid funds.

Otherwise, while under international law Australia has jurisdiction to legislate extraterritorially in a range of circumstances, it does not have the power directly to enforce its laws within the jurisdiction of other states. The usual absence of enforcement power is a fundamental reason why jurisdiction to legislate for Australian companies overseas is not often used.

Equally important, regulation of the activities of Australian companies overseas is also governed by the notion of "international comity", which is the general mutual respect and good behaviour which friendly states owe to each other. This is a self imposed restraint on states to avoid abuse of their rights and powers. It would be inappropriate for Australia to attempt to impose requirements on Australian companies operating in another country's jurisdiction where those requirements may conflict with the laws of that country. For example, Australian environmental standards may be ill‐suited to another country's circumstances and could be in conflict with its laws.

(b) and (c) The question does not arise. The project is not considered to violate Australian environmental standards. The Company has said, and the Turkish Government has accepted and required, that the environmental standards to be applied are among the highest in the world. The process is used in Australia, where, under appropriate strict procedures and construction (of the kind to be applied near Bergama) any environmental risk is controlled. Further, Eurogold is not, in fact, an Australian company. It is an international consortium, with only a minority Australian interest, and a registered Turkish company, which operates under Turkish law.

(8) (a) If the proposed overseas activities involved action by an Australian agency covered by the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, then the provisions of that Act would apply. Otherwise, there are no formal procedures nor hard and fast rules for assessing the environmental acceptability of overseas projects of Australian companies. In general, however, in deciding whether to provide routine support to a project, officials would normally be expected to take into account a wide range of factors, including, as well as any environmental considerations, the law and appropriate procedures in the country concerned, and the economic and commercial benefits to Australia and to the host country.

(b) The Australian authorities have not made a formal environmental assessment of the project. However, in providing routine support to it, the Australian authorities have taken into account the fact that it has been subject to environmental assessment by the Turkish authorities: the Turkish Ministry of the Environment granted formal environmental clearance for the project in October 1994; this assessment has been subject to testing through the Turkish legal system. In addition, the Australian Government has taken into account that the cyanide extraction process is used extensively in the gold mining industry internationally, including in Australia, where, with proper safeguards, it is not considered to pose an environmental hazard; and that the company has given assurances that proper safeguards will be implemented at the Bergama mine and has been prepared, after an initial period of operation, to invite international inspection of the mine site to verify its claims that the process does not cause any environmental problem. Australian officials have also taken into account that this is a major investment by an Australian company which will add considerably to the depth of Australian—Turkish commercial relations; that the investment accords with the objectives of the Turkish Government which attaches a high priority to encouraging foreign investment; that the local community and Turkey as a whole stand to derive significant economic benefits from the project; and that Australia also stands to benefit, both from the commercial success of an Australian company and from the indirect benefits to all Australian companies and economic interests in Turkey in what is expected will be a successful demonstration of Australian commercial enterprise and expertise.

(c) Consultations, principally by the Australian Embassy in Ankara, have included meetings with Turkish Ministers, Turkish officials, mining representatives and with representatives of the local community.

(9) The expenditure of resources needed to prepare such a list could not be justified, especially as, while there is material relating to the project in Departmental and Embassy files, there are only incidental references to environmental evaluations, by other authorities, of the project. Copies of Turkish Government assessments are not held. There has not been any formal environmental assessment of the project by Australian authorities.
